Dota 2 is a very highly skilled game, don't expect to walk in and expect you being very good. You are going to die alot and probably yell at your team mates but that's just the nature of this game. Dota 2 takes place in an arena where you will fight to destory the enemies Anicent if you destory it; you win.  The Ancient is protected by 11 stuctures called towers that protect it. Each of these towers are found in each of the three lanes bottom, middle and top. You take control of a unit that is a hero, many of them are diverse and have a lot of pros and cons such as Crystal Maiden who is really good at locking down heros early game with her stun but she is also the slowest hero in the game.   You are accompanied by 4 other players including yourself to fight against another 5 players. You need to push lanes to be able to destory the enemy towers in each lane but the catch is the enemy team is doing the same thing, so you need to not only push to your victory but to stop the enemy team from pushing aswell.   There is 107 heros in Dota 2 out of the 112 heroes that are in the Warcraft III. They are categorised into 3 groups. Strenght, which are usually the tanky guys. Agility, most carries are found in this category and Intelligence which most of the supports are usually found. All these heroes have different skill levels,  You can customise your Dota experience with annoucer packs which change the voice of the annoucer which include Glados and the narrator from the Stanley Parable. You can change your HUD to different themes example Familiar Woods dat just like Furion / Nature's Prophet world.  i know Dota 2 is a hard game because dota 2 always update patch and getting further, but Dota 2 is a nice game to play it to spare away your angry or bored something like dat...

Dota 2 in a very strategic challenging game. I know a lot of people start playing Dota and get discouraged because of how brutal it is when you get started. Don't give up! Don't be afraid to ask players for help and watch videos, watch TONS of videos. Read guides and builds, and experiment with every hero in bot matches. Go to the Library in-game and read up on every hero and item. Don't skip the tutorials! They may seem boring or dry at first but they really, really useful. This game can be extremely fun, and so fulfilling when you play it. There will be games that your team gets stomped with a 74-16 game....don't worry about it. There will be other games where the entire game is tied and both team have the same amount of towers down and neither team can get ahead, and it reaches over an hour. When it does finally end, whether you won or lost, it won't matter because both teams realize it could have went either way and that is was a truly amazing game. It is moments like that when you are congratulating the other team on a good game, not just because it is expected of you, but because it really was a great game. This is why you need to stick it out in the beginning and keep on trying. More than likely you will start out with a 2-17-4 score, but that's ok! Because in no time you will have that game, the game where your team worked together amazing and your hero was a perfect counter to their entire team and you'll get that 44-6-12 game.  As far as the gameplay is, Valve is very good about fixing the bugs. Most bugs are only on for a few days before a fix has come out. The game is very stable. The only problems I could have with Dota 2 are with the servers. There have been server issues and sometimes it causes you to have an abandon which wasn't fair, but non reversible. Also, there are issues if setting your language preference to English and you get paired with players who don't know any English, this can get frustrating.  All in all, Dota 2 is well worth the hours put into it and the best part is it is completely free to play. You don't have to pay a dime for any content whatsoever. The only thing that costs money is to customize your experience while playing, including Cosmetics, HUDs, Loading Screens, etc.

The satisfaction is incredible, playing every game to game having a great time is just ... amazing. Always constantly active and never getting bored.   Most of the negative reviews are written just because people get angry/rage (including myself) since it's such a competitive game, I know its 'only just a game' but, this game is revolved around teamwork and if your team dont co-operate you will probably lose.  But lets anaylse why I have changed from a positive to a negative review. *EDIT* Changed back into positive.  The game has a few downsides such as public matchmaking and the MMR system, In public games where you get matched up with people with 200 games played whereas you may have 1000 games played (which is a very big gap) literally is detrimental to your game, most likely you will lose because the player is not as skilled as you are.   A big ♥♥♥♥ing mistake that I feel is ruining my DotA experience is my MMR - a ranking system which determines where you are placed based on skill. Low MMR is about 3k below, medium is about 3k - 5k, high is 5k+ #ProLyfeRuffLyfe. Based on my friends decision they told me as a player is decent at the game and should be able to hit 4k, when i was around my 400th win I thought I was pro and decided to calibrate - I was a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I calibrated to around 2.4k which is an absolute ♥♥♥♥ MMR and right now I'm way better. 'So why can't you just carry games because how skilled you are?' Well here is the problem. I know people have bad games and you can just accept it and try to help them and move on. BUT HERE IS THE ♥♥♥♥ING PROBLEM. I decided to play some ranked games, first 40~ or so games was a sucess I carried most games - team was okay, listened and communicated. I got to around 3.2k not bad for a month play. I come back after summer refreshed and decided to play before the International update. MY ♥♥♥♥ING GOD - THIS GAME THREW ITSELF IN THE TRASH. ♥♥♥♥ing every single game - mid leshrac, mid storm, mid mid mid mid. These heroes were unbalanced as ♥♥♥♥ and it took them about 3 months to update this game, next thing you know REBORN *will get into that later* then games just were ruined. I was on an 18~ loss streak back to like 2.8k and was stuck in this *Trench* forever, these few updates have ruined the game. I'm still stuck in 2.8k and trying to make a smurf to get to 4k. During my 18~ loss most of my games were me going positive and the rest of my team going negative not because they were unskilled but because of the meta/heroes that were being picked. I know you can counter pick - but no hero can counter 1vs5 - this resulted in teams feeding, quicker games, and overall a ganking ganking flamming kind of game with no chance of comeback.   Recent changes such as Reborn client as well as custom games have dropped quite a few players, right now meta is unbareable, rushed games, ganks only, nerfed creep gold, no item changes - the game isn't in a great state right now - thus why this review has been updated. It's been almost a full year since i've written this review and many updates have been made but, honestly, this game is going downhill, I've actually switched to LOL and find that there are always updates (usually 2 weeks) and they actually update what needs to be nerfed and what needs to be buffed. Constantly, items and heroes are always being changed, special events being added regularly *Giff Diretide* - well no more, some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t custom game called Haunted Colleseum. I used to love DotA but right now not so much, when valve as a whole decide to update their games regularly I may comeback but right now with a recent change to Cs:GO adding a broken revolver shows how much Valve as a whole are slacking right now so who knows when these changes will start to happen.  *MASSIVE EDIT* Well then, balance of power update released. I am amazed at what valve has done. However MMR thing still bothers me but now the game for once actually feels *balanced*. I am throughly enjoying the new heroes games feel winnable again, pulled a sick comeback from 0-23 to 42-35 the other day, games feel like they are lasting the approprate time, gold gain feels good. (Midas feels broken) The new Arc Warden is pretty legit if i might say - great creative choices. Right now Valve has outdown themselves just in time for the christmas holidays. This game is actually becomming a great game that I'll always love forever. Thanks, IceFrog - for everything. DotA>LOL  On the other hand some positives.  This game has a very steep learning curve by nature and may take a while to get used to but once you learn all the mechanics the game is quite easy. Only way to improve after that is just improving individual ability and learning the game mechanics. You feel a sense of acomplishement when you win a game, all that hardwork and skill pays off. THAT FEEL IS SOMETHING YOU NEVER FEEL - IT JUST FEELS SO GOOD WHEN YOU CARRY A GAME 21-3 WITH LINA MID *KreyGasm*  But anyway,Dota is a really enjoyable game and I recommend it to people with time and the compassion to play as well as to take massive amounts of time into a game. DotA will always be an enjoyable game and will always be the game that I will love and forever play - when its updated.  I've also met a friend in Dota that I eventually met in real life and he is a good friend. I alway play with him and we have tons of fun. Not only is it a fun game but you can meet new people playing the game you love and enjoy.  Good luck have fun, go and rekt noobs :d2invoker:

Dota 2 is a skill-based Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA). I could describe Dota 2 as a fast-learning curve not easy to master, I mean that everyone could start playing this game, but a little of them can reach high-level. Valve tries to satisfy the whole community adding a matchmaking that tracks your statistic and helps to find the right match for you, but sometimes match could be frustrating thanks to community; the major issues with Dota 2 is the not region-locked matchmaking, this could make teams that, due to language misunderstanding, won't cooperate. In my opinion loking the regions isn't the better way to fix this issues beacuse players should have the possibility to match worldwide to improve their skill, rather I prefer a team region-locked or, better, language-locked. Gameplay speaking is way better than other MOBAs, less user-friendly and more competitive; last-hitting mechanics allow team to focus on single hero that will be useful in late game, otherwise denies mechanics allow to counter enemy heros' growing. The hero pool is unlocked by default, so you can choose the right hero to counter enemy team. Valve is trying to set a new standard for e-sport investing a lot of money on it, we have just to support it by playing the game and following the growing e-sport scene, this will grant hours of fun. I almost forgive... it's FREE.

A great game with a very friendly and tolerant community, its also a very educational and cultural experience. Since I've been playing dota I've learned to speak russian and spanish, Who needs rosetta stone when you have dota right? The russians are so friendly and have a neat little nickname for americans called 'Suukah', I think it means comrade or friend. And the peruvians are so helpful, for instance I was mid as pudge and at the start of the match a peruvian dazzle came mid with me and stayed with for about 11 minutes, He helped me out by taking the last hits and first blood. He said 'movimiento ♥♥♥♥', I think it means 'I got your back', What a nice guy. Dota is great and all but there are a few problems with some heros, like bloodseeker, Phantom Assassin, Faceless void, And huskar. They need to be buffed, I find them extrememly underwhelmed. Bloodseekers ult cd is just too long and needs to be lowered to ten seconds, Phantom assassin needs a higher crit ratio, faceless needs more evasion and movement speed, and huskar's flaming spear should cost no hp. Oh and there's one other hero needs to be nerfed hard, Bat rider is just too overpowered and unbalanced. I think he has too much hp, and the base should be lowered to 320, also lower his base movement speed to 200. Aside from those few problems dota 2 is the best FPS I have ever played in my life. From its lowly origins as a custom game in Warcraft 3, Dota has risen to the most populated of all Steam titles. It is a brutally competitive MOBA from which most other MOBAs have drawn their inspiration. If you enjoy games like League of Legends, Heroes of Newerth, or Smite, but wish that there was more depth to the competition, this is the game for you. Past the steep learning curve awaits a matchmaking system that ensures you'll be pitted against opponents of your calibur, rising in difficulty as you rise in skill. With a pool of over 100 playable heroes available from the very start of the game, no two games will be alike. This game requires patience, dedication to improvement, and a thick hide, but for those who posess these, the payoff is enormous.

The few hundred hours i've spent with this game has been spent in public lobbies and some bot matches. It's great. Gameplay is Solid, There's enough diversity in playstyles to make any tactitian weep with joy. Though the community might not always be 'Top Notch', there are a lot of people out there who are really looking forward to a good time, wether you are new to the game or not. Sure there are bugs. Sure there are some unbalanced heroes and items. Sure there's the occaisonal right ♥♥♥♥, but if you are going to play a game that has near constant connection to the untamed internet and its hordes of demonic flamers and trolls, your gonna have to walk over that bridge, wether the troll likes it or not. The artstyle is appealing to the eye and the combat is vibrant with epic style animations and effects. Don't get me wrong, the Combat FEELS Good, but it LOOKS even better. There is no Pay-To-Win, which is what makes this a real 1# Place titel for me. The HUD Is Grounded in what works and has none of what doesnt. There's even a little tutorial to explain the base game mechanics (with the exeption of runes and items). Overall, the game left me impressed and a few few cents short after those beautiful visual clothing sets i bought (just a few, I Swear) What i'm trying to say is that youre experience with this game is what you make of it. Wether its going to be playing for the team, a lone wolf, a team tank or something in the middle, its up to you wether your'e going to enjoy it, or decide it's not for you and so for me so far, Its Been One Helluve Ride....  Edit: Servers Dont Work That Well Right Now. Lets Hope Valve Fixes That.  Also : Reborn.

-Pros/Cons down below-  Ah Dota, it's sure a great game with a not-so-great community, which is kinda sad.  However that doesn't stop the game from being fun, unless you're unlucky and end up with a couple of raging russians telling you to... ...well if I knew russian I probably would've known. So, how is this game good enough for people to play it even though the community is crap? Because it's simply amazing and well balanced. There might be a few heroes that could use some tweaking, but I wouldn't call them overpowered. The graphics are pretty nice and the lightning is really good honestly. Also, something good is that I've never met a hacker (as far as I know), even though at the time of writing I've played about 325 hours. This game does contain IAPs (obiviously), however, none of them give you any in-game bonus, all are cosmetics for your hero or HUD etc.   So, should you download Dota 2? I'd say yes, it's a great game with a few minor bugs but nothing that should affect gameplay or bother you.  If you decide to download it I strongly recommend you to play the tutorial.  It is kinda strange and isn't on the normal Dota map but it teaches you the basics pretty good.  This has been fixed with reborn, it now offers 'guided bot matches' which are much better.  Pros: + Nice graphics + Great settings menu + Good amount of graphics settings + Balanced heros  + Insanely fun with nice teammates/friends + Free to play but not pay to win (all items are purely cosmetic) + There are some really nice announcers if you're tired of the default one (they're paid though) + There are also music packs if you're tired of the default music (also paid) + Many items can be purchased cheaper on the Steam community market + SOURCE 2! + Custom gamemodes + Matchmaking for custom gamemodes is really fast + Fast tab-ing out/in (even with fullscreen)  Cons: - Community is, like with almost all competetive free games, ♥♥♥♥ - Russians who only speak russian - Russians who speak english yet they speak russian - Matchmaking can take a while  - You really notice how old the Source 1 engine is (it's soon getting replaced with Source 2 though) - Seems to have problems with some ATI/AMD graphics cards (minor problems though, nothing gamebreaking, seems to have been fixed with Source 2 too)

Let me start by saying this, Dota 2 is my favourite game of all time, but I feel that most of the time the negatives outweigh the positives.  The negatives:  1. The community is cancerous. Everyone spams 'ez' or 'изи' ('ez' in Russian) at the end of every single match, making the losers feel terrible and spreading that attitude of negativity to others. People also spam 'ez mid' or 'noob' for no reason other than making others feel bad.  2. The ranked system is broken. I don't care what some 6k egotist on reddit says about 'git gud to raise your mmr'. That is simply fallacious. Raising your mmr is just a case of playing a snowballing mid and hoping for the best, but the people on your team will almost never let you go mid and argue about it. You can't help if you get matched with people that intentionally feed or go afk. No matter how well you do in the game, if you lose, your mmr decreases. This also works the other way around. If you feed deliberately but your team wins, you gain mmr. Seems fair. The only way it seems to raise your mmr consistently is to abuse the cancer (overpowered) heroes of the patch (looking at you, Slark), in which case, it is not by skill that you are raising your mmr, but by abusing a broken hero. Again, a broken system. Don't hope to have fun in ranked.  3. 90% of the people I get matched with can't speak English, despite my language preference being set to English.  4. Even though the game has over 110 heroes, you see the same ones over and over again (PA, LC, Drow, Slark, Pudge etc) meaning you have to play the same heroes over and over to counter them.  5. Getting reported for no/stupid reasons. I got reported by 3 people because I said I was playing Windranger as a support, because they believed that she was best as a carry (we won that game aswell).  The positives:  1. The game is fun with friends. Playing in a 5 stack also eliminates the possibility of deliberate feeders and AFK'ers.  2. Cosmetic items keep the heroes fresh and add something for people that enjoy collecting things.  3. Sometimes you will get a good team and have a really fun game.  4. The game looks very nice visually.  5. The game is insanely addictive.  The game itself is very good, but it just gets ruined by the players.  Nominating for the 'Just 5 More Minutes' award as it is the most addictive game that I have ever played.

Dota 2 has a lot to offer, both good and bad. It's really easy to pick up the concept of the game and what your 'supposed' to do. The only problem is every game is different, in the far too many games I've played I don't think I've ever had the same game before. When your teammates ask you 'What were you thinking when you did that?' Generally with some curses thrown in, normally you don't have a good reply, they can all see with hindsight, you couldn'tve have known that Pudge had an Invis rune. In all honesty Dota is really fun to play with friends, whether you're just messing around or playing seriously, if your lucky maybe 1/50 games if you make the effort you can pick up some new friends to play with.   Pros -Easy to pick up/simple -Very interesting in that every game is different -No hero is truly 'OP' at least for long, there are always counters. -Meet many interesting people -Some people truly try to help  Cons -Toxic community (for the most part) -Random people not on your language preference speaking stuff you don't understand -Learning to play all 90 or so heroes instead of 2 takes a little while -People saying you suck if you don't have a set -Watching people do exactly the opposite of what you recommended and dieing -Watching people do exactly what you asked and dieing

Dota 2  Dota 2 is a F2P MOBA game made by Valve and was in beta for a long time until it became free to the public in 2013. Dota 2 requires alot of skill and it isn't a game where ou jump right in to the game like TF2. Valve intended that players should find their favourite hero and learn tacticts with that hero however most players don't get that and hate on it for childish or just ride the hate wagon. Let's get to the game now... You start in the same map each time (And I would appreciate some more maps). Each side looks similar and there are 3 main roads to each team's spawn but they are protected by minions, towers and players, the objective is to destroy the towers and get to the enemy base and destroy this core thingamajic. You start leveling up your character and your abilities/hero gets stronger and it's key to the game. You will really need to play as a team rather than a lone wolf and will require you to speak with your teammates and not expect them to know your stun and attack plan.   I will give this game a 4.7/5. I think it's a good game but it might need some new maps.

Trial by fire. Straight up. You're going to learn exceptions to the rule by being killed by them, and it's going to happen a lot. Dota is the most brutal learning curve of any game I've ever played. Sometimes in a well-done fashion, sometimes not. There are few games where I can honestly say that at 300 hours you have barely any true idea what you're doing.   Amazingly complex game! Tons of fun, especially with friends.   Not a casually oriented game at all, but enormously entertaining to play and watch.   No grind, no microtransactions that affect gameplay in any way. No outside advantages, no premade skills. Everything happens in game and you need to be quick on your feet.  Try it out! Just be warned that properly trying it out will take hundreds of hours.   Relax, you're doing fine.

Possitives:  Have you played any other MOBA before playing Dota2? Well allow me to introduce you to the first son of the MOBA genre's father father, the one that started it all, Aeon of Strife. Dota 2 is a well balanced and evenly paced MOBA which offers a lot of variety when it comes to Heroes to play and items to make your hero stronger. The game has quite a steep learning curve, but once you feel like you've gone over that curve then the game becomes so enjoyable especially with friends. The game has now been released and is F2P, so what do you have to lose?  Negatives:   The community is quite hostile to anyone who doesn't play very well, sadly. A lot of Russian players don't even want to play with other Russians and instead choose the 'English' language preference and end up screwing over the people who actually do speak English and causes communication issues. The toxic behavior some people in this game can be unreal, and they will sometimes do whatever it takes to make your game horrible. Yeah, you can mute them and try to ignore them but surely they would be inclind to just help the enemy team by feeding themselves to them just because you done one thing wrong that they didn't like. But that's why you should try to play with as many friends as possible, in order to minimise this issue.

Don't get me wrong, this isn't a bad game. Not by any stretch. It's a candidate for my favourite game of all time, in fact. I have a second account devoted to it, where my playtime is similar, and I haven't gotten anywhere close to 2000+ hours in any other video game.  But I can't recommend it to a new player, for a single very significant reason.   The community is the single most toxic community I have ever been a part of. It is extremely, extremely rare for a match to be completely free of players abusing you for bad decisions and shouting at you over a microphone in a language you can't even understand. For me, it's become comical, but for a new player, unless they have friends that are willing to teach them the basics and help them learn the mechanics of the game, they are going to struggle. There are tutorials, but these are beyond limited, and with a pool of 113 Heroes each with individual and unique abilities, the learning curve is exceptionally steep. In order to be a ''good'' player, every detail of every single skill and item in the game will need to be learned (that is, its function, cooldown, damage, added effects, gold cost, mana cost, and more.) This takes several hours to achieve. The best way of learning all these intricate details would usually be to just play the game, but the aforementioned toxic community makes this impossible unless you have a number of friends willing to play alongside you while you learn the basics.  Now, let's assume you have a group of four friends, or you are lucky enough to be matched with reasonable and understanding players. Let's assume that you've put the time into learning the mechanics of the game.   You're going to have a great time. The game is, with a few glaring exceptions,    *cough* Monkey King *cough*    well balanced and fair at all times, putting the outcome of each and every game at least largely down to the player's skill and their ability to communicate with their team. It is completely and utterly free to play, there are no extra heroes or stat bonuses that can be bought, although there are cosmetic item sets and other miscellaneous items such as different soundtracks and HUDs that can be bought with real money, but these are entirely optional. This means that every player has access to the same number of heroes, and on top of that Heroes are not cycled like in other MOBAs- all 113 heroes are available all the time. The sheer amount of playtime that this game offers is mindblowing, especially taking the fact that it is free into consideration. I can't think of any other game, free or otherwise, that could remain so fresh and enjoyable for so long. There are so many different playstyles and so many different incredible hero combinations that can be utilised, the cliché that 'no two games are the same' definitely applies here.  On top of all this, it's excellently optimised- most systems will be able to run it at a semi-decent framerate.  The terrible community and the natural learning curve that comes with the MOBA genre really are a shame, because this game really is a true achievement of video gaming. Its a 10/10 game without a doubt but it's near impossible to get into, and it is that very factor that means, in the vast majority of cases, this game cannot be recommended.

DotA 2 is a multiplayer online game in develop by Valve Corporation and the stand alone version of Defense of the Ancient mod on Warcraft 3: Reign of Chaos and Warcraft 3: The Frozen Throne . DotA 2 officially announced on October 13, 2010, at the time of people who can play DotA 2 is limited, only certain people are getting special rights of the Developer and Distributor. DotA 2 was not like other online games that bermode Click and Play, DotA 2 requires another program to be patchernya, namely Steam.  The purpose of DotA 2 is destroying ancient opponents protected by other players. Here, players will choose one of 98 heroes that exist. Each hero has different abilities and strengths, this is what makes DotA 2 stressful. As a real-time strategy game, players are required to be able to decide the action as soon as possible if you do not want to die or lose.    Gameplay   Gameplay of DotA 2 is a combination of real-time strategy with top-down perspective, and also system-level and system equipment adapted from role-playing game . The game is divided into two teams, the Radiant and the Dire. Each team has a hero, respectively, with their respective strengths, but the player can determine the game mode to be played so that the players can use the Radiant team The hero of The Dire team, and vice versa.  Players are required to quickly determine the action to be performed when pressed, otherwise the player will die and will provide benefits to the hero who killed him. The more kills, the player is getting rich, and vice versa, the more killed, players will lack the gold so it can not upgrade the item itself.  DotA 2 is a team game, not a solo game, because if you want to solo do not play DotA, go play chess. Therefore, it's useless if only one hero who has a hero equip decent but the other does not, the team will definitely lose. This game teaches us that we can not stand alone without the help of others, especially the help from our friends.    Players Type Server Dota 2 In Southeast Asia      People are always calling other people as Pinoy  Pinoy is slang for the Philippines. For unknown reasons why, if you have people like this in the game so if something goes wrong then you will be called Pinoy by this person. No matter where you come from countries, such as Indonesia, Malaysia or Singapore you will still be called Pinoy. Such people will assume Pinoy is a person who can not play the game without seeing meraka national origin.     People who are considered by the other players as Pinoy  It does not matter if you're Filipino or not, if you make a mistake then you will automatically be Pinoy. This may not be too offended if the person who made a mistake is the Philippines. Although the Philippines has a bad reputation in Dota 2, but not all Filipinos will admit it. Filipino nationalists are people who, if they were heckled by pinoy call then they will become more aggressive. So I think you should focus on their mistakes rather than calling him Pinoy.     People who do Crowing Bottle selfishly until the end of the game  Bottle crowing is a technique used to increase the survivability, especially in the middle lane and it was fine. That is not cool is to do it at the extreme stage. Do you have to be selfish bottle crowing from the beginning to the end of the game? Why? Although the role of support you are, you realize that I also need a courier? For example, for the wards? Do you realize that there are 4 other people who also need their items? If you make the team overwhelmed just because you need a bottle crowing to survive until the end of the game then I think you should review again the way you play this game.     People from Europe or North America who complain about lag  No such thing as dedicated servers. I know it. But sooner or later you will meet the person who decided to play the game on the server that is located in another part of the earth. It is not wrong because the rules do not prohibit it. I even tried to queuing at the European servers to play with friends there. But if you experience lag during play because choosing a server far away there then stop complaining or worse pause hoping lagnya lost.     People who pretend to be someone Singapore or Malaysia  With the purpose of pretending to be a person of Singapore or Malaysia, people like this will continue to add 'le' or 'la' every time he says something. And I mean absolutely everything ('Top la! B la! Nice la! GGWP la!'). How do I know that there are people who pretend to be like this? Because I know some of them. Why do they do it? I do not know for sure. If they want to retrace the footsteps of Daryl 'iceiceice' Cai Yee Koh or 'Mushi' then they need to be more than just wearing this access. This may be because the Pinoy has a way of 'unique' in the play and 'act' in pubs. It all comes back to you to consider whether the Pinoy is a bad player or not. My FAVOURITE game on Steam. This game requires skill and practice. But once the practice and skill comes, it really pays off and you will soon find yourself right into the game. Dota 2 provides fun gameplay for both those who just want a good time and for those who want to play competitive. I believe that this game has been very well prepared and is continuing to grow at a steady pace. New aspects of the game are regularly made to keep the game going. Some of these include new gamemodes (such as Diretide and Wraith Night) and new heroes (such as the three spirits and Legion Commander). The game provides a friendly welcome to the new players by giving a tutorial and offering practice without any negative criticism from raging players. As well as that, coaches have been introduced to help you as you game so don't be afraid to try it out! Overall I really recommend this game whether you are playing by yourself or with friends.  Rating: 9/10 Notes: Overall very good. The 1 point off is just the community and the matchmaking ranking. By this i mean that usually i'm put with like people that are very new (not that i'm against them, it's just that at my level i expect people with higher skill levels) sometimes mess up really badly and cost me the game. Additionally, they sometimes blame for no apparent reason. A solution to this is the new ranked matchmaking but how are you going to be put in the right skill bracket if you are constantly pulled down? A note the new players, try to practice with bots before going into pubs :)

Terrible game for new players. The learning curve is expectedly high, yet beside training bot games where you learn nothing, or at least nothing that compares to the real gaming situation, there is noway for new players to have decent first steps into this game.  As a total unexperienced and new player I am matched with players that have hundreds or even thousands of games. This is the worst kind of matchmaking I have experienced in a mp game yet. I really tried to enjoy it and not get too frustrated but it's just terrible. Especially when you are no match for your enemies and you are obviously holding your team back. This isn't fun for anyone in this scenario.  The game itself is great, but playing against bots for hours hasn't helped a bit, could be that even gave a wrong feeling about the real game. Truly disappointed, because I am used to superb and absolutely fine quality of Valve. I suppose the game has it's core of players and targetting new players isn't a priority.  So, if you do not have a friend that can take you by the hand and guide you through anything, you gonna have a bad time.

then imply that they are filled only by playing more games, in this game you do not feel good if you lose, and even if you win, if you lose you do not feel good because you were not able to overcome the challenge to fight as roosters against a person, you feel as deprived from that person and you lose everything that the game says 'you should' defend as important to not know what purpose, the simple fact of losing to someone too many times can create a sense of depression as if to say that we are not able to be on par with someone and to succumb to their will, and that is where it comes hatred towards teammate, you do not agree to not being up to the game and start to blame the teammates. every time after training you will prove that you have become better and the game puts you against opponents that you are not yet up to beat and the cycle begins again.the game makers have implemented the system of ranking so as to push on this mechanism even more since the number you see written on the screen at the time indicates how much you're worth inside of their system, more you practice and the more they reward you with a number on the screen , but the fact that you play only goes as they please because keeps alive the game and they can make money over there.not even win games is rewarding because what you must do is suppress the enemy against his will and make him feel bad as you never wanted to feel when you lost the matches. they call it 'free to play' because this mechanism is activated immediately, they know that probably many of the people who try the game will pay with their dedication, time and hidden deep sadness and justifying it as a passion for the game. the fact that they sell cosmetics items in the store is just another way to take advantage of weak minds not to mention the money that goes around the 'pro gaming', there are tournaments with millions of dollars as a reward, and you compete on a game that is completely unbalanced, with many bugs and even less content of the first version exists for many years.  in the end this is horrifying, I think I analyzed it all exhaustively.

Dota 2 is hard, but there's a huge reward for those who commit. On the surface, the game is a like-for-like reproduction of the genre-creating (and still updated) Defense of the Ancients modification for Warcraft III, now transferred into Valve's Source engine. The game's punishing design is sometimes enough to drive you up the wall, but it's worth sticking the hours in: success in Dota 2 is about learning to effectively juggle both the broad strokes and finer details.  If you're not aware of the basics of the burgeoning MOBA genre, two teams of five players spawn on corners of a map. Each team needs to work together with the goal of ultimately destroying a central structure--in Dota 2's case, the Ancient--in the opposing team's base. With most games lasting around the 40-minute mark, and occasionally edging past an hour, watching the enemy fortress dramatically crumble and sink to the ground feels like an exhilarating payoff.

Dota 2 is a very extensive and deep game but this depth and complexity in my opinion means a great ceiling of fun.  I really enjoy this game. You can play as an oblivious person with your oblivious friends and derp around the game and have lots of fun trying to bash each others heads in while trying to break that coveted ancient, but be warned; if you enjoy this game you might want to try playing online.  Playing online is a different experience ENTIRELY. Team work becomes so much much oh ever so much much so muchly much much more crucial than before (Dr.Suess reference XD) If you are still playing with your group of friends though at this point that should help a lot. But like many people (myself included) you will be in games where you are alone amongst 4 strangers All of whom have their own agenda seemingly (it is not ALWAYS like this.) you will try your best to help your team win but it will inevitably end in a couple of your teammates being head-strong idiots who fed the other team (let the other team kill them to many times) then the fed team is big bad and bulky, then you lose.  There are games where you and your team will work together and you will DESTROY!!! that will not always be the case so enjoy it when it happens and get over it when it doesn't.  If you plan on being great at this game be prepared to spend hours researching what the items do; all of the recipes, heroe's skills (especially ultimates), and watch games of people who are good (I reccomend Purge he's on YouTube.)  If all this seems overwhelming it's because this game can be CRAZY overwhelming however it has potential to be CRAZY fun!   The bottom line is what you put into this game is what you will get out of it; at the time of this review i have 270+ hours in-game and I still feel relatively noobish; I have been having fun this whole time however.  So if you don't feel like putting away crazy amounts of time into a game then i suggest you get 1-9 friends who also don't know how DOTA works to get this game and just play private games together and have a BLAST because it is quite a lot of fun.   A little about me. I played DOTA 1 the Warcraft III mod as a late-comer with 1 other friend game after game and we derped PLENTY But through those games I learned about the stats and recipes of about 90% of the items in the game, giving me a pretty sizable advantage.  I could have made this review about ten times longer but then it would have been a guide... (it already kind of is)  10/10 by the way this game is great!

As you begin to play this game,you're given a tutorial on how the gameplay works.   As you finish completing the tutorial you would have options to either play with bots or with online players.   There is a wide variety of modes to choose from.   All of the heroes are unlocked from the start so you don't have to unlock them one by one like any other MOBA game.  Each heroes have their own specific roles so choose wisely and don't anyhow go whatever you feel like.   There is no in-game money in this game and you earned different rewards as you play many matches.   There is a lore for you to read for each character if you're interested.   However these game have a steep leaning curve and those who are new to MOBA genre will struggle how the gameplay system work.   It require a lot of tactics & teamwork in order to win a match........that is if your partner will listen to you cause a lot of player i found will quickly rage at you if you make a minor issue while some other just rage quit because they felt like they cannot make a comeback.   A lot of heroes are memorable mainly because sometimes you would see those heroes interact with one another depending if they are rival or allied.

I highly recommend this game and there's no reason not to try it out, it's free!

The horn bellowed throughout the battlefield, signaling yet another war for these 10 brave warriors to fight. The green and red foot soldiers and magi of the Radiant and Dire sharpened their swords and practiced their spells, all whilst praying to their ancient and reminiscing memories of their families one last time; as they knew that once they set out of the barracks and into war, they may never be able to see them again. These soldiers had to let go of all emotion now, as emotion on the battlefield is a sign of weakness; one the enemy could very well take advantage of.  But these soldiers knew they were nothing; they would die to the sword of the enemy, and no one would remember them. There are thousands and thousands of them, they were not allowed to be phased by the death of their comrade. They knew that they were but meat shields to be used by the real warriors, the heroes, in their quest to destroy the enemy ancient. One of these brave and skilled heroes was Kanye. Kanye of the West. Kanye has witnessed many battles on this battlefield. He fights 5-6 wars a day, sleeps by dawn, wakes by the morning, and is ready to fight 5-6 more. These wars were but play time for him, he would fight enemy heroes, kill or be killed by them, and just laugh at whatever the result. There was no doubt in his comrades' mind that he was skilled, but there is a slight problem with Kanye, one that stops him from receiving all awards and accolades that he very well deserves.  Kanye wasn't allowed to receive any awards for wars that he participates in as he would suddenly disappear from them, for apparently no reason. It was obvious Kanye didn't want to leave any of the wars he participates in; he does well, never complains, never bad mouths his enemies, and all in all, has fun. But even through all these, all these disappearances negatively affect his record, as he is penalized and banned from all awards and accolades for a given amount of battles. Therefore, Kanye has to push and force himself through wars that he isn't even given credit for to get rid of his penalty, before he can receive awards again. ********************************************************************************************** 'Kanye, be careful. I see no enemy in sight, they might be headed your way.' Kanye heard, as he slashed at enemy soldiers from atop his steed. 'Copy, no problem.'  This was Kanye's last battle before he would be recognized for his efforts one again. Once he finishes this fight, every succeeding war that he fights after will finally be recognizes by his superiors, and the motivation he once had of fighting will finally be rekindled. Kanye pulled his sword out of the last foot soldier in the enemy battalion, and wiped the blood off with his hand.  Out of the corner of his eye, he caught a short glimpse of movement in the trees. He pulled the reins of his horse towards the trees, and his horse promptly followed. 'I think I got one over here where I am, but I'm not sure who it is quite yet.' Kanye said. 'Alright, we're on our way there. Be careful.' 'I'm closing in on where I saw the movement.' As his horse clopped towards the trees, a horrid stench began to creep unto his nostrils. 'Damn, it stinks.' He whispered. 'Crap! I think I know wh-' Kanye's sentence was cut short, as he suddenly saw a bloodied chain hook speed towards him. 'Come to Pudgey!' The hook dug deep into his back, as he was pulled towards where it was thrown. The stench grew stronger the farther he was pulled, and as he turned his head around, he saw what atrocious being was the cause of this. Pudge. ''Ello, mate. How 'ya doin' today?' Pudge yelled as he pulled Kanye and his dark horse towards him. 'Sorry to spoil your little party over there, but I decided that I wanted to join in.' Kanye reached for his sword and slashed at the chain of the hook. The chain easily snapped and fell to the ground. 'Oh, I'm sorry Pudge. Did I break your little hook toy? You'd think a butcher would get a stronger chain for his hook than that, yeah?' Kanye laughed as he pulled the hook out of his back. 'Oh that thing, mate? I have a lot more where that came from, don't worry.' 'Enough talk. Your breath is killing me more than your fighting. Let's dance.'  Kanye raised his reins, lifting his horse up. 'Aphotic Shield!' A dark magic surrounded Kanye, forming an impenetrable shield. He charged, sword at the ready, at the huge hunk of talking meat in front of him. 'I'm not scared of you, mate. Get over 'ere.' *Poof* Kanye disappeared. 'What?' Pudge said confused as he looked around him, searching for signs of the lord of Avernus and his horse. 'He seems to have disappeared, mates.' Pudge told his teammates. 'Who?' 'Kanye.' 'Oh, Kanye. He always disappears, don't worry. He's gone, move on now.' 'Alrighty then.' ********************************************************************************************** The slight drizzle has become a full blown heavy rain, banging on the metal surface of our roof like cats and dogs falling from the sky. And there I was, staring at my monitor. *Auto disconnect in (25.0) seconds* My heart sank and my blood boiled. I have played in the low priority matchmaking for almost a whole month now, all because of this crappy internet.  *Auto disconnect in (10.0) seconds* I alt-tabbed, opened google chrome, typed in  google.com  in the address bar, and alas, the page wouldn't open. There was no internet. I disconnected from the game, and I had 5 minutes to reconnect. I immediately turned off my router, hoping that a hard reset would fix the problem. I went outside, ate dinner as fast as I could, went back in my room, and turned the router on. My heart pumped stronger than Derrick Rose would as he lays a shot into the basket. The final light lit up, signalling that the router was fully on. My laptop connected to the internet, I opened up Dota 2, and reconnected to the game. 'Did I abandon already?' I typed into the chat. It took a while for someone to reply. I was hoping they were typing something along the lines of: 'No, we paused it just for you!' This thought brought me a slight glimmer of hope that maybe, just maybe, I did not have to play Dota 2 in the low priority bracket for another 5 games, and that I cou- 'Yes.' replied another player. Well, that sucks.  I disconnected from the game, my heart heavy from sadness as I slowly walked towards the kitchen, and asked my mom to cook me 2 more eggs for me to eat.  I cri. ********************************************************************************************** TL;DR My internet sucks and never works, and i'm mad. 11/10 would abandon again

Dota came from a custom game in warcraft 3 and has evolved into a lifestyle. As one of the biggest games in E-sports in the world the 5 on 5 team battles are never the same. Fun to play and fun to watch this game has literally thousands of hours of value. Valve supplies seasonal activities and special game modes as well as relatively consistant updates containing purchaseable cosmetic items add value to this already quality game. Ice Frog, the games original designer in warcraft 3, still balances, rebalances and rebuilds heroes, items, the map, and even the games physics making the game ever evolving and never stale. In addition once a year Valve holds the Dota 2 International tournement which is arguably the biggest event in e-sports averaging now over $10 million prize pools, bringing together the best players and teams in the world for an event comparable to any major sporting championship. On route to be the biggest E-sport in the world and validating E-sports as a whole, the last international being tracked/covered by ESPN, Dota 2 might be considered the most influential game in E-sports. Having said all that, Do I recommend this game? Yes, for both casual and serious gamers, Dota4Life.

I have been playing Dota for the past 5 years and what I have learned from each grueling game is that, this game is not for you if you can't handle:  1. New players on team.  2. Crying baby you have to babysit.  3. Angry all knowing abuser.  4. Russians …  5. Open karaoke in foreign language.  6 .Being forced to play same role over and over in hope that you might win (& still lose).  7. Losing to a PA/Bashing heroes (Bara/Troll/Void(+backtrack))  8. Being blamed by the whole team for being the solo support and getting focused by the enemy team.  9. and so on …   If you can handle at least 4 of the above mentioned points, you should definitely try to play dota, Yes it has a steep learning curve as many people have rightly pointed out, but once in a while you do get those games which just makes you wanna come back for me. And to continue playing in dota you need to invest more time like one does for studies to be able to maintain your standing in the MMR or general pubs or you can say that you play for the FUN, ( but we all know, we play for the Win :P ).  Yes the dota community is bit harsh and you will need lot of patience to get through to people and once in a while you will rage at others as well but that is just part and parcel of this game. But once you get into it and start enjoying it, it is one of the best game available in market which can give you the best feeling of accomplishment and satisfaction when you win a game after a long and hard battle which will just keep you coming back for more and more.

Negatives First off, i'd like to say i love this game but it should never be played by any human with a rational mindor semblence of sanity at all.  The community is so garbage that it will kill this game for you.   No lie, no joke, you will grow to be the most cynical hateful person because everyone 90% of the time in the game forces you to be the only competent one.   The game itself also has quite a few flaws, for instance the pathfinding is absolutely horrendous and in terms of balancing there isn't much.   You may look at the roster and want to pick a cool looking hero, but you shouldn't because ♥♥♥♥ you. Most heroes are either irrelevant to drafters who know what they're doing or are jokes. Each patch has a rotation of heroes that are strongest that will be overplayed in every skill bracket untill they get nerfed to the point of irrelevance. Then there are some heroes that are just absolutely broken and shouldn't be in the game to begin with because no matter how many times they are nerfed or their counters get buffed they manage to find a way in.   Also, the game has an extreme learning curve but no utillities in present to help you learn it. The tutorial shows you the most basic information the could've figured out by just playing the game however it does look nice. The bots aren't programmed particularily well, but they may show you some things that the tutorial did not care to mention.   The most irratating part of the game is that there is no region lock, so in a communcation teambased game (and i've had this happen before) you may get up to 5 different langauges on the same team.   Most of the time its dysfunctional numbing mess that makes you wonder if you have too much free time like me.  Positives  If you have the patience, and the iron will to grind for competent teammates and try to have a positive attitude the game is actually quite fun. It offers a good challenge, and despite win or loose some games really are 'gg' (good game). When both teams have 'meta' heroes that can fight each other equally it becomes a real good time. Working as a team to accomplish a goal, and playing well really has a fulfilling feel to it and if you like that, you may want to try this game.  While the game is scattered interms of balance, each hero can be fun in its own way, and each certainly different to it. Some heroes act fairly simillar, but even then they each have their own feel that makes each worth trying out atleast once.   Individual playstyle in certain heroes is also highlighted by this uniqueness and your personality and how you play often shines through by what you play the most.   For instance i'm a prick so i play heroes that display this through underhanded and dirty tatics. In contrast one of friends who plays mostly nice characters that do simple things is a pretty nice guy.   All in all this is like the cheap hooker of mobas, she may look nasty and she probably got some diseases but shes experienced in the job and no matter how many STD's she contracts she'll be always for a good time every once in a while.

Am I missing something?  I've played about 4-5 hours on a friends account and another 2 on one I created and I'm still waiting for the big reveal. I will say this particular type of strategy game has never really been my favorite so I may be a bit biased. In execution this game just feels tedious and repetitive. You painstakingly build up your character and slowly attempt to take over bits of territory inch by inch. The thing is by the time you are about to win or lose the match i've been ready for it to end for weeks. There is depth here but for myself the mechanics are either too simple (wait for the perfect moment to kill something to get a gold bonus) and tedious (kill your own minion to prevent your opponent from getting a gold bonus) for me to want to stick with the game for any longer.  I appreciate what they got right (relatively simple game design with loads of features) in this game but the bottom line is that I just do not enjoy playing it and cannot see where the crazy high ratings are coming from.  I would technically give this game a 5/10 which would lead to me normally hiting a yes to the recommend option on these reviews. I still would recommend it to people who are fans of warcraft and the rts in general. However because of the overwhelming positive number of ratings and reviews a 5/10 is about as negative a review as I have seen on this game. I am clealry in the minority here and may be missing something...maybe i'll try and pick it up again in a few months but for right now I am putting it down and scratching my head.

But for any new players looking into this game try it out and don't let the toxic negative players gat in the way of your fun even if you win/lose. The in-game purchases are the really tempting parts so just ask for it as a gift when someone asks what you would like for your birthday, christmas, etc.  If you do make the choice to play dota 2 then learn to have fun put wrinkles in your brain and most importantly HAVE FUN!!

When it says that this is a 'casual' game, that's a lie. If you don't do your homework and research how to play whatever character you choose, then your teammates will make you regret not doing so as well as the rest of the game. This is far from the casual player's MOBA. The community for Dota 2 is very quick to strongly dislike you, but no matter what you do to try and earn back what little reputation you may have earned in the past, you will probably never see any respect from them again, ever. However, the community also knows literally all the ins and outs of the game. But once you get past all that as well as tricking your friends into joining you for a match or two, you just might find dota 2 to be something you enjoy.

Don't play this game. If you're reading this, odds are it's not too late. Save yourself while you can still be saved. This game is heroin. It has an impossibly steep learning curve that requires hundreds of hours of dedicated play to reach even a sub-competent level of skill. It requires an intuition that has been cultivated to an instict-like level. Succeeding at this can provide a high unrivaled by any other kind of video game. It's the addicting kind of high that makes you strive to play more and get better. But just like heroin, the more you play, the more those satisfying highs become fewer and farther between. There are hundreds of variables, many of which are almost completely out of your control, that can impact how fun or satisfying a game is. Worst of all, the community is not welcoming to new players in any way. You will be personally insulted. You will be blamed and flamed. Every decision you make will be questioned and judged by people who usually have almost no idea what they're talking about. 50%-90% of games which depend heavily on team-coordination will have people on your team that do not speak the same language (Don't worry, they will still insult you in their native tongue). People will rage and lag and quit. All of these things stand between you and that next heroin high. They waste tons of time, they don't help and in some cases are detrimental to you getting better or making improvements, and it's not fun. That's right. 50%-90% of the 30-60 minute games you will play will honestly not be fun. And that is AFTER you have spent all this time learning and becoming proficient at the game. Seriously. Don't play this game.

Hey you, yeah you! Don't have the brain capacity to control a massive army, build bases, and execute daring army battles even though this game's mechanics were taken from real-time-strategy games? And do you enjoy blaming teammates rather than doing something about it when you're losing? Do you enjoy picking characters, who only need right-clicks(carries) to function? Do you say 'we no def' when you're losing even though the game is called DEFENSE OF THE ANCIENTS? Then if so you hypocritical basterd, this game is meant for you!   Expect your first matches to be full of carries and practically no support plays at all! But who cares? You're having fun losing! Be careful though young warrior! Matches can be full of people complaining about your play or the items you buy! Don't worry they're just jealous of your feedi-- I mean killing streak! So what if they call a 'r*tarded play' or a 'wrong item' on you, if you're getting killz, then it's all fine! They're just jelly that you found a secret new meta before they could! So what if you play a support hero and they complain when you last hit? Not your fault my brotha, they're just too slow to react! So what if you're a support hero and not buy wards? Those wards are expensive as shet! If they want all the farm, while you just stand there, and then expect you to buy wards, then they are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as ♥♥♥♥! How can you possibly buy wards when you don't have any gold?! Bunch of r*♥♥♥♥♥, amirite?   You'll notice in your first games that people like to kill other people. Well that's normal, people do that in real life. But you must remember this golden rule: Always push. Kid, no matter how many times you pawn their noob arses you can't win if you can destroy the ancient. This game is not won by kills but by pushing. For example: There is an impending 5 on 5 brawl or 'clash' as they call it. But as your teammates prepare for bloodshed you notice at the other side of the map a pack of allied mindless soldiers or 'creeps' as they call it, slowly march towards an enemy tower. This is the perfect situation to push because the enemy 'Heroes' are way too far to respond to their tower being pushed. So what do you do? Ditch your teammates and head for that tower. Wait until they have started fighting and then you push. With the enemy team busy slaying your outnumbered teammates, you're free to burn that tower down to the ground. Results? A bounty of gold, and a pushed tower! Your teammates can complain all they want about you leaving them, when in fact they should be thanking you for giving them the tower bounty, ungrateful basterds.  If somehow, you managed to get to their 3rd tower, you'll notice that behind it are two buildings. These two buildings spawn the mindless 'creeps'. Unless you destroy the 3rd tower, these buildings are invulnerable, meaning they can't be f*cked with. If you destroy the 3rd tower then they are stripped of their godlike armor and now are ok to f*ck with. Pro tip: Destroy the melee barracks first. Why? Because destroying it somehow gives your melee creeps steroids. And since the melee creeps are the most produced creeps, giving them steroids is the most rewarding effect. And also, the building somehow has a regeneration effect, meaning it will heal itself! So if you're going to attack it, might as well destroy it now or you'll be forced to retreat and watch it 'heal'. Which leaves you to wonder as to how is it able to heal itself if it's just a building. How? Because f*ck logic that's why! And if you manage to destroy all of the enemy's barracks then the in-game announcer will shout: 'Mega creeps!' Signifying that all of the allied creeps have steroids. At that point, you can pretty much let the creeps swarm the enemy. I mean why not? You fought your ♥♥♥ out the whole match, and had to deal with the enemy's b*llsh*t, so why not let them have a slow and painful death? Sounds good doesn't it? And if you're lucky, you might witness an enemy hero get killed by being swarmed by your steroid creeps, fun ain't it?  When picking a 'hero' don't be that guy who picks first. And if you're notoriously unlucky, don't bother to random a hero. Yes it does give extra starting gold if you do, but you'll just end up giving it to the enemy as you feed. Let the others pick first. Take your time. This is the part of the game where you actually use the most of your mind with. Analyze, be considerate, and choose a hero who can both counter the enemy picks and complement your allied picks. Now that you've pick a hero it's time for the laning phase! If you're support then they will need wards, and wards need gold to possess, so what do you do? GO TO MID LANE. Why? So you can last hit without any teammate hogging all the farm. If you're carry then they will need you to get lots of exp and gold, so what do you do? GO TO MID LANE. If you're an offlaner then you need farm to get utility skills and items, so what do you do? GO TO MID LANE. If you're tank then they need you to get tanky items and lots of exp to get stronger, so what do you do? GO TO MID LANE. In fact, any hero you choose is a prime choice for mid lane. Remember, first come gets the lane.  But anyways this game is quite addictive and may ruin your social life, if you even had one. Friends, family, love ones all seem insignificant when you're in a match. If you're still in school, study time may become dota time, and if you're working, well you know what's going to happen. Overall this game has achieved what all games should achieve: Making you play and enjoy this game. So yes I recommend this game.   Good day to you sir

Defense of the Ancients 2 is my favorite video game. It is a free-to-play game created and maintained by the Valve Corporation, which is headquartered in Bellevue, Washington and ruled by the legendary Gabe Logan Newell. Defense of the Ancients 2 (DotA2) is a multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) in which each of ten players (two teams of five players each) take control of ten heroes to do battle and fulfill objectives on a roughly-symmetrical playing field. The game is routinely praised for being unforgivingly strategic and nearly impossible to master. Players seeking any level of success must be nimble of hand, cunning of mind, and, perhaps most importantly, completely void of human emotion: when two warriors lock eyes on the battlefield, be they the armorclad Dragon Knight, the enigmatic Juggernaut, the unrelenting Bloodseeker, or the mischievous faerie-dragon Puck, all mercy must be put aside. The best teams do not only destroy their opponents, though that is an important part: the best teams humiliate their enemies, casting them down like broken-winged birds into the loser’s pit of shame amidst an unceasing stream of ridicule and scorn. In a sense it is not a battle of heroes: it is a battle of egos where the most resilient emerges the victor. I, having accrued nearly two thousand matchmaking points, am unusually good, and with my signature hero, the Sniper, I have sown violence and death across thousands of battlefields. Regarding items, I start with a Butterfly. Providing massive bonuses to agility, attack speed, and evasion, it is, by a wide margin, the best item in the game. I usually stay mid lane and farm gold until I finish it, typically around minute 40, at which point I will start roaming and ganking. After netting a few kills I will purchase Mask of Madness to improve my attack speed and mobility. Some people prefer Boots of Speed as their mobility item, but in my opinion, only the dimmest of dimwits rely on passive effects: a truly skilled player (like me) can utilize active effects to greater result. Not to mention the Boots of Speed have no offensive capabilities whatsoever—neither attack damage, attack speed, or agility. One could argue that the upgraded Boots of Speed (called Power Treads) remedies this problem, but I would counter-argue that the passive 30 increased attack speed granted by the Power Treads pales in comparison to the Mask of Madness’s active attack speed bonus of 100. It is painfully obvious which is better—yet still I am routinely disappointed by just how many players refuse to buy the Mask of Madness. Passive effects are the bane of my online existence.

8/10  This game begins in your head like Age of the Empires, but then you realize it's much more. take hold of one hero and like any RPG, rage into battle. In dota you are the minion, your master unseen, yet he sends creatures to aid you, you are not alone, other heroes battle with you, users, have wow in such a unique blend of both multiplayer battles with astounding detail, every character can move their mouths the designs on their clothes visible, cloth waving in the winds.  One thing i very much respect is when you point your character in all new directions he won't repetitively bother you with. 'Yes.' 'Setting tragectory,' 'I'm manning this spot,' They each have a variety of things to say when walking, and won't say it every time you click, which is such a distraction in most MMORPG.  The only thing that would prevent me from loving it fully was the amazing 3D face you have in the corner, getting to see your hero is great, but he only talks when walking or being reincarnated (Coming back to life after dying,) this game supports mic input, so why wouldn't they have your character talk in the side when you did. anyway, that's a minor issue i see with it, this game is great, there is literally no reason not to get it, this game is free to play, and totally awesome.  #UPDATE002: Upon playing more of Dota 2, i have found a major flaw in all of their matchmaking systems. you see i have 5 matches left, in laggy servers, just because i quit. i wasn't abandoning i had my language on spanish not english, so my server was all the way in mexico, it was lagging on so i disconnected, next thing i know, the accept button now says 'Accept low prioity match'. so now i can only join laggy servers for abandoning the team. I COULDN'T DO ANYTHING FOR THE TEAM LIKE THAT. and now whoever quits the low priority servers i keep joining, it adds up to my punishment as they say, my punishment list. in numbers, well i'm currently at 5, yeah, it's fun to pay off my punishment, for having to quit! and that's why my review is now 8 out of 10, not 9 out of 10 anymore, thanks valve, way to make me hate your game, i still like this game enough to play it and have fun with it, but i'm stuck having to wait out in servers a sitting duck (Cause the lag is too much to bear, i'll only be feeding myself to the enemy.) until my numbers run dry!   hopefully thing review provides a lengthy opinion on why you i recommend it. this game was put together greatly, but still failed in a big part of me, i believe this game deserves a 8 out of 10.

Dota 2 is hard, but there's a huge reward for those who commit. On the surface, the game is a like-for-like reproduction of the genre-creating (and still updated) Defense of the Ancients modification for Warcraft III, now transferred into Valve's Source engine. The game's punishing design is sometimes enough to drive you up the wall, but it's worth sticking the hours in: success in Dota 2 is about learning to effectively juggle both the broad strokes and finer details.  If you're not aware of the basics of the burgeoning MOBA genre, two teams of five players spawn on corners of a map. Each team needs to work together with the goal of ultimately destroying a central structure--in Dota 2's case, the Ancient--in the opposing team's base. With most games lasting around the 40-minute mark, and occasionally edging past an hour, watching the enemy fortress dramatically crumble and sink to the ground feels like an exhilarating payoff.

It is the best of games, it is the worst of games. There hasn't be a game in recent years that is equally likely to make you swear at the screen and idiotic teammates, as it is to make you smile and laugh when stuff goes well. I guarantee every game will produce emotion, even if some of those are better left unfelt. Just don't punish the hardware you're playing on, it's not to blame.  And the first couple dozen games you play, you will hate it. And your team will hate you. And you'll be told to delete dota and kill yourself. And because you're persistent and don't take crap from random morons on the internet, you will ignore them and get better at the game purely out of spite. It's a great game. Let the other player's hatered fuel your desire to improve, and you will get better.

This game simply revolutionises the concept of team playing. Many of the new rules of team playing introduced by DotA 2 may prove confusing for a lot of people, so let's do a quick test:  Do you enjoy getting frequently yelled at or flamed for not barging headlong into a fight with low health just to die and feed the enemy team?  Do you like hearing 10 pings per second from at least 2 people at the same time on a point on the map where you must go and die, thus feeding the enemy team (and then being called a noob)?  When alone at home, enjoying a quiet, uneventful afternoon, in a relaxed, civilised environment, do you feel the urge to throw yourself in a highly stressful, xenophobic, toxic, sausage-measuring slugfest of teenage (mostly Russian) boys with barely any knowledge of English, attempting to inflate their egos by virtually punching each other while insulting each other?  If the answer to those questions is yes, then this is the game for you, you murderous sociopath. 10/10, will play during finals.

Dota 2 is not going to be for everyone due to the skill level needed as well as the tactics needed to play the game. People coming from League of Legends may have a hard time playing this game because of the different mechanics, so expect to do well just because your level 15 in LoL. This game is the original Dota in a more up to date form. Dota 2 is rising in the competitive arena as MLG is just taking it under its wing in the recent MLG Columbus Championship, as well as Dota 2 being played at Dreamhack Winter 2013 for the first time.   If you want to play a competitive MOBA with a better community (imo) than LoL, then shoot for this game. It is the next step in terms of skills needed.

Never seen a mentally challenged person before? Well now is your chance! This game not only allows you to observe mentally challenged people BUT even interact with them. For a big fat price of 0 dollars, you can experience the stupidity of people first-hand as you are placed in the natural habitat of mentally challenged people. Although the game advertises a 5vs5 experience, at the very least it will be a 3vs7 because the first law of DOTA2 is 'In a public game, there will be a minimum of two mentally challenged people on your team.' If you're unlucky enough to stumble on to hard mode than the game will become a 1vs9. There are over 100 different heroes in the game with more being added which means you can experience different levels and forms of pointless bickering with mongoloids. 100+ heroes means you can experience literally A BAJILLION unique combinations of contracting Down's Syndrome from the community.  Ever see someone give up on life so easily? Well now is your chance! Enter matchmaking with other players and die at least twice within the first 3 minutes to watch players throw every single known profanity at you. Then watch as these players say 'gg go next' faster than you can ♥♥♥ from a cool summer breeze. If you die enough times in the game then watch as your team mates leave the game to kill themselves in order to ascend the DOTA2 heaven as this is the only appropriate reaction to getting a noob on your team.  Want to learn different languages but don't have the time? Too poor to afford free Google translate? Well now is your chance to become a multilingual god whose vast array of languages will surely impress the ladies.   Warning: Game is extremely addictive. Once you start playing, you have a 103% chance of becoming mentally challenged.  Overall, 1/10 would recommend.

Of the half-dozen people I started learning Dota 2 with, three still play regularly. Though there are hundreds of thousands of players of our approximate skill level populating the matchmaking queues, the four of us are more like each other than we are like anyone else playing Valve’s isometric wizard-’em-up.  Spending a year learning to shuffle a gaggle of fantasy heroes up Dota’s teetering stack of rules and game mechanics will do that to you: we’ve developed a secret language of our own, one that runs parallel to the talk of creeps and lanes and farm and rax common to everyone who plays the game. “Whack a ward on the donkletron I’m going to stick one up their jungle” is a sentence I can say out loud and be completely understood by at least those three people. For some reason, there’s also a lot of singing involved. It’s a lot like being a sailor.

There was a time when me and my friends were just playing coop games together. You know. We'd decide that we would play something like borderlands or maybe middle earth 2, and just have fun. Then, a little more than 2 years ago, while my friends were at my place for some LAN action, we found this game called DOTA 2. It was out of beta, and some of us knew about DOTA 1, so we gave it a go. From that moment i was obsessed with the game for something like a year. So were my friends. Dota became the most common game played among our community and spread like the ♥♥♥♥ing plague. Listen. The community might be toxic, the russians might be Russian, and I might be stuck at mid 2k MMR busting my ♥♥♥ off while some dickbag loses my team the match, but you know what. This game somehow, through the PIDORASI and CYKAS, the rage inducing lost games, the blaming of people, SOMEHOW this game proves to be just amazing. For every bad game I've had, I can tell a dota story I'm happy to have. I'm glad I have alot of friends who play DOTA. I think that if you play only solo, it could get depressing.

General Free to play (no pay to play), cross-platform (Windows, Linux, Mac).  Community While there are quite some flamers around, there are also a bunch of nice people you can meet. Team fights especially with your mates are the most fun so be sure not to only play alone. Region and especially language settings are unfortunately more or less ignored at the moment. :(  Comparison to League of Legends In contrast to League of Legends you can play any hero right from the beginning, though recently the amount of 'new' heroes (so far there are still a few Dota 1 heroes awaiting to be 'ported') introduced is quite less than in League of Legends. There are no masteries or runes, which makes stuff easier in this regard. There are no summoner spells and no backteleporting (though you can buy teleportation scrolls which teleport you to any friendly building.) There an upgradable courier to bring you stuff! :D :D Felt there are a lot more monster or 'creature' heroes in Dota 2, hm. I don't mind humans Valve!  Free to play You can't buy any items which would give you any advance on your opponent. Which is a good thing I'd say. Items you can buy are cosmetical items, like armor parts (please don't start to force Item Sets on me Valve), different HUDs, taunt animations, differently looking wards etc.

Dota 2 is a 2013 multiplayer online battle arena video game and the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos and Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, Dota 2 was released as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, concluding a public beta testing phase that began in 2011. OS X and Linux versions of Dota 2 were released on July 18, 2013. The game is available exclusively through Valve's content-delivery platform, Steam.  Dota 2 is played in discrete matches involving two five-player teams, each of which occupies a stronghold at a corner of the map. Each stronghold contains a building called the 'Ancient', which the opposite team must destroy to win the match. Each player controls a 'Hero' character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory.  Development of Dota 2 began in 2009, when the developer of the DotA mod, IceFrog, was hired by Valve as lead designer. Dota 2 was praised by video game critics, who lauded its rewarding gameplay, enhanced production quality and faithfulness to its predecessor. However, the game was criticized for its steep learning curve and inhospitable community. Dota 2 has become the most actively played game on Steam, with daily peaks of over 800,000 concurrent players.
