If you're going to spend any time playing either this and/or League of Legends, this is a far more interesting use of your time.  Here are a list of pros and cons:  Pros:  -Heroes have integrity and character -Hats -Carries don't build the same things as each other -There is no designated 'jungler' role -Game mechanics don't change to accommodate bad players -Game mechanics don't change to accommodate immature players -volvo -Holiday themed game modes in which you can obtain hats -Game mechanics don't change to accommodate whiny players -Hat trading -gaben -Victories are highly satisfying -The game is highly cerebral -Half-Life 3 confirmed -Also, hats  Cons:  -The matchmaking system is suspicious -Russians not playing on the Russian servers  As you can see, the pros clearly outweigh the cons. By this metric, you should most definitely play this hat simulator, I mean, game.

Dota 2 - is a multiplayer game in the genre of real-time strategy with RPG elements. Is an extension of the world-famous fashion DotA («Defense of the Ancients» - Defense of the Ancients) to the game Warcraft III. Maud on so much popular that the game industry has a new genre - Action-RTS, with lots of 'clones', both successful and not.  Gameplay is a competition between the two teams, consisting of three or five persons. One team is the bright side, the second - the Dark. Each side, a different set of characters.  Each player can only control one business unit or, in other words, his hero. In the course of the passing game hero gains experience, thereby increasing their level. He can also earn gold. In addition, he regularly receives small amounts from its base, it can mine gold by killing enemies.  Murder heroes brings significantly more gold than the destruction of enemy creeps. In addition, the hero can collect and buy a variety of items that affect its strength and development, as well as provide additional benefits.  In the course of the game have to fight not only with the opposing party, but also beat the regular attack creeps, computer controlled. The main task - keeping the defense of its own base, destroy the enemy's main building base side.  In addition, the characters can be dispersed throughout the territory and fight with neutral monsters.

So... DotA....Ive had my share of WC3 version of this game (and it rocked my world back then!), so i decided to try and get my invite. After a while i got one and what i saw after installation WAS AMASING! Valve's desingners and artists did their best to bring good old Defense of the Ancients up to the standarts of graphics and style of games today. I will not compare D2 to any other MOBA-game, because itll just cause some disturbance and trolling in the comments section. So lets compare it to the original: graphics(all of it inc. animation and artwork) got better, interface got free from the 'chains' of WC3 engine and became more user-friendly, after a while adequate matchmaking system(kind of...), ability to watch tournaments online in client itself, genious marketing model(you can buy ONLY cosmetic items, which will have no impact on balance(HEYO~ other MOBAs! sry..). After a couple of matches i got one thing perfectly clear: DotA2 gives you is thing that youll hate or love, dont think something in-between is possible. Conclusion: MOBA at its finest. Perfect solution to nothing-to-do situation!

I've been playing this game for 2-3 years now and I'm still learning a lot of new things playing new heroes. I got better since the beginning of course but there are still a lot of things hindering me from becoming better due to the people I often get teamed with. Unreasonable, uncultured, foul, uncooperative, egotistical and indenial people ruining my games 80% of the time. People like to say not to complain about others and work on yourself to get good and that's true. I can live with my mistakes and I know I do sometimes. But complaining about a team that snowballed pretty well until the mid game where every crumbled because of the refusal to get BKBs isn't my mistake when I've been telling them for 15 minutes to get a BKB and end the game. It was too late when my carries had their BKBs because they've been losing the past few team fights due to not being able to survive. Nobody cares how much damage per second you can do when you can hardly survive a fight. It's like having the fastest car in the world with no engine. Logic? I'm not a high skilled player and not very mechanical but I observe a lot of the things people do in pub games and often times my team makes the most mistakes. Primarily because they like to play for themselves and refuse to strategize and listen to the shot caller. I've been in normal skill bracket all my life since I started so I know how they play very well. If only my team is on the same page with me, I'd win most of my games and not have to waste time on a bunch of immature, fun loving (as in spoiling games and throwing), and unreasonable ♥♥♥♥faces.   TL;DR : I hate how most Pinoys, Indonesians, and Thais play. Mainly Filipinos and Indonesians because they think they know the game but they can never show it in their plays and for Thais, they barely speak a word of English so it was very difficult to communicate strategies with them.

DotA 2 is a constantly evolving Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA) masterwork that continuously reinvents competitive gaming with new heros, items and gameplay patches while simultaneously remaining linear in it's general strategy: DEFENSE of the ANCIENTS!  DotA 2's straightforward mechanics are simple to conceive yet difficult to master. And just when you think you've found a workable strategy for one of your favorite heros (of which, there are over 100 to choose from!!), a new patch is released with Nerfs & Buffs that change the entire landscape of the game.  DotA 2 brings players together in a competitive environment where communciation, team dynamics, sacrifice and objective based gaming coalesce into perhaps the greatest online gaming experience ever.  The Internationial, an annual DotA 2 competition hosted by Valve, held it's 5th event in 2015 and boasted an impressive $18.5 million dollar prize pool. The prize pool is almost entirely generated by the DotA 2 community (all 11.5 million of us) and their (our) in-game purchases during the weeks preceding the event. The International's prize pool in 2015 was the second largest prize pool on record for that year, with winnings exceeding that of the Masters and Wimbeldon. (NOTE: The International 2016 shattered last year's prize pool with just over $20.5 million)  The content is centered in an epic fantasy realm filled with Knights, Dragons, Assassins, Kings, Magic, and enough lore to keep the obessive supporters (self included) entertained for days.  If you consider yourself a gamer and have yet to experience Dota 2, you are in for a real treat. I'm trading my console in folks! All it does now is collect dust, for I am ever busy defending my Ancient from ensuing attacks as I battle alongside warriors in arms as we ebb and flow across the Radiant/Dire battlefield to solidfy our victory, or die in defeat.

Dota 2 is a multiplayer online battle arena video game, the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos and Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, Dota 2 was released as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, OS X and Linux in July 2013, concluding a Windows-only public beta testing phase that began in 2011. The game is available exclusively through Valve's content-delivery platform, Steam.

I've been playing the 'original' Defense of the Ancients since the 5th grade, and to be fair, this game had me drawn. Improvements, and a lot of it, were much welcome to the community. The gameplay were significantly improved, and what is even better, is that it has left the beauty of the first DOTA preserved. My experience with Dota 2 has been really good thus far. As a player of other moba games such as League of Legends, Heroes of the Storm, and Smite, in my own opinion Dota 2 is the best amongst them. For those who really want a challenge that is...... because Dota is not something that every player can play and expect to win easily. No, this is the only game which employs some of the hardcore moba features such as lasthitting and the sort. The variety in terms of heroes (which are all unlocked), combos, tactics is insane. I have put 1000+ hours in it and I still find tons of stuff everyday. And once you get the hang of it, you'll get addicted. Teamplay is a must in this game and i recommend you play with friends (or you can play and make some). Ofcourse, you'll need a long time to learn the game, but its worth it. Once you start ranked matches, its 'all about dat MMR'. I recommend it to all moba players out there who want a 'real' moba. If you want casual, go for LoL or something.  9/10

So... DotA....Ive had my share of WC3 version of this game (and it rocked my world back then!), so i decided to try and get my invite. After a while i got one and what i saw after installation WAS AMASING! Valve's desingners and artists did their best to bring good old Defense of the Ancients up to the standarts of graphics and style of games today. I will not compare D2 to any other MOBA-game, because itll just cause some disturbance and trolling in the comments section. So lets compare it to the original: graphics(all of it inc. animation and artwork) got better, interface got free from the 'chains' of WC3 engine and became more user-friendly, after a while adequate matchmaking system(kind of...), ability to watch tournaments online in client itself, genious marketing model(you can buy ONLY cosmetic items, which will have no impact on balance(HEYO~ other MOBAs! sry..). After a couple of matches i got one thing perfectly clear: DotA2 gives you is thing that youll hate or love, dont think something in-between is possible. Conclusion: MOBA at its finest. Perfect solution to nothing-to-do situation!

Dota 2 is the successor to Defense of the Ancients, the Warcraft 3 mod that spawned an entire genre of team-based, RPG-esque hero battlers. The game is deeply engaging, wildly fun, and seemingly limitless in its replayability. By its nature as an hour-long game of teamwork and cooperation, a minority of the community can be hostile and unwelcoming at times, but on the whole the game's players are friendly, enthusiastic and energetic.  For newer players in particular, Dota 2 is a game best played with friends, who will be more willing and likely to show you the ropes than a group of four strangers on the internet. I heartily recommend all of you to give this game a try!

Scientists (better known colloquially as Boffins) are a quirky and interesting bunch. Burdened with the responsibility for delving into the Forbidden Mysteries of the universe, they have an insatiable curiosity and an unhealthy obsession with monkeys. They also like Star Trek and love to make funny laser noises when they think no one is watching. Even though the endless pursuit of knowledge has driven them insane, they go about their tasks with great ardour and perseverance, not because they want to, but because they must. Because intelligence is a privilege. A gift, to be used for the good of mankind.  Since the beginning of time, science has waged an eternal war against the forces of Magic. Scientists claim that the Universe was created by a massive explosion called the 'Big Bada Boom', resulting from the collision of Egos from two Hollywood superstars in another dimension. The Magic guys however claim the Universe was created by some old white guy who sent his only son to Earth wearing his underpants on the outside with a symbol that looks like a red 'S' on his chest that meant 'hope' in his home language.  To this day, all attempts to resolve this war have been unsuccessful, often degenerating into drunken ribaldry and rampant wedgies. To settle the matter, Arthur C. Clarke declared that 'Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.' This is because whenever you go to Vegas to watch a magic show, you can never tell if the magician is using technological tricks or real magic.  Incidentally, practitioners of Vegas Magic are masters of manipulating the time-money continuum, as opposed to the space-time continuum favoured by garden variety scientists. Anyone who's ever observed one will wake up the next morning with 2 hours missing from their life and $40 missing from their wallet, having no memory of the previous night except for the sinister phrase 'Ta da!'  Anyway, scientists are also no slouches when it comes to Jedi Mind Tricks. While pondering the perplexing but rather otiose question of ' Why Asparagus Makes Your Wee Smell  [www.bbc.com] ', scientists managed to convince a bunch of strangers to eat the vegetable and then sniff their own and each other's urine. Seriously, how do you convince total strangers to eat vegetables?  The reason why scientists are so good at mind manipulation is because they do a lot of research in the area of Cognitive Biases. For the less academic types, Cognitive Biases are inclinations to think in certain ways that lead people to behaving irrationally. Where by irrational they mean more stupid than usual. For example, people consistently confuse the price of a good with its quality - they think an item labelled with an expensive price tag is better than the same item labelled with a cheaper price tag. This is why people keep buying the same overpriced and over-hyped Call of Duty games year after year.  Worried that their simian friends might be conned into buying Call of Duty games,  the boffins at Yale University  [news.yale.edu]  designed a series of experiments to test whether  Capuchin monkeys  [en.wikipedia.org]  were susceptible to this pricing bias. They taught them to make choices in an experimental market and to buy novel foods at different prices. They also trained them to get jobs in  government  and in  executive management .  What the scientists found was that the Capuchins were not fooled by higher prices. When given Steam accounts, Capuchins would eschew banal and overpriced sycophantic franchises in favour of more affordable Free-To-Play games like Team Fortress and Dota 2. This result didn't surprise anyone except the scientists because as everyone knows, monkeys don't have money and don't go shopping. They are actually barred from shopping malls because of their blasé attitude towards shoplifting. Even Amway won't sell to them. No kidding.  The downside to Capuchins playing online games is that they are very bad losers renowned for their deplorable online behaviour. They rage quit, AFK frequently, and like to render dubious gameplay advice peppered with imprecations and expletives. They regularly accuse superior players of hacking and 'kill stealing' while casting aspersions on their sexuality and genealogy. They also sometimes speak in tongues (which may or may not be a foreign language).  As for Dota 2, it was originally a mod for WarCraft 3 that became popular and spawned a new gaming genre known as the MOBA or Male Only ♥♥♥♥♥ing Arena. Dota, on the other hand, is an acronym for Don't Open Thy ♥♥♥, perhaps a reference to a game winning strategy or an obscure Latin Biblical reference, nobody really knows. Basically two teams (mostly males) get together and aggressively complain about things like OP heroes, exploits, ganking, and useless teammates. There's a lot of preening and posturing, not unlike the tribal mating rituals of the Wachatu Tribe.  MOBA gameplay is similar to Action RPGs like Torchlight or Diablo. Basically you run around exploring jungles and steal gold from enemy players called 'creeps'. They are called 'creeps' because they will stalk you on Facebook and spam dodgy trade requests for your rare items. The toughest enemy units are towers that have a lot of hitpoints and can kill you in a few hits. With lots of practice you should be able to take one down solo with no more than 6 or 7 deaths while teammates encourage you with their battle cries of 'Stop feeding!' Whatever that means. It's probably an abbreviation for 'Stop feeding the Beast!' A statement of reverence for your amazing tower soloing skills.  Because MOBAs are so popular (and hence profitable), the market is being saturated by companies pining for a profit churning them out. It's like those game shows where contestants are put into a glass box filled with money, and a fan blows the money around and they have to grab as much as they can before the time runs out. At the moment, the most popular MOBAs are League of Legends and Dota 2. Blizzard's new Heroes of the Storm will likely make an impact somewhere between 'Meh' and 'Whatever'. Although WoW fans will probably be mad for it, if they can tear themselves away from WoW long enough to play a game. Blizzard is the company famous for rewarding their loyal customers with laggy online-only single player games.  Although the majority of MOBAs are F2P, they have different business models. In Dota 2 all heroes are immediately available with only cosmetic items available for purchase. Others like LoL and HotS favour a rotating roster of free characters, with a permanent character unlock available for cash. For those credit card warriors with more money than good sense looking to supplement their lack of skills with debt, this is probably not the game for you. For everyone else, Dota 2 is free, so try it out risk-free, or not.

Dota 2 - The successor of 'Defense of the Ancients'  Dota 2, itself, is a great game, easy to grasp, fun and interesting characters, variety out the ♥♥♥. I have played this game for 3 years and loved it, that is, until ranked matchmaking. Ranked matchmaking is the worst thing you can add to a TEAM based game. The thing is, you very rarily will get a team on your skill level. Therefore in the first 10 ranked games, which is your rating period, you will probably have garbage teammates. This will make you lose the game, and your rank is based on win-loss for some reason. So say you have 7 bad games and 3 good games in ranked. All due to team flunking, your rank will suffer, easily <2000. Which is the scrub teir, MEANING, you will not be able to raise your rank due to the trash you will be put with. I would fix this by making the rank system depend on: xpm, gpm, kdr, support items used, wards placed and destroyed, towers destroyed, assists. Rather than just wins and losses.  Another complaint I have about this game is the ridiculously toxic community, you could miss one last hit (how you get gold) and they will call you out on being an 'autistic muslim with downs.' Ive heard that one a lot recently. The reports on comm abuse don't do anything unless the entire team reports them, and most people dont report just because they dont care.  The game itself is AMAZING, getting a team together is how you have to play though, if you arent severly masochistic.  Thank You

Some may look to avoid Dota 2 as a result of it's steep learning curve, and instead start with League of Legends, which is in my opinion, basic Dota. But I assure you that (and many others would say the same) once you get the hang of the game, it'll be endless fun with plenty of strategies and possibilities. With over 100 unique and original heroes to choose from all from the start (no unlocking required), and how difficult, occasionally cruel, and complex Defence Of The Ancients 2 is, it'll be an extremely rewarding and satisfying experience whenever you emerge victorious from a match after reducing the enemies' base to rubble. As a result, no match will ever be identical to one anouther. I recommend you to give it a try and see what you think.

This game... This game is so much fun. I had never played a MOBA before Dota 2, and I thought I never would. If you didn't know what a MOBA was, it's a Multiplayer Online Battle Arena. There are 10 people in a game, 5 on each team. You pick a hero out of 100+ heroes and fight together as a team and hopefully win. It sounds straight forward, but there is a lot of strategy involved and you have to think before you act.  I remember hearing about it a lot while it was in Beta, but never really took an interest in it. But when it officially realized, I took a stab at it and never look back. I now have about 140 hours on it, and I've been playing it for a couple months. It is that fun.  But if you have never played a MOBA before, it has a VERY steep learning curve. I remember going into my first online game after the training and was for some reason in the All Pick gamemode (I'll get to the gamemodes later) for some reason and played as Bristleback as he look really awesome. I though I would do good... I was wrong, so wrong. I did sooooo bad, so, so bad. I recommend you look up some guides and videos before you jump into online. Also, play a lot of bot games before online too.  When you start playing online, choose the Limited Heroes mode. The LM mode is where you can choose out of the 20 easiest heroes and hopefully play against other new people. This is where everyone should start. The other gamemodes are Single Draft, you choose out of 3 randomly chosen heroes, Least Played, you can choose out of your leasted played heroes, All Pick, where you can choose any hero, Captains Draft, you get assigned a captain who assigns and bans heroes for you from a limited hero pool, Captains Mode, the same as Captains Draft, but you can pick and ban all the heroes in the game, not just some, Random Draft, you choose a hero out of a pool of 20 heroes, everyone takes turns, and All Random, you get assigned a random hero.  Dota 2 is a free to play game, but it is NOT pay to win. Everything you can buy are all cosmetic and do not affect gameplay.  When you are in your match, there will be things called 'Towers', you want to protect yours and destroy the other teams. There are also little minions called Creeps, they are more important than you think. They go up with you in the Lanes, which there are 3 of. A bottom, middle, and top lane. Your prized possesion and most valuable structure is your Ancient. If you destroy the other teams, you win, if they destroy yours, you lose. Simple. There is also a big monseter called Roshan. If you kill him, he drops an item call the Aegis of the Immortal. Whoever picks it up will resurrect at the spot they died.  There is some more in depth stuff in the game, but this is a review, not a guide.   So there it is. my review for Dota 2. It is a very, very fun and addicting MOBA with a steep learning curve.  if you just want a score, I would give it a 9.5/10. Not a 10 because of it's steep learning curve preventing some players getting into the game.  Thanks for reading! :) Also, this was my first Steam review, feed back is appreciated.

Edited on 1 August 2015  After 24 hundred hours on DotA 2, I've come to a conclusion. I'll admit that DotA 2 is not for everyone.  I will only recommend DotA 2 for anyone who wants a challenge. DotA 2 is not your average game to destress. In fact, it is quite the opposite. DotA 2 will make you pull your hair out, smash your headphones in frustration and spam Alt-LeftClicks. But why do I still play it? Little can beat that satisfaction you get from beating the enemies after a long 60+ minutes match, the feeling of accomplishment when you escape with 1 Hp or the rush of adrenaline when you jump into all 5 enemies, ready to use the biggest ultimate of your life.  The skill ceiling of DotA 2 is only as high as the sky. It's reachable, but it is not exactly very easy to be a master. 110 Heroes to choose from, 110 Heroes to master. Its up to you and your patience to master them. Some heroes are definitely easier than others, and vice versa.   DotA 2 also is somewhat like the real world. There are tons of people who will critise and put you down, and you must have the peserverance to keep moving forward.   Also, Some things to take note of if you are playing in the SouthEast Asia region and below the 'average' skill of players (e.g. when you are first starting out) Pinoys who lack humility and overloads everyone with insults + chat/mic spam Singaporeans whose ego is too big  Ultimately, it is still your Choice. If you enjoy a challenge, DotA 2 may be the game for you. If not, thanks for reading my review.

I will be honest. I love DOTA 2. The artworks and creation of the game is really imaginative, and I am getting inspiration from the game. The gameplay is pretty good too, but the game really depends on the early and late game stages, as games have been turned around from megas.   However, the community, on the other hand... The majority just instant pick heroes they want to play, and generally feed. Supports try to last hit instead of denying and harassing the enemies to create space for their carries to farm, which would generally mean that they lose. Another downfall would be that there are a lot, and I mean A LOT of non English players on the Australian servers, not showing cooperation and team work, becoming dependent on themselves, which I think is irritating.  We all have to admit on something...  Meepo is the best hero that the game has to offer. 8^)

To the Newcomer   A great game with a steep learning curve you shouldn't be afraid of. You must understand that yes, it really does take over 100 hours just to get a grasp of all the basics, but you can improve faster if you take the time to read what things do. Once you understand all the interactions in the game, you'll remember everything you need to in no time. It can be fun figuring it all out for yourself!  Remember to relax and that you  will  lose a bunch of your early games. You will probably get raged at, but you should simply ignore the insults! Rage doesn't help the team win and you shouldn't complain or rage back. Taking a breath and encouraging the team to move forward with helpful suggestions will alleviate the tunnel vision received from getting needlessly angry. Even if you lose, you can still have fun and will have still learned a wealth of information!  Once you accept all that, you can easily enjoy the game. There will be plenty of great times had, don't let anything stop you from reaching your wins!  The most important thing to remember is to have  fun  and  learn  during all that time, because you will be spending a lot of time getting to know the game.  A personal recommendation of mine:  Get involved in the forums and keep up with the metagame. It ebbs and flows every few months with the trends players follow, changing seasonally. You have plenty of time to learn and your previous knowledge is still useful and never wasted by a balance patch. On the forums you can find like-minded individuals who can provide feedback on your questions and thoughts, and with the guidance of others you'll never feel lost.   To the Veteran   Dota 2 is  the  game to play if you like this genre. With over 10 years of refinement the balance is unparalleled by any other game of its kind. Pretty much the best of what you're looking for.  So to all I say: dive in! It's completely free to play and definitely worth every delicious hour spent playing.

DOTA2: where should/could I start on a review about a game such as this. I could say it's a great game and that wouldn't be a lie, but it would, however, be far from the truth. While the game does provide a rich environment for players to hone their skills and play with friends, the game also roots itself into your subconcious: consequently making your more and more toxic. Winning is great in this game but losing. . .losing could potentially make you mad, as you'll eventually find yourself blaming other's for your lack wins. It took me quite some time before I realized just how bad this game was for my life. I became a condescending prick and found myself losing friends simply because I wasn't fun to play with. It was a tough lesson to learn, but it was neccessary. To this day I still know people who play this game, and I've urged them to quit while they're ahead. Because, while the game can be fun, in the long-run the amount of pent up frustration emanating from this game is uncalled for. My profile says I haven't played since December; in reality, I haven't played since May 2015 and haven't looked back.

A few weeks ago, I was a DOTA virgin. I'd never played it, and had little understanding of what it was all about. But following a lunchtime conversation wth 600-plus-hours-of-playtime-expert Cassandra, her boundless enthusiasm persuaded me to take the plunge.   I documented my experience as I played through the game's fairly solid training mode in our DOTA 2 LiveTopic, and evolved from clueless idiot to idiot with a clue. Following a week of playing with actual human beings, I'm now fully grounded in the game's fundamentals, and am looking forward to mastering its subtleties and nuances in my quest to become an adept DOTA player.   The Facts Developer: Valve  Publisher: Valve  Version reviewed: PC  Also available on: PC, Mac  Price: $FREE  Get it here  Review copy was downloaded for nothing.  What immediately strikes me about DOTA – to coin a hideously over-used cliché – is that it's easy to learn, but difficult to master. It's a phrase oft bandied about, but in this case it perfectly describes DOTA's very simple concept and goals – which take mere seconds to understand – and its phenomenal gameplay variability and strategic depth – which offer enormous scope for skills development.

After playing quite a bit of League of Legends, I decided to finally give DOTA 2 a fair shake, and... well, I think I like it. There are some frustrations in transitioning from LoL's mechanics, especially when it comes to Tower/creep aggro (very different strategy than LoL) and overall champion strength, but the more I stick with it, the easier it is to avoid blindly falling prey to these things. I like that all the champions are free, with the ability to pay for non-effective, aesthetic customizations, not to mention the integration with Steam Workshop, to potentially get your own mods in the game. I still favor LoL, but there is a lot to like here, and I look forward to spending more time learning the depths of this game.

DotA is a game which places you in an alternate universe where the Soviet Union will conquer the world. You and your comrades are trapped in a Western society. So angry at the oppressive western capitalist regime, your team channel their rage into feeding the enemy team resources and lives in order to destroy the establishment from within. As you band together with said saboteurs you slowly work towards a 'divine rapier' a gift from the holy Gaben to present to the enemy team. Upon recieving this gift the enemy team's hard carry will use it to rapidly tear down towers (symbolisation of the lavish skyscapers built by capitalism causing starvation to millions) and kill the creeps (who represent the brain-washed capitalist puppet slaves throwing away their lives chasing the dream of riches falsely implanted by ruthless American propoganda) until the heartland is vulnerable to soviet conquer. To celebrate your triumphant victory in the face of United States terror you can report your teammates to the new regime, so they will know who worked hardest to give over to the impending Russian invasion and reward them with time off for their hard work. 10/10 Original plotline and authentic Russian actors for teammates.

Dota 2 is a game that challenges your reflexs and stratagy with 4 teamates and 5 opposing players. As someone who had never played the original Dota for Warcraft 3 and had only played League of Legends prior to the release of Dota 2, I can safely say it's worth the switch. Every aspect of this game seems to be done really well, and it doesn't seem like Valve is stopping on the updates anytime soon.  The only negative thing I can say about this game is the community, but theses days if you play online you can expect that in any game.

tldr; Dota 2 is a fun, intricate game that requires good teamwork and skill but is very rewarding once experience is gained.  I have just reached my 1000th game and almost 1000th hour in Dota 2 and I felt compelled to write a review regarding my thoughts. Dota 2 is unlike any other game you've ever experienced and unlike any game you'll ever probably experience. It is an extremely detailed, intricate and competitive MOBA styled video game that takes place in one small arena with five persistant players.  Dota 2 is a game that punishes you severely for being bad and making mistakes but also rewards you greatly when you start getting a hand of how the competitive gameplay works. Getting good at Dota requires effort, attention to detail, patience, a love of Mother Russia and many many ruined mice. In my experience I have played with Dota players that sabotage a match willingly and I have played with people who are capable of turning a losing battle into a great victory. Once you start playing you will most probably be horrible but as your hours start to accumulate slowly your skill starts increasing too and once you start getting a lot of kills you will truly understand the fun of Dota 2.   You will surely find players that are better and also players that are worse than you. In my honest opinion it is a game one should start playing with the knowledge that great teamwork will most likely lead to a great victory. If you are not looking for a game that requires good teamwork and communication however Dota is not for you. The game can get very intricate as the skills learnt coupled with the items you choose to purchase are capable of boosting your stats incredibly and can change the outcome of a game.  Try it out, who knows, you might enjoy it so much that you'd start playing it professionally..

Just a list of things about it: frustrating, hard, confusing, far too intricate, unforgiving, unbalanced, VERY computer intensive, buggy, unrewarding, and TERRIBLE matchmaking. Don't get me wrong, I used to play this game. I never really liked it, but just enough to where I played it a lot. The devs don't care AT ALL about pubs (the matches where people who aren't pro play), they only care about the pro players and how they're doing. The abandon system is completely rigged, if you leave a game for more than 5 minutes (this means if you crash, your internet fails, or you just leave) you get an abandon. Abandons make it so you can't get battle points to level up your profile and you also have even worse matchmaking for the next game you play. The thing is, when someone leaves a game, it simply says, ''Whomever' has left the game.' It isn't like in many other games where it says whether you have dc'ed through straight-up leaving or crashing. Don't get this game. If you already play it, just know I'm not gonna play it anymore.

Well. I was really really really excited about the release of Dota 2. I can't say I was disappointed. Actually I was quite happy. I enjoyed it. For some time. I played this game for years now but I cannot believe how much it actually changed. With Reborn, Dota 2 has become a game development platform. Classic Dota dominates three quarters of the UI, but that 'Custom Game' tab ultimately represents an offering far, far bigger than it.   The Dota 2 community is enormously elitist - a sign of weakness is tantamount to blood in the water. Nobody wants to admit their mistakes, everybody wants to blame somebody else. This is a community with a widespread working knowledge of the Dunning-Kruger effect, for heaven's sake.  Even if Dota 2 gained a scrappy new identity, you should respect your elders and load WC3 from time to time ;)

I personally prefer Dota 2 over any other MOBA. Here are some reasons why:   - In Dota 2, all heros are free and ready to play as soon as you start! This helps avoid power crawls when developers create a new hero to play.   (Sorry League.)    - There are over 110 heros to play, all with thier own unique skills. All of the heros have thier own animations as well.  - Though there is only one offical 'gamemode' for Dota, there are hundreds of user create modes. Many of them are quite popular, such as 'IMBA.' (One even turns Dota in to a hack-and-slash RPG!)  - I agree that the community can be harsh, but that's what friends are for? Seriously. It's better with them. In fact everything is.  - And Dota is free. Unless you want purely cosmetic skins.   PURELY COSMETIC SKINS.

By far my favorite MOBA to date. If you enjoy 5v5 matches then you will highly enjoy this game! League of Legends has its high points but the graphics and the ability to play ALL of the available heroes without making purchases is what makes this stand out the most.   Here are some the the pros and cons comparing Dota2 to League of Legends. PROS: -Courier that can deliver items to you on the battlefield -Use all heroes without purchasing them individually  -High Res graphics  -The ability to deny your opponents XP and Gold by killing friendly structures/buildings -Win Free loot when you play to 'dress up' your heroes  -Multiple Item shops spread around the map  CONS: -No free universal spells like HEAL, TELEPORT, ETC that can be used on all heroes -Only has a single 5v5 map, no 3v3 option/map -Matches range in time from 20 minutes to upward to 1.5 hours. Hard to predict how much time to set aside to play. -Match Making Rating system is somewhat unbalanced and makes it hard to conistantly gain rank.

I think Dota used to be a great game, but got worse over the years. The community got worse and worse and I can say that it finally has one of the worst one among all online games. Icefrog(the guy who balances the game) started to add drastic changes(such as 5-6 new items, Aghs upgrades, map changes, huge balance changes) every patch without adjusting them properly.   Balanced changes has been poor lately, leading to 3-4 extremely overpowered heroes you'll see in every game that will get nerfed into oblivion in the next patch and be irrelevant for at least a year, and 5-10 unplayably weak ones you'll almost never see. The new items Icefrog has added in the last year has been too strong before their eventual nerfs in the next patch, which led them being built in every game by at least 5-6 people.   Also, in the second half of 2014(aka post TI4), a comeback mechanic has been added, and it broke the game. Dota has been balanced around early agression, while maintaining late game strategies viable. Comeback mechanic ruined it just because a vocal part of the community(*cough*reddit*cough*) complained so hard about TI4 finals and having no chances of winning after literally getting destroyed early. It has been nerfed, but it's still there. Many aspects that broke the fundementals of the game(destroying cost efficency, nerfing every damage item etc) has also been added.  I think Icefrog wanted to make Dota more enjoyable to watch, but made it more boring to play in the end. I've started playing the original Dota in 2010, and have been playing this game for years(you can see how many hours I've played this game) and I've been very passionate about it. I've stopped playing it like 2 weeks ago, and my friend who played it for like 10 years(more than some professional players) did the same. I feel like Dota is not the game I played with lots of fun years ago, and the enjoyment I get out of it is not even close.

Dota 2 is unlike anything you've ever played before. The first thing that blows me away is the fact that every game lasts anywhere from 30-60 minutes. You'd better hope none of your 4 teammates have social lives, because if only 1 of them disconnects, you get to experience the thrills of being farmed, butchered, and roasted for the remainder of the match.  Another captivating facet of Dota 2 is the player cards that randomly drop as 'rewards' for playing matches. Rather than getting in-game items for your heroes, you get to ogle over some of most l33t pr0 g4m3rz Dota 2 has to offer. Each player card not only tells you the name, age, and preferred heroes of all the pros, it also shows you a mugshot of their stunned face as they get exposed to light for the first time in their lives.  Challenge appeals to many gamers, and most would agree that a well-practiced human opponent is the toughest thing you'll ever face. In Dota 2, that's not the case. Enter bots, Dota's way to get rid of as many newbies as possible right off the bat. If you're new to a competitive, online game, what do you do first? Most people would start by training with bots so as not to make fools of themselves against the real deal. Sadly, starting out against ai is the worst mistake you'll ever make. Even on the 'easy' difficulty, noobs will be double-teamed, pwned, and danced on by the bot zergs before they can allocate those skill points.  Lastly, Dota 2 offers surprises on every menu. Crashing to desktop when I'm trying to read up on different heroes in the included library feature always manages to keep me on my toes. The micro transaction store loads so slowly you'd think they wanted to keep all their items for themselves. The tutorials are really helpful, that is until you reach the final section and aren't allowed to finish after dedicating hours of work on all the previous tasks because the last mission is bugged.  All in all, Dota 2 is a very fun, competitive game that has something for everyone. I highly recommend it!

As a dota (1) player, I'd say dota2 is quite a satisfying version of its ancestor.   The servers are pretty good (at least in AU I usually have 30ms -ping after rebirth). In addition to its wonderful graphics and cool hero designs (not pretty sure about female heroes, ss and wk though...), the gaming experience becomes extremely smooth with the introduction of numerous convenient functions, such as voice chat and alt click (informing your teammates of HP, mana, exp, lv, runes, items, time...). They give us more freedom to focus on controlling the heroes and using their skills, with a higher level of execution within the team. You probably wanna play this game to understand what I'm trying to say. It's free to play anyway. You can have so much fun playing normal games with your friends, or play ranked if you want to go competitive.  The community is awesome. Custom games and fan-made 'skins' are positive bonuses to the original game.  Yet still there are things that can be improved. I've met several players who intentionally ignore their own responsibilities as a team member, either feeding without communication or filling our ears with malicious insults. It's so frustrating to see your team losing a winnable game due to some childish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ especially in a ranked game. I've realized these people don't really get punished after being reported for at least three times and can still turn up on your loading screen every now and then. I guess for now the only way to avoid those players is to disconnect before everybody gets in, if luckily you are not the last one who connects into the game and these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ don't change their names very often.  In recent patches new heroes, items and skills have been added to the game (and some old skills and items were changed). It's common that a hero can become relatively imbalanced after a patch's release then quickly gets nerfed in the next patch. Perhaps it's better for the developers to put in more consideration before implementing new changes, although I understand this game has almost infinite possibilities. + Probably the deepest, most complex MOBA there is + Massive cast of heroes with huge variety and each with a very unique playstyle + 100% free, all heroes available, no pay-to-win, microtransactions are cosmetic only, and there are endless ways to pimp out your heroes, HUD, announcer and more.  PROTIP:  most people know this but if you are looking to buy items check the Marketplace, you can buy from other players usually much cheaper than from the official store. + Despite only 1 official map, every game feels totally different due to endless combinations of heroes and builds + Devs put a lot of effort into balancing, updates are very frequent + Active and talented modding community, tons of fun, crazy custom game modes to play + Tons of servers available including South Africa and SEA + Tons of settings to tweak in terms of controls and HUD options so you can play exactly how you want- a big deal in a game where technical skill and response time is very important  ~ Won't be a concern for most people but the AI for computer-controlled bots is really terrible, and they play nothing like actual humans. Unless you're learning the very basics of the game practicing against bots will actually teach bad habits and adversely affect your skill. ~ LAN play is supported, however you still need to have an internet connection to launch the game ~ Personally, I feel that although the variety of cosmetic items is nice, many of the more expensive items have really flashy, over the top particle effects that can make already visually cluttered teamfights very hard to follow. As of this review there is no option to disable custom cosmetics.  - (In it's current state) very little rubber-banding or comeback mechanics. Unless all players are exactly equal in skill, once one team starts winning they will continue to snowball to inevitable victory, and playing from behind in DOTA is one of the most painful and frustrating experiences in videogames - Extremely steep learning curve, not to mention the game is constantly changing, coming back after a month almost feels like playing an entirely different game - Like most online games, the community is absolute cancer - Like most online games, playing alone is absolute cancer   WARNING: Personal sob-story ahead. There was a time when I was so addicted to DOTA that I neglected my studies, social life, my health, pretty much everything else. It ultimately culminated in a bit of a breakdown, and since then I only play when my friends get together for a LAN. Now, I obviously don't blame all my problems on the game, there were a lot of factors that led me to that point in my life, but DOTA was definitely a big one. Not everyone will get hooked like I did, but I do think the game is inherently quite addictive. Due to the very high skill ceiling, you want to keep learning and getting better, and it's very satisfying when you win, but very discouraging when you lose. You'll keep coming back no matter how many times it beats you down because that high from pulling off a close victory is really exhilarating. Those of you who have played Dark Souls know what I mean. The difference with DOTA is that you'll never actually beat the game- there is no final boss, just the next match, and the next match, and the next. Anyway, just something to keep in mind.    TLDR:  It's the definitive MOBA experience, but not for the faint-hearted. An extremely technical game. Would only reccommend if you have some friends to LAN with, it's free at least.

I remember, about a year ago I was handed a beta key to this game. I played a few times, although I remember my first game of Dota 2, in bots. I didn't really know what I was doing, however I still enjoyed it. I put it away for a while, and about 3 or 4 months ago I picked the game up again due to fascination for the game yet again. I noticed immense changes, and across the time I have been playing, I noticed more improvements since I started a year ago. All I can honestly praise about the game is the time and dedication put into this game by Valve. If you have ever played a Valve game (TF2, Portal, Half-Life), this game is made with the same quality and care, with over a hundred heroes to play, each have their own amazing model, animations, cosmetics and voice-lines and lore. This game has a somewhat great community (I say somewhat because of the constant game-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who love to ruin my games), and Valve takes input from it. Each hero has their own respective playstyle, such as micro-management, and you can change the way you play with each hero by skilling them different, or building items differently then you normally would, thus creating new ways to play your hero and adjust to each situation. I most definitally recommend this game only because of the infinite enjoyment that this game bears, even if you lose, you can get better and learn from it.

Vg icon.svg  Part of a series on:   Video games    Platforms[show]                  Genres[show]                 Related[show]            Development[show]             v ·   t ·   e    A video game is an electronic game that involves human interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a video device such as a TV screen or computer monitor. The word video in video game traditionally referred to a raster display device, but in the 2000s, it implies any type of display device that can produce two- or three-dimensional images. Video games are sometimes believed to be a form of art, but this designation is controversial.  The electronic systems used to play video games are known as platforms; examples of these are personal computers and video game consoles. These platforms range from large mainframe computers to small handheld computing devices. Specialized video games such as arcade games, in which the video game components are housed in a large, coin-operated chassis, while common in the 1980s, have gradually declined in use due to the widespread availability of affordable home video game devices (e.g., PlayStation 4 and Xbox One) and video games on desktop and laptop computers and smartphones.  The input device used for games, the game controller, varies across platforms. Common controllers include gamepads, mouses, keyboards, joysticks, the touchscreens of mobile devices and buttons. Players typically view the game on a video screen or television and there are often game sounds from loudspeakers. Some games in the 2000s include haptic, vibration-creating effects or force feedback peripherals. In the 2010s, the video game industry is of increasing commercial importance, with growth driven particularly by the emerging Asian markets and mobile games. As of 2015, video games generated sales of USD 74 billion annually worldwide, and were the third-largest segment in the U.S. entertainment market, behind broadcast and cable TV.    Contents [hide]  1 History 2 Overview 2.1 Platforms 2.2 Genres 2.3 Classifications 2.3.1 Casual games 2.3.2 Serious games  2.4 Educational games  3 Development 3.1 Downloadable content 3.2 Modifications 3.3 Cheating 3.4 Glitches 3.5 Easter eggs  4 Theory 5 Emulation 6 Social aspects 6.1 Demographics 6.2 Culture 6.3 Multiplayer 6.4 Behavioral effects 6.5 Objections to video games  7 Ratings and censorship 7.1 ESRB 7.2 PEGI 7.3 Germany: BPjM and USK  8 Commercial aspects 8.1 Game sales 8.2 Conventions  9 Museums 10 See also 11 Notes 12 References 13 External links   History  Main article: History of video games  See also: Early history of video games       Tennis for Two, an early analog computer game that used an oscilloscope for a display Early games used interactive electronic devices with various display formats. The earliest example is from 1947—a 'Cathode ray tube Amusement Device' was filed for a patent on 25 January 1947, by Thomas T. Goldsmith Jr. and Estle Ray Mann, and issued on 14 December 1948, as U.S. Patent 2455992.[1] Inspired by radar display tech, it consisted of an analog device that allowed a user to control a vector-drawn dot on the screen to simulate a missile being fired at targets, which were drawings fixed to the screen.[2]  Other early examples include: The Nimrod computer at the 1951 Festival of Britain OXO a tic-tac-toe Computer game by Alexander S. Douglas for the EDSAC in 1952 Tennis for Two, an electronic interactive game engineered by William Higinbotham in 1958 Spacewar!, written by MIT students Martin Graetz, Steve Russell, and Wayne Wiitanen's on a DEC PDP-1 computer in 1961. Pong, a 1972 game by Atari.  Each game used different means of display: NIMROD used a panel of lights to play the game of Nim,[3] OXO used a graphical display to play tic-tac-toe[4] Tennis for Two used an oscilloscope to display a side view of a tennis court,[2] and Spacewar! used the DEC PDP-1's vector display to have two spaceships battle each other.[5]        Nolan Bushnell at the Game Developers Conference in 2011 In 1971, Computer Space, created by Nolan Bushnell and Ted Dabney, was the first commercially sold, coin-operated video game. It used a black-and-white television for its display, and the computer system was made of 74 series TTL chips.[6] The game was featured in the 1973 science fiction film Soylent Green. Computer Space was followed in 1972 by the Magnavox Odyssey, the first home console. Modeled after a late 1960s prototype console developed by Ralph H. Baer called the 'Brown Box', it also used a standard television.[2][7] These were followed by two versions of Atari's Pong; an arcade version in 1972 and a home version in 1975 that dramatically increased video game popularity.[8] The commercial success of Pong led numerous other companies to develop Pong clones and their own systems, spawning the video game industry.[9]  A flood of Pong clones eventually led to the video game crash of 1977, which came to an end with the mainstream success of Taito's 1978 shooter game Space Invaders,[10] marking the beginning of the golden age of arcade video games and inspiring dozens of manufacturers to enter the market.[10][11] The game inspired arcade machines to become prevalent in mainstream locations such as shopping malls, traditional storefronts, restaurants, and convenience stores.[12] The game also became the subject of numerous articles and stories on television and in newspapers and magazines, establishing video gaming as a rapidly growing mainstream hobby.[13][14] Space Invaders was soon licensed for the Atari VCS (later known as Atari 2600), becoming the first 'killer app' and quadrupling the console's sales.[15] This helped Atari recover from their earlier losses,[16] and in turn the Atari VCS revived the home video game market during the second generation of consoles, up until the North American video game crash of 1983.[17] The home video game industry was revitalized shortly afterwards by the widespread success of the Nintendo Entertainment System,[18] which marked a shift in the dominance of the video game industry from the United States to Japan during the third generation of consoles.[19]  Overview  Platforms  See also: History of video games        Different video game consoles from left to right: Sega Dreamcast, PlayStation 2, Nintendo Gamecube, and Xbox The term 'platform' refers to the specific combination of electronic components or computer hardware which, in conjunction with software, allows a video game to operate.[20] The term 'system' is also commonly used. The distinctions below are not always clear and there may be games that bridge one or more platforms. In addition to personal computers, there are other devices which have the ability to play games but are not dedicated video game machines, such as smartphones, PDAs and graphing calculators. In common use a 'PC game' refers to a form of media that involves a player interacting with a personal computer connected to a video monitor. Dota 2.  Dota 2 is a MOBA (Massive Online Battle Arena) similar to games such as League of Legends and Heroes of the Storm. In this, you pick from a slowly increasing pool of 100+ characters, called heroes, and wage battles against other people online.  The combat comprises of mostly right-clicking and spamming your abilities, which have diverse effects (and cool animations). It requires split second decision making, quick reaction time, and a good chunk of math. Though this sounds bad, you quickly learn the approximations, and you require less time for said math.  Now onto the worst of it. The players. How do describe the Dota 2 community? Toxic. Expect to go into every match with people complaining about the game, flaming you for your mistakes, and being complete jerks. People here are quite egotistical and believe they are amazing at the game, when in reality, they are just as bad as the rest of the team. So please, do us all a favour, and NOT flame others. If you have anything positive to share, do so. If not, it may be best to simply keep quiet, as flaming your team leads them to play worse.  Why should you play the game? In all honesty, don't. It'll most likely consume your time and fill you with hate and rage. However, if you manage not to be affected as such, or find a nice group of friends to constantly play with, it's actually quite a pleasant experience.  Cool 5 v 5 battles, with all the animations and visual effects flying across the screen. The perfect ability at the perfect time, winning your team the entire game. Surviving what seems like a fatal attack from your opponents. And the most amazing moment of all, when your team has been losing the entire game, it seems hopeless, it seems like a loss, but somehow you manage to win that one fight, which leads to winning another, and another, till you eventually comeback, and WIN the game. Truly amazing.    Cons: 1) Steep learning curve: This game will take you 800 hours just to get decent. 2) (Very) Toxic community. 3) Difficult. 4) Time-consuming. 5) Feels like hell at some points. 6) Team-based.   Pros: 1) Strategic. 2) Amazing with friends. 3) Filled with amazing moments. 4) Team-based. 5) Not Pay-to-Win: The only items you can buy are purely cosmetic. 6) Never gets boring.   Tips: 1) Don't play ranked till you're about 800 hours in. Doing so will give you your rank when you fully understand the game, meaning your rank will be higher than it otherwise would be. 2) Mute everyone. If your teammates are in the slightest bit toxic mute them. Do not respond. Do not tell them you are muting them. Simply mute them, and continue playing the game. 3) Spend time watching professional matches and guides to improve your gameplay. 4) Don't believe you're in the right. Doubt yourself. Claiming you know everything will prevent you from improving. Learn from your mistakes. Even if it truly was your team's fault, find a way to blame yourself. To improve. 5) Remember, it's a game. Don't get angry. 6) Take a break every once-in-a-while. Go read a book. Do some exercise. Anything but staying glued to a screen. 7) Enjoy.

Before you get discouraged by the people saying 'DotA is a waste of time'... there's more to it!  The great thing about this game is that they've added custom map support. If you don't enjoy the typical MOBA genre - go play the custom stuff! By the gods, they've remade Castle Fight and Legion TD - maps that I've played with friends back in ye olde Warcraft III days.  Yes, grinding ELO, getting angry at your teammates and losing matches can get frustrating and seem like a waste of time. But DotA2 gives a lot of opportunities to play a whole lot of different stuff with friends you can't interract with physically anymore (because you/they moved f.e.). And in my opinion playing a nice Tower Defense map with someone while in a voice-chat call is more fun than just chatting.

Huge learning curve. Big skill curve too. Good game if you like competitive games, bad game if you don't like them. First starting out? Prepare to be flamed at. Playing for a while? Learning literally every aspect of the game that you can and practice what you learn. For example tread switching, or pulling creeps, or ultra strict time utilization. Once you start learning and practicing, then ultimately getting better, Dota will be enjoyable. Before then, this game sucks cuz you'll be a noob <3 10/10 would recommend  P.S. Playing this game will infuriate you. Watching someone play this game even more so. But at the end of the day it will all be worth it. Something with this level of depth requires commitment and when it goes all so wrong because some potato thought it was a good idea to go it alone... You might want to stockpile on spare screens just in case.  There are others like it out there but they forgo some of the little things that are the defining traits for this game. Its like playing Jenga with 3 levels instead of 12. Sure, it might be less draggy and less demoralising but the ups just don't match up here.   If you want a game to truly test your mental capacity to stay cool, to think under pressure and ultimately corral a herd of 4 potential world beaters from becoming 4 tasty drumsticks for the other team, look nowhere else.

This game was once highly favored by me (Hence over 2000 hours), but now it is a mere pass-time. Hear me out on why I would not necessarily recommend this game before you go replying to this.  (To save time, skip to last paragraph. For more details, read through.)  Dota: Reborn made similar custom games as Warcraft III, which was a good move for 'Reborn' and custom game fans. This game still has major/minor glitches that have not been catered to for years, as well as new annoying glitches per update that need attendance. This will never go away, don't wait for it. Items won't work when clicked, broken items on ability draft will ruin entire games, your player will turn and commit suicide when you are clearly clicking the opposite direction, the game delays even if you have an amazing ping which ultimately will get you killed, etc...   Remember, don't take my word for any of this, just google it. You’de think a near billion dollar grossing annual average to a game would get developers interested in fixing these constant bugs. Maybe they have other incentives.  A large portion of custom game time hours are spent in a menu waiting, or failing game starts. On regular play, you are forced to play entire 30 - 75 minute games, which will make a 'fair game' totally worth it. Problem is, around 5-15% (MAX) of games are the fair games, and the rest are entirely abandon worthy. Maybe this is how they suck people in. By using gambling strategy to get people to click a button and wait for the 5 - 15% chance of having a good game.   What is a fair game? Most of the time, you want to abandon a game due to the above glitches. Another would be being matched with adolescent troll children from the hills of a third world who constantly throw games because they can't click a button for the life of them. The other is hackers scripting (google/youtube it), which make the game practically impossible to win or lose depending who's side they are on. Finally, another reason is just bad judgement by Dota on teams matched by statistics. I have literally checked this out by viewing all the statistics from both teams before a match. I saw several games with complete imbalances between levels, lifetime stats, and last 20 games stats. Instead of fixing the imbalance, Dota just recently decided to block me (and whomever else) from viewing these statistics now. I can only view the stats of the first player I click on per game, leaving the rest blank. There is also nothing on this subject yet on google. This way they probably lessen the early abandons, and waste even more time for players.  Why can't you quit (abandon) a game before investing 30 - 75 minutes of your life in a troll filled game? If you try quitting a game, you will be placed in low priority. Why is this a big deal? An 'abandon' is guaranteed you have to win your next game or so in order to get out of it. This low priority is horrible because you are stuck with another set of hills children but with a longer game wait under 'single draft.' Single draft is being forced to play 1 of 3 characters out of around 110 possible. Which means another set of imbalances based on luck of the draw gambling techniques, and now you can repeat the abandon and start the circle over again with more games piled in low priority. YEAAAAY!  So I'm just going to say that although 'Dota: Reborn' has some amazing challenges and fun times with friends, the weight of faults heavily exceed the fun. This is why I would not recommend it to new players, friends, or family. At the end, only you can decide if a game is worth it. Good luck.

Dota 2 is the spiritual successor to the Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne custom game 'Defense of the Ancients: Allstars,' in which the player controls a single hero unit in a battle to level up, collect loot, and destroy the enemy's structures, all within a typical 30-45-minute experience. Games can be longer or shorter, but typically fall within that window. As the metagame has changed due to content update patches, games have grown shorter over the years, but in the past, Dota was likened to 'World of Warcraft in an hour.' It is an accurate analogy, as the player experiences many traditional RPG elements while competing head-to-head against other players.  Dota 2 is an incredibly complex, strategy-driven, competitive game. With over 100 individual, unique heroes from which to choose, as well as a variety of different game modes to mix up the drafting process, each game is an experience unto itself. No two games will ever be identical.  The one thing standing in the way of most players new to the genre of MOBAs is the unforgiving nature of the game. For better or worse, each mistake a player makes can be critical in the final outcome of the game, especially as the clock ticks on. In a couple of seconds, the entire tide of the game could swing heavily from one team to the other's if even one costly mistake is made. As a result of this, many players have developed a rather distasteful attitude toward others when mistakes are made. A word that is often thrown around is 'toxic,' which isn't inaccurate; the toxicity of the community can be a terrible deterrent to new players, and can actively inhibit growth of the game.  Thankfully, Valve have implemented ways in which to curb these behaviors through punishments dished out to players with nasty attitudes. Each player is given a number of 'reports' per week, which can be issued against other players who have exhibited poor form, rudeness, excessive communication spam, or other infractions, and as a player accrues reports, he or she may face a communication mute or a number of games in the 'low priority' queue, which is sort of like rehabilitation back into society.  While I have spent a lot of time talking about the negative aspects of the game, I want to stress that I have been playing Dota since 2004, and I don't see a stopping point in sight even yet. I am consistently captivated by the dynamic and interesting nature of the game, of each individual game, to offer me a unique, fun, and rewarding trade-off for my time commitment. There are few feelings in gaming as satisfying and enjoyable as coming away from a game with a hard-fought win against other players with good attitudes. It makes the bad stuff seem trivial by comparison.  In addition to the actual gameplay elements explored in this review, Dota 2 is part of the greater Steam Trading community, a collective of games featuring in-game economies and persistent item storage for players through the Steam platform. Even if you don't particularly like the game itself, item trading from player-to-player can be tremendously rewarding and fun, and if you're lucky, you could find yourself with an item worth up to many thousands of dollars.  Of course, with any relatively free market, there will be unsavory and dishonest individuals out there who will not blink an eye before attempting to scam you, rip you off, or otherwise take advantage of you. Thankfully, there are plenty of resources available to new traders, so do your research! In fact, if you need help, don't be afraid to add me directly and fire away. I'm always happy to help.  In conclusion, Dota and Dota 2 are without a doubt the games on which I have spent the most time playing. Each new game brings me a new, exciting experience, and as long as you remind yourself to maintain a positive attitude and resist the urge to treat your fellow player with disrespect, you will agree that it is among the best multiplayer experiences available anywhere.  Learn it, love it, and play on!

Dota 2 is a game that I have a love-hate relationship with. I love meeting random strangers and coordinating to win the game as a team. This is a team game after all. However, with that team factor, some people can be very toxic and unfriendly. But don't let that discourage you from playing this game. Dota 2 is a very complex game that takes a long time to understand. But, the community is very welcoming and friendly to new players for the most part. This game will keep you hooked for a very long time. The game is updated every few months or so with major gameplay changes that keep the game fresh and exciting. I have also spent hundreds of dollars on in-game cosmetics, so if that's your thing we have that too. Overall Dota 2 is a great game that I would reccomend to someone who is willing to take on the challenge. NOTE: Some reviews recently are saying that the new update 7.00 'broke the game.' Most people are complaining about the new HUD and the bugs in the update. Valve always takes feedback from the community and I am sure the HUD will be improved. As for the bugs, I would say that most of the major bugs have been fixed and the rest will be fixed shortly. Dota 2 is very playable at this current moment in time.

Having played 1.400 hours of Dota 2 so far you can imagine I'm a big fan of the game and I love it, so I'm going to talk about the bad things Dota has instead of the good things.... Firstable Dota 2 is EXTREMELY hard to learn and play properly, this is a proble because many players could just leave this game after a couple of matches. Yes, there are some 'Noob-friendly' heroes but I believe that learning and using properly a hero in Dota is the least difficult part of the game. Second bad thing about Dota 2 is MMR; I'm not saying that MMR(Ranked Matchmaking) is broken, doesnt work or things like those, I'm talking mostly about MMR calibration matches. I've played with some players that are actully able to play really well bur are still stuck in 'MMR hell' with avg MMR of 1.5 k MMR. When you are there you are in the worst place you can be in Dota 2 because of the absurd amount of flamers, trolls and trash-talkers.  Well, these are what I think to be the worst problems of this game; but I still strongly suggest to play this game because it's extremely funny and beautiful. REMEMBER: the community isn't just made of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, there is a bright side. I hope this was interesting :)

First things first: No matter what you think of the game or what this review might tell you, GIVE IT A TRY. IT'S FREE. Now then, this is a game I very much enjoy. I'm generally not too much a fan of serious games, I really like just messing around in funny games but this. It's the most serious game I've ever played, and I love it. I can't ever get enough of it, I've already put approx. 700 hours in it and it isn't even *fully* made yet (still heroes to be added, etc.) It's a very hard game to get started with and don't expect any help from the community, they'll just call you an idiot that should uninstall the game. However, recently tutorials were added so you can at least get the idea, but you'll still be bad. This is ok. Deal with it and try to learn step-by-step, insult-by-insult, and when you're finally a decent player, you're never going to quit it again. You'll keep on playing and you won't be able to get enough of the game.

Two space crocodiles have landed on Earth, The Crocodile of Lettuce and The Crocodile of Poprocks, your job is to get down in the trenches and defend them to your last breath. Explore a beautiful map, full of hostile creatures, hills, and pathing errors, defeat your opposing crocodile by destroying their fireball ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and breaking down their recruitment centers for the murderously inclined. Choose from over 20 unique beings, all of whom have a stake in this teeth-bared, no-holds-barred beatdown, ranging from lost loved ones, to stolen pride, to even homosexual subtext between a man and a fish. Destroy countless creatures just minding their own business in the forest so you can steal the money hidden in their money bladders, walk through rivers that occasianally have various flavors of candy appear in them, or even fight the deadly Roshan, guardian of the Immortal Taco Plate!

I can't recommend this game for one simple reason.  The community.  Being from Europe,and playing TF2 for most of my time,I can expect a few people not knowing english.But a full team of 5 with 100+ hours that can simply only say ''no eng'' is really a blow to my faith in humanity. Don't get me wrong,I love this game and it's roots,and deep below I know it is a smart game.But being an RTS gamer,I'd expect deeper planning and more strategy within the team.It's in my muscle memory to find and exploit weaknesses in the opposing teams defense.And I can't take a single base all by myself,while my team is literally banging their heads on the thickest part of the base.  Honestly,this game is too flawed to have a 90/100 from MetaCritic. Also,anyone that says ''IF U PLAY TF2 THEN GO PLAY TF2,DOTO IS 12123123/10 GAEM'' should remember that all these reviews are opinions of hundreds a thousands of people giving their honest review.  Final Score : 6.5/10  Also,I'm not a very thick-skinned person.

Dota 2 overall is a great game. It has a classic MOBA play style with a better community than League of Legends (in my opinion) but that isn't saying the community is great. The community is filled with Smurf accounts (People who are high levels that make new accounts for Win % [for those who didn't know]) trolls and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bag teammates. That is expected from a free game however. Once you get past that bad part of the community you may find a team who is really good and matches eachother and is really professional when you play them. In my opinion of all the popular MOBA games Dota is one of the most balanced and graphically pleasing games. Valve is doing a great job keeping the community active and keeping the game up to date with balances and new heroes. I do hope to see another Game mode added like Wraith Night, that was Fantastic. 10\10 would Dota again.

Very similar to League of Legends. A bit slower, with a tendancy toward longer cooldowns on abilities, this can make poor rotations and mistakes more costly. Also it allows you the ability to deny the other laner, AKA get the last hit on your friendly units in order to deprive the bonus from the opposing laner, making last hitting even more important. Last important difference is the use of courier animals that do your shopping for you, letting a superior player stay in lane indefinately. A very fun game, not superior to League of Legends, but very much equal.

If you value your sanity, do not play this game. You will lose time, your life, and money. Game is great. Community is mostly terrible. Server connection is terrible, you get punished for Valve's fault, and then when another player deserves a punishment, the punishment is so insignificant that they continue their terrible behaviour.  If you can take on a terrible community, go on 30 losing streaks due to team, and not buy a single cosmetic, go for it.  PROS: Great game. Gameplay is difficult, intricate and requires great amount of logic. Some people are nice enough, but it's pretty rare. Winning games is very emotionally rewarding too.  CONS: Community is terrible. Rascism is prevalent, from people screaming at Russians for feeding, to screaming at Peruvians for playing Dota 2. The way Valve deals with its community problems in Dota is terrible. Bad behaviour is often punished so insignificantly that the violator will simply continue, while people who are disconnected due to Valve's terrible server are punished equally to the violators.  Also, this game is amazingly addicting. You can play with your friends all the time, and have no fun (since you kill everything), or go solo. If you win, you want to play another match to feel the satisfaction again, however if you lose, you just say 'one more, one more match then I quit' until you win, and then restart the cycle.   MOBA's in general I find have a terrible community.   10/10 gameplay 2/10 community  Last note: However bad the community is, THIS GAME IS AMAZING TO WATCH OTHERS PLAY. I love this game, I hate playing it, and I love to watch matches.

Every game has its pros and cons, this includes DOTA 2  Pros :- -It is a F2P game which delivers something that most F2Ps don't, as we doubtlessly know most F2P games requires money(mostly in an expensive prices) to advance through the game unlike DOTA 2 , this game requires pure skills, teamwork, team coordination and etc to win a match although you can spend your money on sets and items(if you played well enough, chances for an item to drop increases), remember that it is optional and it doesn't affect the game in any way.The gameplay is repetitive, but it will never get us bored as we will discover different patterns of gameplay as we battle with different opponents and teammates, this will bring us on the edge of our seats(ironically, kek). There is nothing much to say in advance really, the graphics are mesmerising(more of an eye candy to be accurate), the gameplay is fun and addictive despite being in-depth and chellenging as you progresses throughout the game.  Cons :- -Toxicity of most of the member of the dota 2 community, yes.TOXICITY.Although it is irrasional to say this, but it takes a while to level up your dota.  Conclusion :- -I'd recommend this game to anyone who wants an enjoyable gaming experience and competitive environment. Remember to be cautious and matured as you'll be facing angry kids throughout the matches, kek.

Dota 2. I once 'recommended' this game as being way too hard for me to play it.   I was wrong.  This game is...it's hard. Exceptionally Hard for people who are just starting. I barely realized what was wrong with me back then. I did not want to play. I barely tried. I was blinded by stupidity and ignorancy.  This game is full of variables, all of which can add up to an amazing concotion, or an epic failure. It all depends on you to decide which you'll take.  It does take a long time to 'learn the ropes', if you have friends who are good players in Dota 2, ask them for all the help you can, if they are willing to teach and help you, gather all the information you can.   Find your Hero. Melee, Ranged or Magic? Strength, Agility or Wisdom?  If you like MOBAs like LoL or Smite, then you definately have to try this game out. In my opinion, it's way harder than both, but, much more enjoyable.   Losing is a pathway, but not a must!
