Dota 2 is a two player children’s game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.  Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent’s ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.  To add to the pirate flavor, each player also has an eye patch. Wearing these will slightly affect depth perception and add a marginal bit of sport to the shooting.  This game retailed for the somewhat impressive sum of $16 back in 1962. With its huge plastic ships (close to a foot long), giant vinyl play mat, and the eye patches, it may well stand as one of the more overproduced games of the early 1960s. Dota 2.

Dota 2 is the semi-sequel/remake/re-release/evolution of the long-running WarCraft 3 mod Defense of the Ancients, which in itself was based on a custom map for StarCraft called Aeons of Strife. After the release of the original Dota map in 2003, the WarCraft 3 community began producing a long line of Dota spin-offs, sequels and mods (just as Eul, Dota's creator, had used AoS as inspiration for Dota itself), which culminated in the release of DotA: Allstars by Steve 'Guinsoo' Feak.  Allstars would become the most dominant and consistently updated version of all the Dota maps and mods. In 2005, Guinsoo passed the torch to the enigmatic IceFrog, who has been supporting, updating, and shaping Dota ever since. His changes have been the most significant, the most popular (the mod grew more during his time than ever before), and arguably have benefited and enriched Dota as a whole. By 2010, DotA: Allstars became simply DotA, and IceFrog was showing no signs of stopping. Later that year, Dota 2 was formally announced (with its development spear-headed by both IceFrog and Eul, both of its most important 'authors'; its past and present, alike), entered a semi-closed beta in late 2011, and was finally officially released in mid-2013... and the rest is history.  History lessons aside, Dota 2 is a game of uncompromising depth and complexity. Though its gameplay intricacies can appear opaque, arbitrary and incomprehensible at first sight, the way these expansive game mechanics interact with one another when exposed to the element of player imperfection is truly remarkable: over a hundred heroes, each with at least four spell-based abilities and all capable of using up to six magical items, from a massive arsenal of over a hundred. Games can last anywhere from 25 to 55 minutes, and possibly far more!  Dota's metagame is constantly shifting, and as of writing the game and mod are at total parity through version 6.80, released earlier this year. On top of that, it is completely free to play, with no features locked out to any players whatsoever. Not even cosmetic items, which form the backbone of the game's vast micro-transaction-based economy: these items are freely distributed by Valve to all players through level-based gift drops and random-chance item drops. Free game updates alter the game balance significantly, while introducing new seasonal game modes, and far more. And that's not even scratching the surface of the game's competitive scene, with its many tournaments, its constantly evolving teams and its own storylines, all leading up to the annual Valve-organized grand championship: The International.  It may be incredibly difficult and frustrating at first, but given time, patience, simple memory and a keen mind, anyone can ultimately come to see Dota as perhaps the most enjoyable, enthralling and captivating game experience ever conceived. Oh, and it's sort of fun.

And that's not even scratching the surface of the game's competitive scene, with its many tournaments, its constantly evolving teams and its own storylines, all leading up to the annual Valve-organized grand championship: The International.  It may be incredibly difficult and frustrating at first, but given time, patience, simple memory and a keen mind, anyone can ultimately come to see Dota as perhaps the most enjoyable, enthralling and captivating game experience ever conceived. Oh, and it's sort of fun.

So I first reviewed this and found this game really fun. After establishing a little over 1000 hours on this game I have a little more to say:  The game has now a fully developed tutorial that will ease new players in and I wish it was as fully developed when I first started to play. The tutorial goes through the basics and explains essential information to anyone who is new to MMOs or just to Dota .   The hardest thing about playing a game is finding a reason to play. Whether for a great story or for a fun multiplayer. While most of the story in Dota 2 lies behind character bios and annual yearly events most the action is in the multiplayer environment which takes me to the most important topic.  Dota 2 is a challenging game, offering a range of difficult characters and with over 102 characters the game is rarely repetitive. Those who disagree usually are ones who play CoD and shoot other players in the face 24 hours a day 8 days a week... and yes I know my calender. MMOs are a different kind of game and should be taken as such. To be more specific there are 1.701821437811023x10^20 combinations for games. Yeah. That's a LOT of different games and I'm not counting the numerous different play styles and levels of players. Despite how fun I find this game, I have much to critique.  Teammates are rarely supportive and in the early stages of learning the game are very negative and are the number 1 reason why nobody ever comes back to the game. To be more specific the learning curve is very large. Regular updates are nice but for those who have limited internet this will be a hassle.   So in conclusion Dota 2 is a great game, rough to learn but fun to play, and it is bound to last a LOT longer than the Halo 4 campaign. Considering it is free to play I would recommend you try it out. You may just find that you are the next Invoker master... Good luck with that

Dota 2 is an incredible game! This addictive MOBA-style game endorses fun, and is a great outlet for communication. Games like these also help increase your cognitive functions, memory and finger-work (if you play the piano). As for addiction-issues, well, I can only give you this advice: Try not to overplay Dota 2, as it is supremely addicting! Smart, intuitive gameplay, with vast collections of customizable gear your hero can wear, along with in-game chatting and open text-chat, this game is already living up to its standards.  Many people would hate the fact that despite Dota 2's ingenuity, when playing this game, many people would often insult the people performing below standards. Even the report button does not seem to stop these people from telling you off. But here is my advice: Ignore them. What goes around comes around. Dota 2 was not meant to mentally hurt people, it was meant to be an addictive MOBA game that genuinely gives fun to others. I should know, I have been playing for quite some time now.  My recommendation? Play Dota 2! Why shouldn't you? With MOBA-style games dominating the gaming industry, you should not get left behind! With tutorials all ready for beginners (comes with a free set for completing most of the tutorial as a bonus), playing Dota 2 will be as easy as breathing. Or walking for that matter. Play Dota 2!

Oh my god I love this game so much. It is by far one of the most complex games I've seen. It has so many mechanics that you're always learning a new playstyle, a new hero, a new role as a certain hero, what items to get, what abilities work well. The game also never gets boring. Even though you're always just trying to blow up a statue in the end, there's never a stale moment. Well... Barely ever. I'm not gonna lie and say that every aspect about this game is absolutely perfect. In public all pick games, there'll be heroes that are easy to be good with and are picked more than you want them to (Riki, Sniper, Bloodseeker). Also, there will be people that don't speak the same language as you even though you put your preference as english (Я смотрю на Вас, русских). And not everyone that plays this game is nice. At all. While there are more nice people than bitter people in the community, you will encounter really friendly people, and bitter, upright mean people both in game and in real life. But even though alot of this review is not so good things, I guarantee you will not regret playing this game. It's my favorite game and I couldn't recommend it more.

I definitely recommend this game for anyone of those seeking for challenge   BUT   I do not recommend playing the game online. Playing with other people mean that you have to be pro some how.   Any small mistake can get you reported  . I know, I've done it. If you wanna play with other people, make sure you have the ability to resist any offensive words and foul languages. Otherwise, play the game in offline mode, aka with BOTS. OR play with your friends in a LAN party so you know that they wont report you or insult you in any harmful way. The game is cool if you ask me, but like I said, not recommended for extremely sensitive people.

The artstyle and voices are great. Sound effects and textures are awesome. Items are for aesthetical only, so skill is the most important thing. Each heroes had their own uniqueness.  This is the only F2P game where I didn't really enjoy their work. It's totally an unfriendly game for a new players plus extremely toxic community.  If you don't play it with your friends, you can end up with an extreme headache or worst, end up in a nuthouse. You need to play it with friends because it's the only way to enjoy the victory, or suffering, together.  The gameplay can be a little tricky and it can go unbalanced very easily. Sometimes, i prefer to play Warcraft 3 mods or TF2 than playing this game.  This game, as enraging it can be, is also really enjoyable experience. If you want to be constantly surprised by game, developers and other players, and there is inner drive of self-improvement in you; this is it.   Still, for DOTA hardcores or those who brave enough to play this game. Welcome.

I don't know if Icefrog is still the head of developement in dota 2 but the gameplay has been deteriorating since its release. Every patch has something altered in the game instead of just fixing bugs. Old heroes who had the same skills for decades (since dota on Warcraft 3) have been changed and nerfed (Ex. Techie) while new imbalanced heroes are introduced into the game. The map has been completely changed in its first historical alteration in the last patch. They're attempting to bring in features from LoL. Dota 2 is losing more players to LoL. And it's a pity that they are willing to cut originality in order to keep a few douches.   The matchmaking and reporting system is horrendous. If you win a few games then you'll automatically be paired with losers. If you suck a few games, people randomly report you and you end up in the low priority pool. Which is pretty much a penalty. This happens often when you play alone with a four-man team.  It's been over 2-3 years since release and these issues have barely been addressed. They focus more on creating content so it drives money in. The gameplay and nerfing/buffing of heroes has deteriorated the once praised dota experience. It's not worth playing anymore. I know a lot of old school dota players from warcraft 3 that have avoided playing this version.

There's so many reasons why I'd recommend Dota 2, it's one of the few games that will absolutely devour your free time and refuse to let you play much else. Dota takes a good amount of time to get into it and be prepared to be hated and despised by other players while you learn, this is very standard in MOBA's and you should never let it get to you.  I initially played League of Legends for roughly 600-800 hours before Dota 2 and thoroughly enjoyed that but ultimately decided that Dota 2 is newer, fresher and more enjoyable game. Valve are updating this on a weekly basis and some of the heroes are absolutely fantastic in comparison to many of their League counterparts.  Dota 2 is completely free and although it has microtransactions similar to League, all are purely cosmetic and you can actually unlock all the cosmetics without paying anything should you wish. You've got nothing to loose by giving it a go but I'd recommend doing at least 10 or so games before you make your descision to continue playing or not since the game is so complex and in depth. Choose a hero you like the look of, something like Viper, Axe, Lich or Wraith King are good starting heroes and go from there.  If you need any help or just want someone to play with, add me on Steam and I'll help you out :)

I find this game design is too ornate. There are many systems in it which don't support the core of the game, which is 'I work with my team to assault the enemy base in order to destroy the Ancient'.  As this is based on the tower defence genre, last-hitting creeps is a source of income. The bit that's extraneous is last-hitting your own creeps to deny your opponents getting them.  The courier animal system feels extraneous to me.  Other issues include an announcer that makes me feel like I'm a third grader, map legibility issues, and balance issues. By balance I mean that when you die, you get penalized more than is necessary: not only do you lose the time you spend dead, but you lose some of your cash when you die.  I think in creating this game the designers shackled themselves too closely to the old Warcraft III mod, when they should have been finding ways to refine and streamline the game.  It's not that there isn't a game here to be played and learned and enjoyed. But there are far better MOBAs out there.

I've played alot of different mobas (dota, league, smite, strife) and I have to say, dota 2 is one of worst. 90% of the hero roster is ungodly overpowered, and you might say 'If everyone is overpowered, then technically noone is TRULY overpowered.' Well I can assure you that is false. What happens is that if you begin to lose even the slightest amount, the person your losing to becomes god and is almost impossible to defeat. I know people are going to hate me for comparing it to this, but for example, in league of legends, a person can get quite fed, but you can still turn it around if you are good enough. However in this game, there reaches a point where this is physically nothing you can do. Not a damn thing. And you might think that my recommendation sounds like its coming from someone who is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because they lost a bunch of games, but I did win my fair share and it still felt like an overall bad design for this game. The shop is confusing, theres alot of balance issues, the map is difficult to understand where you can and can't go, and it's overall just not a good game.

It's basically League of Legends. Actually, it's the same as League of Legends, but with slightly prettier graphics. Honestly, I didn't enjoy this game. I'm not saying it's a bad game, but MOBA's aren't really my thing. Too slow for me I guess. If you like MOBA's, you may like this. If you like LoL, you will either end up enjoying this yourself or saying 'What the hell? It's the same as League!' I didn't see a whole lot of teamwork when I played. No one seems to speak English. There's also strategy, but it's mostly how you are going to build your guy and what lane you're going to take. That's it really. Overall I thought it was an ok game. I find MOBA's slow and boring, but some people like them. So basically, if you enjoy slow paced games this is for you! If you prefer fast paced games, then you will hate this. Remember, that this is my opinion. The game is free, so try it out to see if you like it or not.

While this game is good for competitive players and has a lot of depth for progression.  The amount of toxic players is insane and completely ruins the game. Even in ranked, it is full of people that enjoy trolling and will do anything to make you mad.   Therefore, I would NOT recommend starting this game, the player base is way too toxic to enjoy it. You may get 1/5 games that you play to be enjoyable with a good team. I will continue to play this as I've invested a lot of time into it and want to improve and hope that the higher rank I get, the less toxic the players are. However, I would not recommend starting this out, as the pain of playing with toxic people is too much.   I would suggest they introduce a stricter policy on toxic players to ensure they cannot continue to flame. Maybe introduce a premium service, where people that are serious about the game can pay a small fee a be bumped into a different version of the game which only has other premium players in it. This would allow the toxic players to be toxic with each other and leave the players that want to improve and play what could be a great game with each other.   Also, add more reporting or reviewing functionalities e.g. 'Was the player a good team mate?' or 'Would you play with them again?'. This will allow the matchmaking system to group together good and helpful team players and allow the other people to be toxic amongst themselves.

The game is nice and hard to learn, but has a steep climb on diffuctlty on many different heroes. Easier ones are the ones most hated such as Sniper, or even Drow (before the recent update, she was a bit easier?). However, with friends and the correct skill to play the game it is beyond worth it because it brings a good amount of fun. Pubs are only fun with friends I seem to find out. MOBA/ARTS games can be very enjoyable, even borderline addictive, after a player has committed enough time to understand the nuances of the game. Oftentimes, a lack of immediate enjoyment prevents a player from sticking to a game long enough to reach that level of competency.  Regardless, Dota 2 remains the quintessential iteration of the genre and Icefrog and Valve continue to refine the formula with subtle-but-meta-shifting updates. Be warned, even compared to other examples of MOBA/ARTS, the game is extremely confusing for a newcomer. The tutorials are underwhelming, and a lot of interactions around heroes' spells and items are never fully explained in-game. Studying outside resources and guides is almost required.  If you can stomach being thoroughly perplexed and mystified for the first thirty or forty hours of gameplay, you will find the depth of gameplay rewarding.

My initial recommendation for this game was negative as a joke, but after hearing the constant whining of 7.00 I had to change it to prevent confusion.  The update did not ruin the game, don't listen to those so-called 'veterans' who claim that it did. I've been playing this game long enough for myself to say that there's little to no error with the recent patch. The HUD is fine, the map design is good, the talents are a neat addition and the new hero is super fun to play with (OP but fun nonetheless). The only issues that I've had so far were a few bugs and AI errors with bot matches, but that's it. They're incredibly minute and not worth your time to complain about. If you have any doubt in mind that this patch will ruin your experience, then forget it. It's all a bunch of lies and deceit.  Give this game a chance and play it. I'm sure you will not regret it.

This review was posted by user 'cylian3' on the metacritic user reviews page on july 7, 2014:  'Never In my entire life have I witnessed a worse community revolving around a video-game than the one that is to be found in Dota 2. The players are: Egotistic, ego centric, unsporting, aggressive, hostile, uncaring, mean, mistrusting, immature, callous, apathetic and incredibly pretentious while at every loss prompting everyone inside the current game to 'Report player X' if someone on their team was even remotely new to the game or did any other action not sanctified by them, be it going in what lane you want, not purchasing courier/wards or simply just had an unlucky run/getting cross-classed. Along with being completely miserable to be around, they frequently never speak the language in the region you're playing and nowhere else is this more apparent when russian is spammed into the chat at all times on European zones from 3 different sources at once. And if people do know English, trolling is nothing short but assured from all directions to all teams.  Second biggest problem with this game would be the elitist mindset that orbits anyone that has played this atrocious game for more than a couple of hours. Any behavior that breaks the typical dota 2's hardcore player routine of buying tango, healing salve and iron branches, perhaps with some boots of speed if they're feeling adventurous will result in a wave of F-bombs, intentional feeding, votes of surrender, spam prompts to report player X and disconnecting users as far as the eye can see. I even had cases where players left the game because some guy forgot to buy a courier at the start of the game. And that's me overlooking the fact that killstealing off your TEAMMATES is considered average behavior/a common tactic. In LoL, you can even report people for 'being unskilled'. As in, anyone. Even if they're level 1.To put it bluntly, MOBA's like dota 2 give out a special kind of disgusting behavior that makes me feel physically ill for very good reasons.  Coming close to problem number 2 is the third epic fail problem of this game. The match-making in Dota 2. Broken, poorly thought through and executed horribly. You are prompted to select a variety of regions before initiating the match-making system and the more regions you have selected, the less waiting time..  Which begs the question, what is the point with the regional system if you're just gonna encourage people to sign up for all regions? The end result will be that nobody sticking to their geographical zones and not only causes frustration in the form of people trying to communicate and chat with eachother in the chat as described above but also disallows any kind of vocal / text tactical communication since everyone does not speak the same language. In all honestly, this game is overloaded with issues just like this and I would be able to overlook this particular embarassing design-flop if it wasn't for the actual hard functionality of the MM as well being broken. The scenario on where 4-5 organized people in a group, all sitting in ventrilo/teamspeak while packing thousands of hours in Dota 2 each have a very likely possibility to be 'teamed' up against new players with less than 10 hours with no complaints from the match-making system (even if there is a very large queue) throws out any chance of that. This happens particulary often if you decide to try the game out with a friend or two which leaves me with yet another question: The purpose of match-making was to find equally skilled opponents. So why is this even remotely possible? Team-based games with a mandatory MM are supposed to be fair. Not Tyrannosaurus rex VS a duckling. I'm reluctant to say that Dota 2 even has a match-making at all once you look at all the facts.  Even with all these problems, I could actually see myself overlooking them at a certain time during a year due to the sheer amount of possible combinations in this game with heroes & items and the addictive quality the game has if it wasn't for all the other flaws.  The commitment to play DotA MOBA's however, is the biggest flaw of them all that this game inhibits. It changes whoever plays the game as a person. For the worse. Why? Because the game inhibits 'addictive' qualities similar with that of jamming needles full with endorphin into your spine every half hour. It's painful, it hurts your emotional stability, it hurts you as a person and it hurts the people around you and for what? A small kick of pleasure/self satisfaction as you managed to win a fundamentally unbalanced game with an emphasis on gank above all else due to chance or otherwise pre-meditated 'pubstomping'? Not worth it in so many ways since at the end of the day, Dota 2 will never be fully balanced because Valve will be split between tournament-balances and casual or the 'normal' version of the game while repeatedly adding more and more content in the form of heroes.  I could keep on going with design flop after design flop but at the end of the day, this game is not worth anyone's time or dedication.'  With all this being said, I fully agree with the opinions articulated by this user and do NOT recommend this game as it is equivalent in an electronic sense to how alcohol and drug abuse would destroy psyches, lives, and families.

I have been playing DOTA since WC3:ROC, I've seen this game evolve from a custom map to a stand alone game reimagined & published by one of the most respected developers around (Valve), and all I can say is this game is more than a game. DOTA is a hero siege style game, one of the original of its kind, it involves heroes struggling to destroy the enemies ancient in teams of 5, whereby heroes have to kill enemy player heroes and npc enemies/buildings in order to win. The game has a steep learning curve and has a community which has always been broad, this is both a good and a bad thing. Mechanics such as 'creeping', 'denying', 'last hitting', 'ganking', item/hero builds, lane arrangments and hero combinations challenge the uninitiated however once you master the details of DOTA you get a rich and highly competitive game. Due to the aforementioned no game of DOTA is the same and you will find yourself interested even despite the core elements of the game remaining unchanged. DOTA 2 brings some unique features such as hero/cosmetic customization and a standardized matchmaking/ranking system, which will keep players coming back. In all, DOTA is a challenging game to learn, and an even more difficult game to master, but it is a game in which players keep coming back, even a decade later. Full recommendation provided you have the patience, and a familiarity with these type of games doesn't hurt to ease the transition (or at least a familiarity with RTS).

Which begs the question, what is the point with the regional system if you're just gonna encourage people to sign up for all regions? The end result will be that nobody sticking to their geographical zones and not only causes frustration in the form of people trying to communicate and chat with eachother in the chat as described above but also disallows any kind of vocal / text tactical communication since everyone does not speak the same language. In all honestly, this game is overloaded with issues just like this and I would be able to overlook this particular embarassing design-flop if it wasn't for the actual hard functionality of the MM as well being broken. The scenario on where 4-5 organized people in a group, all sitting in ventrilo/teamspeak while packing thousands of hours in Dota 2 each have a very likely possibility to be 'teamed' up against new players with less than 10 hours with no complaints from the match-making system (even if there is a very large queue) throws out any chance of that. This happens particulary often if you decide to try the game out with a friend or two which leaves me with yet another question: The purpose of match-making was to find equally skilled opponents. So why is this even remotely possible? Team-based games with a mandatory MM are supposed to be fair. Not Tyrannosaurus rex VS a duckling. I'm reluctant to say that Dota 2 even has a match-making at all once you look at all the facts.  Even with all these problems, I could actually see myself overlooking them at a certain time during a year due to the sheer amount of possible combinations in this game with heroes & items and the addictive quality the game has if it wasn't for all the other flaws.  The commitment to play DotA MOBA's however, is the biggest flaw of them all that this game inhibits. It changes whoever plays the game as a person. For the worse. Why? Because the game inhibits 'addictive' qualities similar with that of jamming needles full with endorphin into your spine every half hour. It's painful, it hurts your emotional stability, it hurts you as a person and it hurts the people around you and for what? A small kick of pleasure/self satisfaction as you managed to win a fundamentally unbalanced game with an emphasis on gank above all else due to chance or otherwise pre-meditated 'pubstomping'? Not worth it in so many ways since at the end of the day, Dota 2 will never be fully balanced because Valve will be split between tournament-balances and casual or the 'normal' version of the game while repeatedly adding more and more content in the form of heroes.  I could keep on going with design flop after design flop but at the end of the day, this game is not worth anyone's time or dedication.'  With all this being said, I fully agree with the opinions articulated by this user and do NOT recommend this game as it is equivalent in an electronic sense to how alcohol and drug abuse would destroy psyches, lives, and families.

Extremely addictive game. Has similar timeless quality to it that chess and go have(and probably many other classic board games), where you continue to study this one setting, one battlefield, and explore different possibilities it offers. For the true experience, you want to have 4 friends to play this with, because all sorts of social conflicts can arise when trying to play a very demanding team game with strangers.  Client is maybe a bit clumsy, with many useful outside-the-game UI elements, such as hero information library, acting sluggishly, making it difficult to look up hero information during a game, but overall it's steady, and offers almost every single feature you could possibly ask for, with actual gameplay being extremely responsive and almost bug-free.  Since Dota 2 has direct competition with LoL, HoN, and some other games that are based upon very similar setting(5v5 wizard deathmatch), I feel I should mention the main thing I feel Dota 2 has going for it, that it does better than the competition, and that's character selection. Heroes, as they are called in Dota 2, are varied, each offering their own set of possible playstyles, and each of them having personality through artwork and multiple voice responses. When you are playing Axe, it's difficult to not get excited and just jump deep behind enemy lines because of just how manly he and his skillset is. Then again, with the cunning Invoker, you spam myriards of spells at the enemies behind allied support all the while Invoker makes obnoxious, snarky remarks about heroes he's squashing. The best I can tell, heroes don't really have intended item or skill builds, you are free to play them as you see fit. Game offers you guides and by default offers you a good suggested items for each stage of the game, but this is merely to help new players get into the game, not the final word on how the hero should be played. This kind of freedom is often cited as the reason for migrating from other similar games to Dota 2.  All in all, if chess was a 5v5 game, played with modern computers and had hats in it, that would be Dota 2. Some people like that, some don't, and everyone hates the community surrounding it, but grab a bunch of friends and give it a try.

The most traditional Moba around, no fancy shmancy summoner spells, masteries, rune pages and such. All Heroes are free by default, you get some nice and basic tutorials and off you go. There are multiple official gamemodes to play, but also many mods to try. The regular game is 5v5 on a three lane map with multiple shops, of which two are secret shops for special items (the shops are not really hidden), two runes, which grant special boni when colected and respawn at set times, a forest full of creep camps and a pit with a mighty bossmonster, Roshan, who grants a Aegis when killed. The Aegis is used to reincarnate if you should die within about six minutes after Roshan is killed. The regular mechanics are similar to other Mobas, farming, shopping, leveling, skilling and pushing. There are some advanced mechanics like denying and stacking though. There is much more to tell about the game, but I am a lazy dude. You should definitely give it a try.

4 years ago - cosmetics will never go any further than basic weaponry; sword, helmets etc. 3 years ago - cosmetics can be pretty much anything, but adhere to colour schemes and lore; pirate leg kunkka, tide squid etc. 2 years ago - colour schemes, lore or even basic models need not to be adhered to; nyx is the prime example of this. Silencer had to get a recolour because he looked like DK, but nyx now gets a SK theme, difference between the situations? Once money was being made, that rule went flying out of the window. 1 year ago - cosmetics now apply to pretty much anything; camera wards, cat drow, skateboarding phoenix, rowing rabbits, pig techies, ♥♥♥♥it, anything goes, rest assured, cosmetics will never effect gameplay though. Now - Cosmetic has an entire event that will impact gameplay.  Ads after loading the game (the 'news' page usually advertises new items) Ads when choosing a game mode (special items for things like Wraith Night and Diretide) Ads when choosing a character (the game shows which sets are available, and how much they cost) Pseudo ads while respawning (the death info screen advertises what items the killing hero is using). And now we have ads at the start of the match as well. The future looks ugly. I hate ads.  People here make fun of LoL and their ludicrous microtransaction system, yet every year we are getting closer to what LoL is doing.

Dota 2 is a real-time strategy game in the sub-genre called MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena). It is a direct sequel to the popular Warcraft 3 Modification. This game has been picked up by Valve corporations and is being worked on by none other than one of the original creators of the Warcraft 3 Modification. After its official launch on the 9th July 2013 it has been a massive hit in the MOBA genre. With it being the number one game on the free to play list on steam and arguably being on par with the largest contender on the MOBA market - League Of Legends.   The game corporates a large roster of playable heroes which are instantly available with gameplay which can offer ten times the amount of strategy and depth compared to any other game on the MOBA market. This combined with players who are working on the game for other players and the fact that the game is trademarked by steam. Dota 2 also has a large competitive scene including the annual “The International Tournament” held by steam.  I totally recommend Dota 2 to anyone with a computer. The ability to play casually or professionally with your friends really is awesome! xD 94/100 -Dom

First, id like say that dota is a fun game. I enjoy the game play very mutch. The variety of playstyles and characters means that there is more than one for each person. However, the penalty from not accepting a match is just overkill. Now, i understand that not everyone can just say 'it was lag' or 'my computer froze' and some punishment IS good. However it is common that in a que that is taking a long time, people will do other things outside of dota and entireley fprget about dota. Sure you can read the bio of EVERY character two times over since you can still accept when viewing the library but there is very little to do in dota to keep your mind off the que (unless you want the highscore in that SUPER fun minigame in witch you drag items in to make a certain recipe). So far, ive only seen a 24 hour ban from matchmaking due to forgetting to accept. That is WAY too mutch time away from dtoa. 24 hours of LP is ok as a max punishment, but being entirely BANNED from matchmaking for a whole DAY is crazy. maybe 8 hours top so that way you can actually play within the day or wake up to dota in the morning. Low priorty is entirely fair (Although it should cap at like 10-12). Still dota is a fun game and i'd reccomend it.

All I could say is that the game is very good and very polished, the gameplay itself is what makes it special. Even thought the game itself only have one map, it will never get old as no matter what each game you play will always have a different feel in it. Unlike some MOBAs, this game will provide everyone a full access of the different heroes that are available, therefore people are able to use different strategies to win the game without paying a dime. The only problem of the game is that it is difficult for new players, even though there is a tutorial which tells the basics, it isn't very reliable for new players because it only explains that fundamentals of the game. Another problem is the community itself, unlike other MOBAs, this game is more punishing and it isn't suitable for every new players. Many people who played the game tend to be very sensitive and they will bring negativity to other players who are mostly because they are playing bad. Each game has an average of 30 minutes to an hour. Whenever the game ends, players will have a chance to receive a item. The items themselves is quite random which people might like and people might not like. Overall the game is good but very difficult to new players. My suggestion is watch PurgeGamer who is a youtuber, he upload videos that might help you in understanding the game further.

The Sequel to Defense of The Ancients (DOTA) which is what one could call the grandfather of what people now call a Moba.   Gameplay is team oriented, obviously... but, most abilities that heroes have are also unique interesting not to mention the fact that a lot of them have impact in the game.  Some ultimates can more or less win you a fight or even the game... and you'll usually -feel- the power in your abilities. It is very, very satisfying in my personal opinion.  You will feel like you're useful to your team. Many of the great looking, devastating spells belong to the supports.   Sound and Music The music is not, in my opinion, bad.. although it may need a bit more variation. The sound of your abilities will largely be satisfying.. if you slam into the earth, you will -hear it-.. and you will -feel- it. Some sound effects can be replaced by items you can buy, however.  Customization: Sound effects can be replaced here and there, as said. And most heroes can use custom items to change their appearence.  Possible turn-offs:  The Vast amount of time each game can take (usually ~50 minutes or more)  The Community which sometimes can be very, very toxic and harsh especially if you're new but, there can be ways around a lot of it (Will give tips under this section)  The Difficulty which for some may be a bit too high.. at first anyway.   Your Personal Preference.. I do not know what you dislike or enjoy and dota 2 is a very different game once you go from being new and stressed to relaxed and enjoying yourself as you know what to do a bit more.   Tips for Fresh blood; Videos and Streams can be helpful and entertaining if you find a personality you enjoy watching and listening to.   Play against bots at first.. it will not be ranked and a lot of fresh blood use these games to learn new heroes, the game itself and more. It may also help if you're afraid of playing against other players.  It may be intimidating at first but, once you get relaxed and can enjoy the game (even if a team-mate is being annoying/mean or you are losing) the game becomes a lot more fun.  If you join a game with other players, state the fact that you're new! A lot of people have respect for this. Yes, a lot of people will ignore this fact and be rude or blame you anyway but, chances are higher that your team will be understanding and explain how things work.  There are guides online and videos made specifically for new players.  The games can drag on, try to play when you know you have the time ^.^  And, I know this is cliché but... -enjoy yourself-! There will be times when you will be frustrated but, playing should at least in my opinion not be a chore. Play when you feel like it!   And of course, be nice to other people even if it's online. Not only can this mean you get in-game friends.. it also means that you, your team and sometimes even the enemy team enjoy yourselves more and even play better (if you're rude to the enemy, they may try to win even harder. Just so you know ~ ).  Thank you for reading ! I re-wrote my small review into this over a small amount of time so, there will be a few things missing most likely but, hopefully someone found this useful <3  I've written some more detailed stuff about mechanics and gameplay below if you want to read it but, as said, there are videos and guides that state what I'll say and more ^.^  Good Luck, Have Fun!  Some more information about gameplay and mechanics below, beware!   The gameplay depends on your role( Core or Support) but, the vast majority of Dota 2 consists of farming in a lane or in the case of supports, making sure the core will be able to gain the money he or she needs.  A support will need experience just like the Core will so that he or she can use their abilities proper and secure the game for their team but, Cores usually need more gold than a Support would in order to properly fulfill their role in the game.  All roles are important however, supports are needed as they will ward (Provide vision for your team) and purchase a courier ( a slave-like being which brings your items to you and your carry! Fancy, no?)   Supports buy these as they are, as stated, not as reliant on gold as the Cores but still needed to make sure you, your lane partner and your team will not die horribly or otherwise come behind your foes.  Now, Cores. Cores need a lot of gold but, to make up for this these heroes are made so that when they do get the items they need they will be able to do a lot in a game. A really good carry can more or less secure a game for a team once they have their items, assuming the enemy team's not able to counter him or her. (A job for the supports, making sure the Core you've fed gold doesn't die early if possible ^.^) However, playing a Core may be harder than playing a support in the end.. and if you play wrong as a Core you could lose your team the game even if you were ahead.   There are three paths on the map also known as lanes, Top(Also known as ¨Offlane¨), Middle and of course Bottom(Also known as ¨Safelane¨) There are two towers on all the lanes until you reach the enemy base which has a single tower and two barracks (buildings that, when killed, makes your npcs stronger.)   Beyond the Barracks you have the Fountain, defended by two towers and the enemy team. If you kill this building, you win the game! Each building gives gold however so, sometimes you may want to kill the towers and barracks in other lanes before going for the finalé. Gold and of course a safety measure in case something bad happens as the base will be defended viciously.  Top is used either by a single offlane hero (this is so that that hero will gain experience quicker.) the heroes that get to go in this lane alone is heroes that you're sure won't die easily if the enemy wants your offlaner dead. (Example; Timbersaw has an ability that gives him more armor, making him less likely to die generally speaking.)  If you want a solo top you will need to have three heroes in the Safe lane to make the process for your Hard Carry (A type of Core hero) or a hero in the jungle.  Middle is generally used by heroes that, like the offlane, can do a lot with more experience early on and or are capable of ¨Ganking¨ your enemy heroes with some early levels, aka helping out other lanes by killing the enemy heroes.   Bottom (Safe lane) Should have a Hard Carry (A hero that can do a -ton- later on if they get good items) and a support. The support will make sure his or her partner will most of all gain gold from farming but, will also make sure the Hard Carry dies as little as possible or even kill some of the enemy heroes in your lane (giving you and him/her experience and gold and making your enemy lose gold.)   Sometimes there can be two supports bottom to support your Carry if you want a solo hero top, use your numbers to your advantage in that case. Experience is shared around the killed hero/enemy npc and as such, if you're three, you gain less experience! So, more farming, more supporting and preferably also more possible kills!  Besides farming Supports (and to a lesser degree Cores/Carries) should also try to deny your -friendly- npc's if they get low. If you kill them, your enemy does not recieve the gold nor the same amount of xp.  Beyond farming, aka killing enemy minions or monsters in the jungle for items to help you win against your enemy in upcoming battles the gameplay also consists of what Imentioned earlier; Fights and ganking.  Sometimes you alone, you and your laning partner or maybe your entire team will try to kill the enemy heroes in an effort to gain the upper-hand over the enemy team.   Ganking is more or less surprise attacks, assassinations (usually provided by your team's middle lane hero) which helps you kill Heroes, towers or simply farming without the enemy team pestering you as much.

I've stopped playing LoL for a few months now, and I decided to play Dota for a change, without watching any gameplay video to make sure I'd like this game. The client itself is great to be honest, then you dive into a guide that wouldn't let you go off tracks and keep going. No way to buy anything that wasn't advised, the game pauses to tell me I'm getting hit by creeps in the center of the screen, that was obnoxious. Then, after around 10 pop-ups that made me groan, I finally destroy the tower and the tutorial is over. Then, the game advises me to play a full game against bots, in which I find out too late that the 'back' button I'd have found in LoL isn't here. That's right, you need to walk, and so I did after a long sigh. One more pop-up, and this time there's no button to close it, and the game is paused of course. I left the training game because of this bug, but to be honest I was getting very bored after a few minutes: it was the second hero I played, I thought as a mage she'd rely on her abilities, but it turns out she doesn't and I started feeling like Dota relies far too much on auto-attacks, as much as ADCs on LoL, despite the fact that I got a mage. Then,I tested this feeling by playing other heroes on a test/sandbox mode (write that down Riot). I felt a slight feeling of enjoyment when I used the given cheats to reduce the cooldowns of my abilities and made my hero invincible, and once again I thought I found a spellcaster but he turned out to use auto-attacks by necessity too much. What completely ruined my experience was Io. I'm not going into details, but I activated the max level cheat and used my ultimate which could have killed me because of its fast health and mana drain. So in a last hope to like the game, I spectated a game and asked its spectator chat what I should do to enjoy the game. This is when I met the Dota community, which seems to be even worse that of LoL, and look at its state. I got advised to 'play medusa and afk 80min', to feed, to troll... In order to enjoy the game, I got told to become toxic. There's no way I'm doing that, so I closed the game and promised myself I'd never play it again. I felt like everything was wrong about it, honestly. So if you liked LoL and liked spell-casting champions there, I do not recommend this game at all. If you liked fast-paced fights and strategic moves, don't download this game. Heroes could have been very different from each other if they relied more on their abilities, instead I felt like each one of them was an ADC that had slight differences from the others. This one could fire a fiery laser while moving, this one becomes a boulder that goes wherever he wants, this one screams sometimes... I'm out after less than an hour.

So I've been playing around 500 hours of Dota2 now. I feel like it's an appropriate time for me to rate this game.  Number 1, this game is super addicting. Each match can last OVER an hour. So unless you want to waste your whole day away, don't play more than liek 4 matches.  Number 2, this game requires alot of brain work; more than CS:GO or any other NORMAL game (even Skyrim and RPG games with a market). There are hundereds of items, heroes (and abilities, and item combos and recipies. Each item/combo/ability adds a new feature to the match. Like most MOBAs, your hero has his starting ablities and base damage/mana pool. BUT you need to have everything memorized and know the compatibility between the two. It took me at LEAST 2 months to understand everything. So plan on playing for 3 months without understanding how to properly play.  Number 3, the market sucks. I have around 70 dota2 items as of now, and only 10 of them are marketable. Only 3 of my items that are marketable I did NOT buy. The reason behind this is because the Valve market SUCKS for Dota2. You do NOT make any money what so ever. I would suggest TF2 or CS:GO over this to make money while playing.   Number 4, the people in the matches are really salty. They don't know how to respect people, and most of them are rude. It's fun to meet that one person that you keep as a friend for a while, but even then, it can get pretty annoying to hear 5 year olds mic spamming (like any MMO game).  Number 5, there really isn't a point to this. DotA (Defence of the Ancients) is a really fun game that has been sucessful, but in the end, you'll still be defending that Ancient. So have fun brawling over and over again!  Just my thoughts.  -LukeS I_M_3rd

Meh... it's not really my type of game. It looked really cool and I was super excited to finally play it, but I wasn't really into the mechanics... I only played the tutorial under the 'Learn' tab, so I probably am missing experience for the review, but I just couldn't stand the game as far as I had played it. I've never played a game where you are not suppose to be dealing the most damage to your opponents. You're suppose to let the bots go after everything? I guess in that aspect it's a little like chess and pawns... So I guess I like playing chess, but don't like videogames that are like chess. The game was a bit glitchy as well. 'Press space to focus on your character!' (presses space, the camera shoots to this bare random part of the map) 'Press the F3 key to have your bought items from the store delivered to your character out in the battlefield!' (presses F3 MULTIPLE TIMES only to end up running back to my fountain to get the items myself) My A.I. companion just ran in circles the entire time!! Say what you will, but I was very excited for this game only to end up being disappointed... maybe I'll try again some other time.

Downloaded the game and gave it a try. Did not like the controls, camera, or community. I think the die hard players are what really got to me. I understand that this is a complex game in need of practice, but I feel like its basic set up is in reverse to helping new players. I love the Valve inclusions of that voice for kills and character customization of its appearance. But that is really about it.  In short -> Complex, convoluted, and most the players are rude and unhelpful. Would only suggest to those I dont want to play with.

Why i don't like the game:  First of all and most important, this is not NOT not NOT a team game. Why?   -The game structure and meta is focused on making one player fed and then he carries his team to victory.  -Supports have to stay far away from the other team mate in the lane they share because this way only the other guy will have the full experience from cs(if both stay together, they will have the exp shared between them, so this means that they both can fall behind fast compared to the other team). (and don’t even dream on touching the cs of the guy. As if the toxicity of most players wasn’t enough, you have to only have fun in this game without taking part of the action for the most part of the laning phase. Pffffttttt. Can this be more stupid as it is? Yes. Just continue reading)  -Only one player can buy wards. Yup. The same guy that has to sit on his thumb since the beginning of the game.  • Other gameplay mechanics:  Controlling the currier is frustrating, especially when you want an item and he is going to grab something for another player. You have to wait. And then you have to be positioned in a way that the currier will not get killed by the enemy. As if you can control that (ex: when you are getting killed because of a gank in the same moment that the currier arrives. o.0)  There is a secret store. As if buying wasn’t a frustrating experience for new players. This store has some recipe items for the most OP higher rank items. Good luck understanding that in the tutorial or in the actual custom item build section of the game were they don’t show you the recipes.  You are close to victory and just destroyed the inner turret of mid lane. Then you see 2 melee barracks and2 ranged barracks and 4 other structures. I only ask why? Why so many useless stuff between me and my team mates victory?  River runes. Random spawned runes that give various bonuses. It’s a rush game for them. They cannot actually be contested. It’s” just pick me up” and you will have a stupid game mechanic that sometimes can be OP (if you find the double damage). I think it’s stupid and it doesn’t favor the good players.  Hey look. I’m with low HP and I need some health. Ohhhhhhhhh. I know. I’ll eat a tree. -.-‘  Loosing gold after death. As if cs was an easy task. Let me explain. You are playing a ranged champ. And you see a low hp minion. You think: ok since I am low level I’ll hit it only when he is really low. Yeaaaaahhhhhh. My bullet took 15 years to travel to him, so now I have to try to approach the cs with so much anticipation that even the enemy will know what I’m trying to do, and now they can hit me for free every freaking time. And now another fun game mechanic for noobs: I’m dead and my item is there for grabs (only some higher “ranked” items). Hahahaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.  Glyph of fortification: omg. Really? Is this a good thing? Protecting structures for a short period of time. This combined with some other stuff makes the game last longer than it should (in conjunction with players being afraid of being killed by the enemy fed player, being afraid of stealing kills, afraid of stealing creep score, of dying and droping items and being flamed at because you are a noob (even if you play the game for like 1000 years). The game is actually boring because it lasts too long. It’s unrewarding from beginning to end and a frustrating experience, and more so for new players that have to learn all this stupid stuff that is totally questionable if it’s good for the game or not. Other moba game players look at this and say: DAMN BITCCCCHHHH. FK THIS CRRRAAAAAP. (vomit)  Speaking of vomit. Rushan drops a cheese. (not a wood(y). But at least I beg some coherence in this crap. Why food when players can eat wood?)   • Some small things I think that ruin the game  Buy teleport scrolls. With what space in the inventory? The same space I need to have my recipe components of the item I want and potions and my wood(y) eating crapp? Ohhhhh. Ok.  Learning the jungle creeps. Some of them are not affected by skills from champs. Can this game be more boring and slower? I can’t even use my skills? Really? Damn.  Learning the champions. Yeah. Good luck on that noob. Learning all of them will take weeks (at least to understand what they do when you face them in the enemy team). There isn’t any good info on how to play them or to make item builds for them (try the in game item build and you will cry) it’s just looking at people doing things and no actual guide on how and why (DOTA players do this on purpose, so they can rub on noobs faces that this game is much complicated that LOL. Yes it is. It’s too much stupid useless stuff on it. It doesn’t make any sense. When they say that more skill is needed for this game it’s a lie. This game is slower. You have time to think, and dream, and take a bath, and kiss your girl, and then you fail the last hit on the cs. But if you get unlucky (vs a more experienced guy) you will die. Yup. Tadaaaaaaaaa. The same as any other game. Pfffttttt. Duhhhh. And face rolling (in the key board) is slower. Even that is boring. Jesus. Being hit by the crowd control skill that lasts for 5 years will make you die (eventually, I hope), and this is why this game is ruthless on mistakes. Ohh wait. One stun that needs no skill to hit (it isn’t a skill shot) and lasts 5 years is another reason why dota players say that this game is ruthless and needs more skill than other mobas. Yup, fk logic.  All “high rank items” are freaking expensive. Why? They know that this game will take too freaking long, and it will be no fun, then they make you suffer to get a full build before the game ends. DOTA2 devs say: suffer biiiitttttccccctcheeeesssssss.  When you win a game, you will earn some random useless (immediately useless. Maybe useful later, I don’t care) stuff that you can blender with some other useless stuff, so you can get one random useless thingy, and there are ways to take advantage of this, like special recipes or whatever (another thing to look at in guides and make you waste more time looking for stuff on the internet and not appreciating a good gaming time). This is a must for me: a big effort (trying to win games) just to get one random stuff that isn’t going to make my game experience better. Essentially, no rewards. Wow, nice.  Denying. Omg. Denying cs. Hahahahaha. The enemy will earn exp because you killed your own minion. Fk logic. This is another reason that the freaking game is so boring and takes too long. And to add pain to injury: suicide. Hahahahahahahahaha. This one just killed me. You can actually deny your death to the enemy team. Ok, listen carefully. I will only play this game if they make one item I just came up with. The item is a strapon, and it’s called U.R.ACuuuUNnnnT. this item could be activated when team members have less than 75% HP, and it will kill then instantly and has no cooldown what so ever. This is actually the only thing that is missing from this game to make it totally fked up. And another: an item that denies the cs denial. And can deny the deny from the deny that was denyed in the first place. How about that for a mind fk.    Overall, the game looks bad in my opinion (it reminds me of Diablo 2 graphics but in hd and polished), its slow, unrewarding, it’s not a team game, lots of toxic players, the game has an individual ranking system (in a fk ing team game!!!! Wut?). It’s bad like the most known mobas.  You want to kill your brain cells. Try this game. It will make you angry and you will lose the perception of what a fun “thing” is in real life. This game is like LoL (League of Legends). I never played LoL, but I can tell you this: LoL is more of a non-serious game, where you compete for fun. It is more easy as well, but DOTA 2 (Defense of the Ancients 2) is more serious in terms of being bad = being reported. If you get reported, most likely you will be sent to low priority which results in longer wait time for finding a game. It is also more punishing than LoL, which results it making more harder than LoL. If you are looking for another MOBA game, give this a try. If you are tired of noobies in LoL, play this and quit LoL. More likely you will find better players in here than LoL. There is also good sportsmanship in this game. Rise up the ranks to be in better games. 9/10

Dota 2 is probably the most frustrating game ever created. Your team will let you down constantly, the enemy team will consistently pick the heroes you hate playing against the most, you will never get the hat drops you want, and your own mind and body will frequently betray you and make you contend with the fact that you are not nearly as good as you think you are (or, more likely, force you to live in a fantasy dream world where you are as good as you think you are and just blame your teammates some more). It'll turn you into a monster and destroy your life. It'll murder your loved ones and feed them to you.  But you'll play it anyway. You'll ragequit and uninstall and stare at your library of games as the creeping realization sweeps over you that you not playing Dota 2 will not effect the universe in even the smallest way, will have no conceivable effect on anything. You will be filled with a sudden dread that nothing you do matters and life has no meaning. Basically the same feeling you get when you play Dota 2. And Dota 2 will be your only distraction from this dessicated husk of a life. So the next day you'll find yourself drawn back into it like a moth to a flame, staving off the moment when you'll have to face your demons for as long as you can. You will probably die alone some day and nobody will remember how high your MMR was or your sunstrike accuracy.  So what are you waiting for, you worthless peons? Get out there and dance! DANCE FOR THE PUPPETMASTER GABE!

Please don't play it.  I know I'm going against the grain by saying this, but please, don't play Dota 2. Now, I know what you're thinking: 'But all my friends play it! It must be good, right?' NO. That feeling is that thing they called 'peer pressure'. Of course, usually when they say that, they're discussing things like smoking and alcohol. Both are addictive substances. Dota 2 is an addictive game.  This leads into my first point:  don't stick with a game because of your friends.  You need to be able to judge a game for your own and separate with it if you don't think it's fun.  My second point is that  this game requires a heavy investment before you can enjoy it properly.  This game is a very complex game. I can't attest to its depth, but only because it's so complex that I can't see the bottom of the lake. But know that it's only so deep because it's so wide. And because it's so wide, you'll have to learn a lot before you can swim in it.  The learning curve of Dota 2 isn't so much a  curve  as much as it is a  cliff . There's a ton to learn about it, and if you're not ready, willing, or able to do a lot of studying, you can't enjoy a game like this to its full potential. I tried to learn it all. I couldn't. So I stopped playing.  My third point:  there's no singleplayer content.  Like TF2 and CS:GO, it's a multiplayer-only game. Now, that would be fine and dandy  if it weren't for my fourth point:  the players are dip♥♥♥♥♥.  From the many and varied foreigners shouting '♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥' at you to the suckers that yell 'MID OR FEED' and, when denied middle lane, feed extensively and generally ruin the game.  On the subject of the players, here's a fifth point:  nobody's concerned with the game itself as much as they are with the professional players.  Having a strong eSports scene is good, I agree, but when it's the only thing people care about, well, the game might have a lack of purpose beyond that.  A relatively minor complaint for my sixth:  the lore sucks.  It's not compelling, impactful, or even cared about by anyone. If you ask any random Dota player what Crystal Maiden's real name is, it's not really likely that they'll say the name 'Rylai.' In fact, there's a high chance they'll say, 'Who cares?' Dota's lore really doesn't affect or justify anything that happens in-game. It sucks.  My seventh is probably the ♥♥♥♥♥iest, but it's the one I have the most trouble with:  nothing makes sense from an in-universe standpoint.  Why are the lane creeps traveling on lanes instead of taking more discreet paths through the jungle or just rushing at each other head-on? Why are there random monsters in the jungle just hanging around waiting for someone to kill them? Why does any soldier on any of the three armies have money on them? Why do I have to bother with laning and getting items when I'm already supposed to be a ghost made of ice that could already deal with anybody you wanted? Why do I need items anyway? What's the deal with sitting around in a lane for two hours farming? Why does holding on to a pair of boots (really, not even wearing them, just  holding on to them ) make me move faster? Why does buying a sword increase attack damage for an archer? Why is any of this the way it is?  Because the gameplay demands it.  Because thou must.   In my opinion, that's a poor reason.  So, in conclusion, it's a game with amazingly complex gameplay, but it has a huge learning curve and nothing in the game makes sense outside of gameplay rules.  And hey, if that's your jam, I'm not stopping you.  But please don't.

This is a great game but only if you can play with 4 friends or work hard to reach the olympian of the best competitive players (aka high mmr). Explanation: moba genre has a problem: teamwork + random people. I mean, even if the matchmaking was perfect, there are others factors that lead to unbalanced games, most notably 'i want to try a new hero' and 'heroes have sinergy with others' => you play with people who choose their hero as they want and don't care about the synergies or if the chosen heroes are bad against opponents picks => people fails, teammates cry => lots of noobs, flamers. So play with friends and vocal communication, you'll know their game style, you'll know their moves, YOU ALL KNOW HOW TO PLAY LIKE A TEAM. The other road is to reach slowly an high mmr, because real competitive players even without communication know the game so well that can adapt to each over picks and play like a pseudo-team, but it's very hard and painful.

I was reluctant for years to play this game due to its blatant stolen properties from Warcraft 3; a game I grew up with. Though that same idea is what made me give this game a chance to begin with. I've played DotA 2 for about a week now and have come to the conclusion that this game is not very good at all. Allow me to explain.  Sure, the gameplay is generally solid and relies heavily on team coordination (which can be both a pro and a con), but other than that it isn't exactly a welcoming title -especially to newcomers. With a single map to play on, you're given the option to play over a hundred different heroes; each with their own strengths and weaknesses. While looking through the character screen to decide who I wanted to play, I noticed some archetypes listed on the bottom to narrow your search. Although one of them really stood out to me, 'carry.' At first I thought this was a complete joke. The word 'carry' is usually a derogitory term used in just about any other game, but here it was a legitimate strategy for any team to have a heavy carry through end game.   I can say I've found my entire experience with this game both very puzzling and frustrating. The mere idea that there are characters made to be so overpowered that they carry a team to victory. Doesn't that kind of defeat the purpose of it being a team game? I understand most carries aren't very useful until late game, but still; I digress.  One major problem I have with this game is its learning curve. It is not an easy game to take in all at once. Not in all facets anyway. However you are entirely expected to understand everything in the game before you even start playing. Not by the game of course -the community. I know it's unfair to judge a game based on its community, but never have I witnessed such belligerant immaturity, stupidity, anger and overall toxicity within a video game. You make even the slightest mistake (or not) and everyone including your own team will jump on you like it's the Spanish Inquisition.   I have plenty of experience and time spent with online gaming in general, however I cannot recall ever wishing a match to end preemptively. You should want to play the game you're playing, right? I would like to enjoy DotA 2, but I beleive I'm done with this game now. There is absolutely nothing here to keep me and the meta is abyssmal.   Sorry, but I'm not recommending this game at all unless you have a full group to play with first. If you go solo to play with randoms, good luck.

TL;DR: No, items aren't useful enough and punishment for deaths are too harsh. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To be honest, despite the low amount of hours I have on this game, I would not recommend this game by any means to anyone who wants to play a Moba and aren't gods at them. Two big reasons:  One: Items.  Most items are very useful and easy to use, but simply don't offer enough in terms of defense against stacked characters. No matter the items, if you are versing a Lion who is decent enough, he will kill you unless you or others kill him first.  Two: The biggest one, YOU ARE PUNISHED FOR SUCKING NO MATTER YOUR SKILL LEVEL Yeah, this might seem weird, you would want people to be punished for doing bad, but apparantly to Valve missing out on XP and possible kills isn't bad enough. So they thought about how else could they punish someone who is sucking, no matter if they legitimately don't know what they are doing or if they just are having a bad game, and it struck them: Let's have them lose gold. Yeah, if you are having a bad game, you will never come back from it because you'll never have the gold to get the items to help you. It's a simply screwed system that can't be fixed.  So yeah, thanks for reading this through if you did.

Contrary to what most people say, Dota 2 does not have a steep learning curve; it is easy enough to learn the mechanics of the game, such as height advantage and couriers. The difficulty comes with remembering how all the mechanics work in conjunction with one another, as well as when and how to use them while playing. Dota 2 has over a hundred unique heroes, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, and the game does not pressure you into learning every single one. However, if you want to become skilled at the game, you should probably learn and play every hero. Dota 2 is a highly competitive game, capable of bringing out the worst in people, but also capable of making you feel like a real winner. With that said, it is HIGHLY recommended you play with friends, as the game relies highly on teamwork and synergy.  TL;DR: Play it with friends, if you have the patience to learn.

As much as I'd wish to give Dota 2 a good review, I really cant. Ranked match making is completely broken unless you abuse the system (or you're just hella good). As a solo queuer, it's pretty darn impossible to advance if you play during normal EST hours since you're most likely going to get a bunch of south american players who speak no english, complain, or throw every time.   Having wasted over 1k usd on the game, I clearly ♥♥♥♥ed up, and hope others avoid this mistake :)

4000 hours of Dota 2 has shown me that while the base game is good, it will never take the evolution that it needs.  Cons:     Developers only care about pro play.    Match-making ruins the game experience.    No region locking. It doesn't matter which region you que into, you will get mostly non-english speakers who have no idea how lanes work.    Decade later, still no surrender button. Could be 60-0, you still need to play or be penalized.    Support is a thankless, basically boring role that nobody plays. This remains a constant even up and over 4k mmr.    The climb is near impossible.   I have given up and came back many times over the last 6 years, but nothing of matter ever changes. If you only care about playing and having fun once in a while with friends, by all means, play away. If your goal is to have fun, competitive games every time while improving your MMR, I wish you luck, but suggest you give League Of Legends a fair chance instead.

Dota 2 is the official sequel to the highly popular mod for Blizzard's Warcraft III, Defense of the Ancients. A mod that has been worked on by many, and therefore it was hard to determind where the rights belong. A lot of legal hocus pocus were going on between Blizzard and Valve last year, and it ended to valve's favor. The Dota name and franchise is now legally a part of Valve, probably thanks to the sneaky acquisition of IceFrog the year before.  Dota 2 is a real-time strategy game in the sub-genre called MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena). A genre that has grown rapidly the past few years, with different type of alterations in favor of success. Dota 2 is a close second to being the most popular MOBA, right behind the giant League of Legends. Just like LoL, Dota 2 is gaining success throughout it's competetive e-sport scene, and it's clear that valve is highly pushing it towards the first position. The latest and biggest tournament was The International 2013, which included a total prize pool of over 2.8 million US dollars, which was the biggest prize pool in e-sport history.

I couldnt decide what to write in this review , so im gonna share with you guys my favorite apple pie recipe Enjoy! :D  Pastry  2 cups all-purpose flour   1 teaspoon salt   2/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons shortening   4 to 6 tablespoons cold water   Filling  1/3 to 1/2 cup sugar   1/4 cup all-purpose flour   1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon   1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg   1/8 teaspoon salt   8 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples (8 medium)   2 tablespoons butter or margarine   1) In medium bowl, mix 2 cups flour and 1 teaspoon salt. Cut in shortening, using pastry blender (or pulling 2 table knives through ingredients in opposite directions), until particles are size of small peas. Sprinkle with cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all flour is moistened and pastry almost cleans side of bowl (1 to 2 teaspoons more water can be added if necessary).  2) Gather pastry into a ball. Divide in half; shape into 2 flattened rounds on lightly floured surface. Wrap in plastic wrap; refrigerate about 45 minutes or until dough is firm and cold, yet pliable. This allows the shortening to become slightly firm, which helps make the baked pastry more flaky. If refrigerated longer, let pastry soften slightly before rolling.  3) Heat oven to 425°F. With floured rolling pin, roll one pastry round into round 2 inches larger than upside-down 9-inch glass pie plate. Fold pastry into fourths; place in pie plate. Unfold and ease into plate, pressing firmly against bottom and side.  4) In large bowl, mix sugar, 1/4 cup flour, the cinnamon, nutmeg and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Stir in apples until well mixed. Spoon into pastry-lined pie plate. Cut butter into small pieces; sprinkle over filling. Trim overhanging edge of pastry 1/2 inch from rim of plate.  5) Roll other round of pastry into 10-inch round. Fold into fourths and cut slits so steam can escape. Unfold top pastry over filling; trim overhanging edge 1 inch from rim of plate. Fold and roll top edge under lower edge, pressing on rim to seal; flute as desired. Cover edge with 2- to 3-inch strip of foil to prevent excessive browning.  6) Bake 40 to 50 minutes or until crust is brown and juice begins to bubble through slits in crust, removing foil for last 15 minutes of baking. Serve warm if desired.

Graphics: 9/10 (visually stunning, but the details/character models are confusing if you've just switched from Dota 1)  Sound/Voice Acting: 8/10 (sound quality is okay, the theme/menu music is kinda cool, but ofcourse gets repetitive or goes unnoticed as time goes by while playing. Character voice acting is okay as well as the announcer)  Gameplay: between 3/10 to 9/10 (the reason why I gave a range is because the learning curve for this game is pretty high but can get pretty addictive once or if you can get the hang of it)  Story/Plot: N/A (this is like football or basketball or counterstrike, there is no story, just one game at a time which usually last between 15 mins to an hour)  Community: 1/10 to 10/10 (This is a multiplayer focused game, and the reason why I gave a range of the full spectrum is because it will highly depend on who you're playing with)  Final Verdict:  This is a very huge step up from DOTA 1 IMO and can be really fun if played CASUALLY with friends.. But can be also be really brutal if played alone and/or with random people depending on your people skills and general level of skill in DOTA. Teamwork will be the deciding factor wether you will either feel total satistaction or depression, when playing this game

As a pure multiplayer only game, I am very happy to say that this game is a satisfying experience. Not everyone may find the MOBA format fun, but for those who do like this genre, this game is excellent. First of all, it has the one thing that competitive multiplayer games must always have: light minimum specification to play the game. Pretty much any kind of semi-recent PCs or laptops can run it to various degrees of performance, unless it's a extremely old rig. And then there's the excellent business model. The game does have somewhat of a progression system, unlocking pretty much everything past level 15. Game modes and different drop rarities are unlocked before that, and while it does take a while to get to that benchmark, you do get a free booster to smooth out the process. But do note that levels have NO effect on your performance whatsoever, and only matters for unlocking different modes and cosmetic drops. If you don't plan to climb the rankings, it doesn't really concern you other than the guaranteed drop you get every time you level up. The cosmetics look great though. Other than that, the game is filled with features to make you want to immerse yourself in the community. Got quota-limited internet like me and can't watch streams without wasting tons of bandwidth? Watch the games on the spectator mode, which does include a broadcaster mode. All major tournaments are casted there as well, and you can watch them for free or even buy passes and get prizes for watching the games (including limited edition cosmetic items). All of this is only possible thanks to Valve's status as pretty much the holder of a good majority of digital game sales.  Alright, enough of the extras. Is the game any good? It is. Is it fun playing the game solo in the long term in a casual manner? Thanks to the competitive nature of the genre, not really. Unless you have a group of people to play the game with or plan on being seriously involved in getting competitively better in the game, playing solo will often lead to great frustration. However, learning the game by itself isn't a horrible experience, surprisingly. The tutorial is quite excellent and the bots are challenging, though not unfairly, for newbies. All in all, it's a game you will love if you like the genre and like climbing a rather steep learning curve.  TL;DR +) Good minimum spec requirement +) Great business model with little progression requirements +) Lots of community support +) Allows you to immerse yourself in the game experience +) Good tutorial -) Steep learning curve for absolute newbies -) Doesn't fix the solo player's frustrations when playing in a team game
