Okay, figured after extensive experience in this game i would write a review and share a bit of those experiences.  pros  -Solid gameplay mechanics   (it is very fun to try out different heroes and see what they're like with their abilities)  -Item store   (the items store in game allows for some really diverse item choosing, from things that help you earn money/save money after death, to things that will allow you to deal insane amounts of damage.)  -Custom games   (if you get bored with the default game modes (such as all pick), these are very fun to check out)  -Compendium rewards   (these add a new level of reward for playing and, are very fun to see what you'll get, and can be quite addictive, and fun.)  -Hero Customization   (this is a really cool feature in game, you can mix and match different outfits to make the heroes in game your hero.)  -Item marketing   (You can actually play this game and sell items for a profit to buy other games. Which i find very cool.)  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- cons  -Can't opt out of channel joining   (when you jump into the game and connect to the server, you are immediatly greeted by a channel which you join and hundreds/thousands of others have been forced to join. However you can leave the channel as soon as you see it pops up.)  -no preferred player matchmaking  (If you enjoyed playing with someone, or took great displeasure in playing with them, there is no way to avoid them/opt in with them in global matchmaking. You can mute the ones you took displeasure from, sure but you still have to play with them, and thus ruining your ability to work as a cohesive unit and your gameplay experience.   There is a party system in game you can take advantage of to join up with those you like to play with, however like most games i fear party games will match you up with other people who are partied together.(I havn't tried the party system so i don't know too much about this feature) If this is the case then it will be your teams ability to work together vs theirs, which in some cases your opponents could be pros and so you lose possibly every game until you learn to work just as good.)  -reporting players for bad conduct  (Although this is a feature in game, i feel it isn't enough to stop people from herassing you or others. After you report someone valve says they have taken action against these users at times, however... after you've reported them you still find them in matches thus ruining your play of the game.(There are numerous solutions to this problem i can think of, so im not sure why valve allows this to happen to their players.))  -bullying  (now this is a major issue in game. When you, or one of your fellow teammates do badly in a match, because your still learning how to play or just plainly doing badly during the match, the bullies jump out to rage on you. They won't just stop there however. They appear to band together almost like a gang to join your matches to herass you and spread hate about you to other such gang members or normal player (so i would suggest changing your profile name from time to time if you plan to play this for exended periods.))  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  personal note  (I really enjoy playing ability draft, the combinations you can do are very OP others not so much. The amount of bullying going on is a real issue for me in this game. After this summers compendium is over and i sell my items, i will probably uninstall this game forever. It was a fun ride to check out, but the stress of playing just isn't worth the little amounts of time you can actually enjoy the game. I would not suggest this game for anyone to play, for mental health reasons.   I feel bad about the young people who will be suckered into playing this game, only to be bullied online. This could be a real issue since adolesent teens can have intense mood swings, some may commit suicide after numerous bad experiences, especially if they are considering being sponsered to play this game.)   There are many other features i havn't mentioned in this list, however this is just a list i cared to write so, take it for what it is.   Take care out there, its dangerous.

A huge influx of league of legends players have come over since the Reborn update and I seldom play games with people who understand the dynamics of DotA, Dota 2 or the Allstars heroes in general, they just don't ♥♥♥♥ing 'get' the game.  Before the Reborn update, I would give credit to about 70% of the people I played with, they understood lane equilibrium, denying towers, denying allies, denying creeps, they understood proper roaming mechanics, when to leave mid lane, when to force fights,  Also the games didn't last an 45 mintues to an hour. Not a huge fan of MOBA games, but I started playing the Dota 2 beta in late 2012 (Christmas to be exact) with a few friends and although I didn't feel much for it I still played since it was something for my friends and I to play together and still play on a fairly daily basis to this day (April 24, 2014). I've played League of Legends and other similar MOBA games, and none really match up to Dota for me, it could simply be that I'm familiar with it and have friends that play it, but I also feel strongly that Dota has a much better system overall and has immensely improved with updates. The game has now officially launched and I am comfortable with giving a review after playing for a great deal of time with friends. I would highly recommend giving the game a try, and if you have friends who play it, ask them to teach you. I have fun playing Dota for the most part because I have friends who play as well. Playing with friends as a team in a MOBA game is recommended as it's always better than teaming up with someone you don't know. If you're looking for a good game to play with your friends that is free I'd direct you at Dota, and hit me up if you do too, we'll be best friends! Friends all around.

It is most definetly a fun game, and frankly, you would be hard pressed to find anybody who hasn't heard this before. If you have heard of this game and just haven't picked it up, I would recommend doing so. If you are unfamiliar with MOBA's I would not consider starting with this game. That is my major complaint. This game has a definite learning curve, and for newer players, there are multiple UI choices that exemplify this. The camera is hard to control at first, and there is no simple way to have the camera follow you. There is no recommended tab for items in the item store, meaning, you have to figure out which items work best for every character before you know what the items do. Additionally, I can't find any form of tutorial to teach you the game mechanics, so it is either nonexistant, or hard to locate. Either way, all of these factors make for a difficult experience for newer players.   Side Note- Your team is going to be especially hostile towards you if you play poorly, and they will almost never give any tips to help you play better. Expect a very poor game community, especially if you are new.

I've played dota for eight or nine years. It is fun and worth the time and effort to learn.   Unfortunately, Dota 2 is currently maimed by an idiotic matchmaking system that punishes you for winning. That's right, punishes you. You win a few games, get over fifty percent w/l, and then all of a sudden you're getting match with guys that don't speak english and fail to understand even basic concepts of the game. Then, when you lose a ♥♥♥♥ load and your winrate is down to forty eight or forty nine percent, you're magically tossed back into a group of people that actually know what they're doing. Then you get a win streak, and get some wins and get out of the hole.   Then the cycle starts all over again. There is no way around it. No amount of always taking a carry, or always taking mid, or always waiting to pick to get what your team needs is going to help you improve your w/l rate. It is rigged, and it is frustrating.  There is also no excuse for the servers for english speaking people to always be flooded with people that don't speak english. This is not racism, this is common sense. You're playing a team based game so you need to be able to communicate with your team. It is ignorant of Valve to allow non-english speakers on the servers in such overwhelming numbers, as that it ruins the play experience for all involved.

This game is nothing other than money grab. Valve is too busy creating cosmetics for easy money to fix bugs that have been in the game for years like creeps following you through fog of war or a more recent game breaking bug that causes the screen to freeze and turn completely white in the middle of the game forcing you to restart Dota with no guarantee that the game was paused. You can also expect to be put in low priority games about once a week because it currently takes around 3 reports in 20 games to send you to low prio. That is 3 people reporting you out of the possible 180. The game is centered around competitive play to the point that there is really no reason to play if you don’t intend on getting better. However the ranking system is currently the simplest and most inadequate of any “competitive” game out there if you win you get +25 MMR if you loss -25 no matter your performance. Go 15/2 as a phoenix that started the game as a support then was forced in to the carry role because you’re the only one that isn’t currently 0/10 clearly you’re not a good player or you could have won that game. The ranking system is so awful that a black market of accounts has popped up so now any scrub with 20 bucks can buy an account in your ranking were he doesn’t belong and give you 0% chance of winning the game. I wouldn’t consider getting in to the game at its current state 12,000,000 players and it’s still a buggy mess with incompetent players that are unavoidable at any skill level.

Okay, so this is the first time I write a review. Normally, I never write review, but I think this is needed.  1700+ hours on dota 2, okay maybe this is not much like the other older player that maybe play already more than 4000 hours.  I already played Dota 2 since patch 6.83, and I found Dota 2 extremely addicting till the 6.88. New hero, a slight bit change of ability, new item. It's a small change but it change a lot in gameplay for Dota. And yes I already played Dota for about 4 years.  Today, the new patch came out (7.00) sized about 6,6 GB. I don't know if valve want to make a new game or what. I found these patches are extremely stupid. The first time I need to make a complain about this patch. All are new, even the hero even the gameplay. big changes on the map, everything is crazy.   I am sure even all the pro players having some critical thinking on these big patches. I would like to say go on make this Dota 2.5 in a test or something. I am sure also even all the former players of Dota 2 want it to revert the changes. Honestly, this is like Lol or HON, even crazier.  Big patches should not be applied instantly, valve you need to review these changes or maybe you will lost a lot of player. This is crazy and maybe you need to start thinking about 6.89.  I think you can update a new survey in dota 2 whether even the players like these new changes to see what you all did. If it has 40% at least a good, then you may have a go.   I remember the Dota 2 Reborn, you guys worked hard and even applied a test on it. Now, it became the new dota. Its a good one. I dont know if they are very desperate for some big changes. But, I think they need to rethink all of these changes.  Funny thing, there is a question whether I recommend this game or not. The answer is yes before the patch 7.00, but for now no is the answer.  Thank You.

Possibly one of the most addictive game i have ever played. Exellent MOBA, definantly better than LoL. The game has an exellent variety of characters to choose from and has pretty decent graphics to it to. The in-game items look really good and are very fun to collect and also sell. However a downside to the game would be the low-priority matchmaking pool which can sometimes be very annoying as if you were to lag out of the game and not reconnect within 5 minutes, you will be put to bad servers with other people in low prior and gain no XP until your 5 games are over. Overall i would reccomend downloading and playing this game.  **UPDATE** Not too sure about the new reborn beta. It has been out for a while now but it just doesn't feel like DOTA anymore. I mean, most things are similiar but they tried to hard on the rework and made it feel so different (not that that's a bad thing), however for a player who's played on the previous UI it's like they started remaking it but then left it unfinished.

There is a lot to talk about in this game, its positives and negatives, so let's get started. Pros :  -Very fun, especially with friends.  -Unique design and characters.  -Intresting and classic lore (evil vs good). -Mostly balanced (emphasis on the mostly) -Not Pay 2 Win -Rampages, FeelsGoodMan (This is a personal one, but coming back from a losing position is amazing.) Cons: (Brace yourself.) -Some heroes are as broken as my life. -Community is more toxic than your underwear after a marathon. -Developers that only really care about that sweet Treasure Chest/Compendium monay. -R A G E  -Possible damage to computer. (See point above) -There is no way to surrender, even in a 100% 'You lost' situation. -For most of us gamers, its really hard to find people that you like playing with, and even more, people that are nice. -Boys below the age of 14 are a real treat, trust me.(Some above that age are great too.) -Extremely hard to learn, requires extensive knowledge of the game. -Lose track of time, games can drag on almost indefinitely. -'I have to go in 30 mins, so I can play one match' players. Conclusion: To be honest, DOTA has been one of my favorite games of all time, and as a MOBA, it is a truly great game. I played this game for a truly a long amount of time as this is one of my many accounts. Been playing this game since beginning, and loved every moment of it. Remember the extremly long Global Silence on Silencer, but no one really cared. Anyway, the game was moving in the right direction right up until Reborn Update.  As with almost every game that Valve 'makes', they turn it into a profit machine, 'Skins are great, Duck gameplay'.(*cough* CS:GO *cough*) I wish that this game wouldn't have turned into such a trash heap full of ♥♥♥♥♥.

I recommend this game to anyone who loves MOBAS, I also recommend that people who want to start playing mobas do now. As dota itslef is becoming a harsh environment for noobs or newbies. I want people who are newbies and noobies to learn not to trash talk and etc. As I Honestly have to say that the Dota 2 community is pretty toxic. But as you get better and better (which would atleast take months or more) the toxic people getting angry will start to fade away. I love dota, it is one of my most played games. Dota is beautiful if you have a beefy computer, if you dont, you can still play it but I recommend that you upgrade your specs to fulfill the true beauty of Dota. Dota also has amazing heroes and so far have no bugs for me. This game is 50% skill 49% teamwork 1% luck, so dont be those people who complain because of their teamates. As you can see by my hours. Play dota, Improve ,and love it    PS: This game is completely free, You dont need to spend a single penny to get an advantage in a match!!!!.

Dota 2 can be described as 'real world' competition simulator. Here's how it works: imagine you and 4 of your friends opened hot-dog stand and want to get max profit out of it, but there's competition going on between you and some other lads who sell same hot dogs for same price. Your goal is to eliminate hot dog storage that's being defended by 3 towers from each side and angry consumers from your and enemy side rush them for some unknown obscure reason. While experience is bearable if you have five man stack, it's still frustraning as you see that your competitors equiping themselves with better sauce and mustard dispensers while you can bearly afford cost of rent. Sometimes I wonder why I even started playing it and remember that it was frustration from other fabulous game. To fully enjoy this game you have to know the essence of Hot-Dog and what makes it heavenly tasty. So in other words you need to read loads of information about many possible hot-dog sellers, that call themselves champions, and their hot-dog making abilities. After you read about them make sure you'll play every single one of them least 10 times before entering glorious matchmaking system, or else you won't atract enough costumers to buy your hot-dogs and won't get money which means no wireless ketchup dispenser. If you happen read all that info and you know how every single hot-dog seller works in given situation, you may start playing and actually enjoying dota2. arsefegits/10

I consider Dota 2 to be the closest thing we'll ever get to a sequel to WarCraft III. For the uninitiated, Dota 2 is the sequel to the WarCraft III mod, Defense of the Ancients, a game that all but launched this genre of games back in 2002-03. Since Activision-Blizzard is busy minting money with other enterprises, I'm taking this opportunity to take Dota 2 and enjoy it as a sequel to one of my favorite games ever.  Dota 2 was snatched away by Valve Software from right under the hands of the mod's original host, Blizzard Entertainment. What is lost in that transition is all connection to the WarCraft universe, which for this fan of WarCraft is slightly disappointing. However, in keeping Dota 2 as close to the original as possible, Valve took the game assets and re-imagined them in such a way that the sharp-eyed gamer could easily detect which WarCraft asset it owes its existence to. This could have been done only as a means to keep the balanced gameplay intact, but either way it was fun for me to say to myself as I played, 'Hey that's the Arthas character right there.'  The premise of the game is fairly simple: you and four teammates each select from nearly 100 heroes, and along with your AI controlled creeps advance along the map to destroy your enemy's ancient, or base. Immediately behind that simplicity lays a game that is both incredibly deep and with a much higher skill ceiling than is found in many competitive online games today. I committed a full 100 hours of gametime to have the mindset that I am only a learner in this universe, and even now after that mark I only feel I have become not horrible at the game.  What makes Dota 2 a game that you can come back to over and over again is that it feels inherently balanced. Many modern online games end up with the scenario where you or your team has brought the veritable knife to a gun fight, and the only thing that remains is how much death and destruction you are to eat. The item shop in Dota 2 solves that in my opinion. Instead of tying all abilities and upgrades to your chosen hero, the item shop allows a team to read a situation and react accordingly with the heroes they are already locked into. If your team just happens to be weak against magic attacks and you end up against five full magic nuker types, you can still save your match by running to the item shop and pick up the Black King Bar.   My only complaints on Dota 2 are two-fold. First is this infant genre has yet to find a way to allow more casual gamers to drop in and out of matches. Once a game of Dota 2 starts, the game is locked in with the ten players it has. Dropping often yields some sort of negative communication. And if someone does drop, no one can come in to take their place. This needs to be addressed at some point.  Secondly - and this is not necessarily the fault of the developer - is that the players of Dota 2 take this game way too seriously. This generation of gamers in my opinion has been brought up that these games, their outcomes and your associated summary statistics are meaningful in a way that matters to you as a person. Of course nothing could be further from the truth, and for gamers of my generation the continuing loss of the random chaos element in online multiplayer video games and the joy that comes from being in it is saddening. It is frustrating to be in matches with players who are so apoplectic about something in which they have no control over - their teammates. No matter how far the technology of video games gets, this one inviolable truth will always prevail: In an online multiplayer video game with random matchmaking, there is no way to control for the vicissitudes of gamers' skill, motive for playing and commitment to the objective of the game.  Dota 2 is another example of how Valve takes a successful mod and turns into something even greater. If you are looking for something truly new, with deep gameplay, a high skill ceiling, and a bright future, Dota 2 is certainly a game for you.

This game is great, with 5v5 and 109 heroes, no two games are the same. My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 when my mother said to him 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop smoking' Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. I don't know if I love or hate this game.

Barbarian's first RTS. We'd hate to have to control more than one unit at a time. The mechanics are archaic, granted that this was a mod for a strategy game that's nearly a decade old, and most of the core gameplay is identical to its first iteration, there's very little replay value (only one map and very few game types, most of which are just the normal game type with an added gimmick or twist), and most of the characters are extremely gimmicky, each falling into one of three generic categories of characters, with 4 different abilities being the only thing setting each character apart from the dozens of others. The game also has quite a few RNG elements, like randomly-spawning powerups and inconsistent damage numbers, making it a joke from the perspective of competitive gaming. But then again, competitive gaming is a joke to begin with, seeing as how a lot of people see ♥♥♥♥ like Call of Duty and Starcraft 2 as games that take legitimate skills and thinking to play. I'd say that the art style is nice, but it's almost all plagiarized from Warcraft 3. Except for one hero. He's plagiarized from Starcraft instead. And god help you if you ever come in contact with the disgusting ♥♥♥♥♥tain community that plays this game. Dota's playerbase is literally the worst of the worst that video gaming has to offer. Oh, and enjoy your forced TF2-style 'hat based economy'. Valve already ruined Team Fortress 2 and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive with that ♥♥♥♥. Now they'll do it again. Not like there's much to ruin to begin with.

Dota 2 is a real-time strategy game in the sub-genre called MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena). A genre that has grown rapidly the past few years, with different type of alterations in favor of success. Dota 2 is a close second to being the most popular MOBA, right behind the giant League of Legends. Just like LoL, Dota 2 is gaining success throughout it's competetive e-sport scene, and it's clear that valve is highly pushing it towards the first position. The latest and biggest tournament was The International 2013, which included a total prize pool of over 2.8 million US dollars, which was the biggest prize pool in e-sport history.

Writing this for the “Love/Hate Relationship” community write-in qualifcation.   I just recently started playing DotA 2 as you can tell. I literally play every game there is with the group of friends I play with on (almost) the daily. Never played DotA 2 with them, however, until recently.   Always heard them talk about it, watched videos with them. Crazy stuff, countless possibilities, crazy combos. All requiring a good game-sense and immense skills when it comes to some heroes.  Never tried to get into it because I've played a lot of MOBAs (have a lot of knowledge on them) and I just didn't feel like getting into a new MOBA (to myself) that required me to learn a ♥♥♥♥-ton of heroes, their abilities, tactics & strategies, techniques, knowledge on how to counter certain heroes, core builds, situational items & just the store's items in general.  But lately, I've been feeling like taking up a challenge like that. I do not like playing a game being very unknowledgeable and possibly ruining the experience of others for the sake of my newbiness. As a new player, I try to play with a full-party being my friends. This means that, yeah, I'll mess up sometimes, but they'll be there to tell me what's right rather than bash me for doing what I did that was wrong. Even when we cannot play as a full-party, however, we happen to come across people that are understanding. Hard to believe, I know, I mean we do come across some toxic players, but hey, that's just inevitable in today's online gaming world.  But what if someone asks me, do I love or hate the game? What would my answer be?  I honestly love it & hate it. It's situational. There are times when I do really good being up against heroes I can instantly learn how to counter and play against, while my friends brief me up on their abilities before I read them real quick in lane. But there are times when ever if I'm told exactly what they do and how to counter them, I just cannot. Some heroes seem like they have really short cooldowns on abilities/ults that should have longer abilities, items that they get to upgrade their ult, etc, all that. It just seems unfair sometimes.   But I know, I'm not one to talk when I just started playing the game, everything is probably there for a reason & things cannot be 100% balanced but everything that I may think or claim is unbalanced or OP might just be normal when all this new knowledge is slapping my face.  I'll get used to it, eventually, I just hope I don't ♥♥♥♥ off a lot of teammates on the way.  I don't feed, I try my best not to, I usually don't end up with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ K/D ratio (except for the last few games). But this is my love/hate relationship with DotA 2. It's amazing, but it's really difficult. I love it... But I hate it?   Nevertheless, another great approach from Valve.  Zitten

Dota 2 is the reason I love this genre of games. I call Dota 2, Dota, I call LoL, MOBA. I don't consider them that much alike other than they have the same basic set up. 5v5, Destroy the other persons main building, lanes, top down heroes that level up, shop system. That's about it.  Why I choose to pick Dota over LoL is pretty simple though. Dota 2, to many peoples beliefs, is much more new player friendly. Not talking about the playerbase but the actual mechanics and set up. There is a good tutorial system that rewards the player with further cosmetics as they progress. The player profile leveling system is purely cosmetic and leveling unlocks more cosmics and gifts. Absolutely NOTHING outside of the match can influence the outcome in it.  LoL has a Glyph, Talent and Power? (Ability) systems that are limited as a new player. You don't have any glyphs at one, you have few talent points to spend at one, you have a limited number of Powers to pick at one. All of these have an affect on the match you are going to play before you play it. That makes it more of a grind to have these glyphs, and have these talents and have all the powers available to feel like you can really play competitively or on an even edge. And while rank is locked to max level, assuring you that it is fairly even, a new player won't get this experience.  When I go into a match with Dota 2, the only thing I know holding me back is personal experience. Which is just built up over time. I pick any hero I want and don't have to grind to unlock one to play or sit through a free hero pool. I get to choose what I like. And if I want to learn how to play em maybe a bit better I can choose an in-game guide that instructs me as I play, what abilities to level up at what levels, and what items to get through the game as well as tooltips on how to effectively use my abilities or items as that hero. This helped me a TON.  I've got only about over 300 hours of Dota 2 as a casual player but I still love it a ton. Unstanding wins and losses is as simple as rewatching your last match as a replay and seeing what went wrong where. Sometimes it's out of your control because of a team mate or a skilled foe. But I've enjoyed every hour I've played and I've slowly mastered how to play 20+ heroes out of the 110+ pool. Though I have at least played almost all the heroes once to get a feel for em.  Gameplay aside, solid sounds and visuals, beautiful graphics, doesn't require a heavy computer to run great. Best of the genre.

DotA has so much depth to it, partly because of the sheer number of characters and items. There are over a hundred heroes you can play at any given time, and just as many items you can build to fit the situation you’re in. No two matches ever play the same way, and there’s a way to counter everyone. And just as the game starts to get stale Valve releases some crazy new patch that changes everything, which I’m still not sure whether that’s good or bad.  In general, the game is incredibly satisfying when you’re ahead. There’s a lot of enjoyment from simply outplaying your opponents and communicating with your team. Unfortunately, the game can become a lot less enjoyable if you’re losing. A (memorable) portion of the playerbase is incredibly toxic, and that shows both in the game and on any forum talking about it. You can be flamed for not doing things properly if you mess up even once in a game - it’s not a common occurrence, but it’s one that you remember for quite awhile.  That flaming tends to happen more when you’re newer to the game, because of its rather steep learning curve. New players often start out doing incredibly terribly, simply because of the sheer number of mechanics there are to learn. There are a lot of tutorials online on how to improve, and once you know the mechanics exist they’re much easier to master. But no matter where you fall on that curve, there’s always new things to learn. Even the best players in the world make mistakes.  Overall, the sheer complexity and variance in the game keep me coming back. It’s a great way to kill some time with friends (or enemies), and it’s a game that I hope to continue enjoying through the 7.00 patch and beyond.

Dota 2 combines the real-time strategy element of traditional top-down perspective, while also incorporating the leveling and itemization system of a role-playing video game. Players are pitted against each other as two distinct factions called the Radiant and the Dire. The Radiant is a faction based at the southwest corner of the map, while the Dire is a faction based at the northeast corner. Players assume the role of one of eighty-five 'heroes' - strategically-powerful units with special skills, who, through combat experience, may progress to a maximum level of twenty-five. The heroes' methods of combat are heavily influenced by their primary property, which can be physical strength, agility, or intelligence. The basic setup of Dota 2 places two strongholds containing critical structures called 'Ancients' at opposing ends of an geographically-balanced map. These bases are connected by three main paths, (referred to as 'lanes'), which are guarded by defensive towers and groups of weaker units commonly referred to as 'creeps' periodically spawned, which traverse their lanes, attacking enemy units and structures upon sight. Players are split into two teams, each consisting of up to five players, to compete as the primary defenders for each Ancient.  The overall objective of each match is to battle through the opposing force's defenses, in order to arrive at and destroy the opponents' Ancient. Because Dota 2 is highly team-oriented, players must coordinate with their teams in order to achieve victory. The towers and stronghold defenses are invulnerable to attacks so long as the towers nearest to the enemy side still stand.

DotA 2. You rage and complain yet you still play. It has this some sort of 'appeal' that makes you wanna play more. With lots of different heroes with their own unique abilities, every game you play is surely different from the others, although you are playing on the same map for the past year.   Teamwork is somewhat non-existent in pub games although sometimes you find players who communicate and cooperate with each other. On the other hand, most of the time you'll find yourself surrounded by strangers who do not even speak English, moreover they act on their own, then blame someone when they die, curse you at their own language, then rage quit. This kinda ruins the fun, as your team will be playing against a more organized team (most of the time). That said, DotA 2 is meant to be played with your friends whom you can communicate and allows you to execute epic plays that will turn around the tide of battle.  DotA 2 is updated regularly with bug fixes, hero nerfs and new features. I think this is what makes you wanna come and play again after 10 straight loses, because most events reward you with great stuff, like in the last Phantom Assassin event, you can get mythical sets and even arcanas for free. There's always room for improvement, even after 10 loses, because every game is different from the other, unless you act the same and do not learn from your mistakes.  If you have the patience, the game will reward you with good stuff, and of course experience to improve yourself ingame. Also lets you learn different languages so you can understand what that feeder says. Good day gaming and do not feed!

DOTA 2 is the best in the MOBA class. I have played LoL, DOTA, DOTA 2 and some lesser known MOBAs and DOTA 2 is by far the best. In addition, it is F2P which is amazing. And unlike, LoL or HoN which require you to use a rotating hero list until you buy your own with real money or accumulate enough in-game currency to purchase a single hero, DOTA 2 immediately gives you access to its entire library of heroes, for free. In LoL as of the date of this post, it would cost $588 to unlock all heroes with real money. (15000RP/$100, total cost heroes 88185 RP. This calculation excludes bundles)   Each character has a unique playstyle and skillset, and doesn't feel like a clone of another character or a cheap rip off. Every character plays a certain role well, and plays it uniquely. Playing well leads to great rewards, and playing poorly has severe consequences.   There are issues with DOTA 2, the biggest being there is a huge learning curve and you are going to start out being bad if you don't have previous DOTA experience. Learning characters skills, what items do, and what you should be doing early mid and late game initially may be overwhelming. However, doing research and practicing eventually pay off as DOTA 2 is truly one of the most challenging and highest skill cap games available. Valve is also implementing (or has implemented) a tutorial, but there is no way the sheer amount of information needed is contained within it. But I'm sure its a great place to start.   Graphics are great. Gameplay is great. Servers seem lag free. Crashes are very rare. ITS FREE!

Dota 2, the succussor to the Warcraft III ROC and TFT now maintained by Icefrog and his team.   Several thoughts come to mind when playing this great RTS game, though it is tedious and frustrating to play at times considering the community, the pro's outweigh the con's by so much.  In my honest opinion the reason why I continue to play Dota 2 is not just for glory and all ( Though to be honest maybe it is haha). Dota 2 encompasses more than just the wins and the rewards you receive. To me it represents so much more that people tend to overlook.  The stuff that people forget is that this game is a TEAM-BASED game and as such it requires a team in order to finish the main objective: Destory the main base of operations for the Dire and Radiant.   In this case what keeps me going is the sheer intensity of strategy to wonder:  Should I save my team-mate? Should I go back to base? Where are all the enemies? If I continue this route, will I be ambushed?  Multiple upon multiple things come to mind when you play this game, because not only must you think rationally and at times abstractly you must consider the base of what Dota 2 starts with a well-oiled team.   Many times, I've come across a team in which they either troll, be passive, ignore, rage-quit, disconnect at the start or even intentionally disrupt the team's flow. This was one of my primary reasons why I am hesitant in playing with other players I don't even know.  Although, when I look back on it, I realize it was a foolish feeling because as you continously play Dota you realize ultimately that:  you learn how to cooperate with your teamates you learn how to adjust accordingly to different situations and circumstances You learn how to strategize with your fellow team mates in order to maintain a strong sense of balance that it doesn't cost the game, but work together towards winning the game.  As an Gamer I realized these thoughts later on, which server to fuel my endeavor to contniue to play with other people just for fun and entertainment.   For every kill we would accomplish, a team-mate would congratulate us For evey nearing death scenario we encounter there is a kind soul attempting to save your skin. For every death we become undeterred and serves to only fuel us even more into winning the game.  And for every single action we take we are closer to making ourselves laugh and have fun in the face of this serious and yet entertaining game that individuals continue to play more and more.  Many people would argue that Dota 2 is just too harsh on it's players and all, but aren't other games also harsh?  When have you ever heard of a Call of Duty player not bash or rage quit in there game? When have you ever heard of a League of Legends player also not bash or rage on there teamates? When have you ever heard of any other game in which OTHER PLAYERS bash, rage, or just plain insult the others because they are losing.  Of course there just words, if you fall under you stand once more, if they insult you, you show them how wrong they are.  For all intents and purposes Dota 2 to me is an entertaining game that I would revisit everytime with a friend, stranger, team, or a guild.   The point is don't let those in the community get to your head or heart, because you never know maybe you'll teach them a lesson in humility, pushing all seriousness aside and feeling the enjoyment and excitement when playing an online game in Dota 2.  In hindsight I regret not being a better teacher or teamate to newbies because it is an unforgiving game with a steep learning curve. Considering the all these faults, players can still have an enjoyable experience playing a game in Dota 2.  All it matters on is if your willing to have a heart to play and learn as you go, because the failures you experience will make you stronger and make friends in the community that will help you have a far more enjoyable experience playing with others for fun.  9.5/10

Dota is bascially a broken game and the devs fail to fix the main problem.   If you random match you basically get whatever random players on your team that know or don't know how to play together. Which basically lends itself to uneven steamrolls.   So Ranked Matchmaking (Solo).  Playing with other people in your skill bracket....   Completely broken. Players are awarded or penalized points based on if their team wins/loses.   The problem is is that it is random and you can have the best game of your life, while another player completely feeds the other team and YOU lose MMR points.  This places you in a lower bracket. At which point you play with players who are worse and you've got a better chance of losing more MMR, thus being placed even lower.   That might work if you chose who you play with. But THAT is TEAM MMR. And as the name implies that reflects on your TEAM MMR points.   If you are in Solo Matchmaking you have absolutely no control or sway over random players on the other side of the internet. You can beg and plead with them to stop playing badly, but you have no control at all.  Then you get dragged down into worse and worse games and the game starts to completely blow.   Dota2 is becaoming very VERY unfun. I try my best to play well but bad players keep ruing game after game whci hdrags me down more and more.  I haven't had a good even, tense well matched game for a month and at this rate I doubt I will ever again.   Steam roll after steamroll or late game givaways are common in low mmr and it's just getting worse.

What can I say? Dota 1 was possibly the first MOBA. And what started as a mod for Warcraft III has come a long way and become one of the -if not the one- most complete MOBA experiences you'll have.  DotA 2 pushes aside the in-game character purchases and the 'play-a-lot-to-get-that-thing-to-progress system'. Starting out with every hero available, the game keeps the player hooked in with actually intense, exciting and fun gameplay; instead of having an ingame shop being your only motivation to keep playing.  This is one of the best online multiplayer experiences you'll have.

i will give it a thumbsup for DOTA . its definitely a game that can improve teamplay and also with the whole lot of heros players get to use .

+ great free2play system, where you pay money purely for cosmetic content + modern graphics, rewards you for having a high-end machine but is also perfectly playable at lower settings + incredible strategic and tactical depth, unique heroes, really good balancing team + allows for great customization of your favorite heroes + really nice utilities like review system, livestreams in client with commentary and much more + incredibly fun with a bunch of friends + huge esports scene  __________________________________  +/- really steep learning curve, the tutorial helps a bit, but you will feel lost as a new player. I recommend playing with friends against bots first a lot. The advantage is however, that there are no flaming kids anymore after you invested a bit of time __________________________________  - solo ranking system is a bit flawed and doesnt really reward you that much - a lot of people on the EU server are from russia, which isnt bad by itself, but many of them refuse to speak english, which can be rather annoying  GREATLY RECOMMENDED

This is legitimately one of the worst games I've ever played. The fact that such a simple game has a competitive community is a bad joke and one of the surest signs that gaming is completely ♥♥♥♥ing dead. The game boils down to two things:  1. Very, very simple teamplay and positioning strategy. The kind of stuff you'd have to be incredibly ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ not to understand. 2. Learning all the heroes and items.  That'd be fine an all, and I'd still be able to say it's a fun casual game or whatever, but it's not fun. I can't figure out why the ♥♥♥♥ this is popular. No aspect of it is satisfying or rewarding in any way. I don't know what the hell happened to people's minds. I palyed this stupid ♥♥♥♥ for over 30 hours and I watched a bunch of tournaments and youtube videos and ♥♥♥♥ to try and 'learn' the 'game' (Protip: If you're not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you can skip that step) and I still can't figure out how anyone extracts any enjoyment from played this aborted fetus of a video game.  10/10, GOTY 2017.
